column2: The selection of the second extraordinary grand jury to investigate the administration of criminal justice in Brooklyn under the guidance of Assistant Attorney General John Harlan Amen began yesterday in Brooklyn Supreme Court. It was adjourned until 10 A.M. today...

De Witt Clinton clinched the team honors as it placed two players in the semi-finals to boost its total to 12 points in the Eastern interscholastic indoor tennis singles championship, sponsored by Clinton, at the 369th Infantry Armory yesterday.

Twelve persons were dead in Chicago last night and the city was almost paralyzed as the Winter's worst snowstorm caused death, injury and property damage throughout the eastern half of the nation as it swept toward New York City. Transportation was blocked in...

MIAMI, Jan. 30.--The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor, at the opening of its Winter session here today, directed President William Green to warn all affiliates against participating in the movement of Labor's NonPartisan League looking toward domination of the National Democratic Convention in 1940.

Vice Chairman John Cashmore of the City Council encountered opposition yesterday from Councilwoman Genevieve B. Earle, the Citizens Union, the Women's City Club and other organizations that are resisting his efforts to get Democratic bills through the Council.

ROME, Jan. 30.--A full account of the part that Italian "volunteers" played in the Catalan offensive from Dec. 23 to Jan. 27 was given today by General Gambara, commander-in-chief of the Italian legionnaires in a detailed report to Premier Benito Mussolini.

Confusion over a New York production of the modern Negro version of "The Mikado" bobbed up again yesterday. The WPA Federal Theatre disclosed it was considering importation of its successful Chicago presentation of the Gilbert and Sullivan work in swing tempo and Michael Todd announced the...

A meeting of the new Association of Customers Men was held yesterday afternoon at the Downtown Athletic Club to elect officers and an executive committee and to adopt a provisional constitution to be in effect until the first general meeting in May.

LONDON, Jan. 30.--A considerable improvemeit in sentiment bolstered the stock markets today and business showed signs of broadening, although operators awaited Chancellor Hitler's speech before taking over large commitments. In the absence of selling, however, bear-covering, after Prime Minister Chamberlain's speech yesterday, materially helped the upswing.

As Falstaff, Mr. Evans continues his increasing treasure of distinguished works. He is a capital fat rogue in a capital play, and the only wonder now is that "Henry IV" has lain in disuse so many years. Under Margaret Webster's invigorating direction, it turns out...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The attack by fourteen private utility companies upon the Tennessee Valley Authority electric power program was rejected in a five-to-two decision of the Supreme Court today. The court held the corporations without legal standing to challenge the validity of the TVA plan.

Invitations have been sent out by Mrs. Thomas Wistar Whitall of Katonah, N.Y., for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Frances Stewart Whitall, to John Leonidas Calvocoressi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonidas J. Calvocoressi, which will take place the afternoon of Feb. 18...

In the purchase by the Irvington Elks Holding Company of the Elks Clubhouse at 925 Springfield Avenue, Irvington, N.J., that property has virtually been restored to the ownership of the Irvington Lodge of Elks. The property was acquired in 1924 by the Irvington Elks and...
PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 30 (AP).--The Spanish Republican Government at Figueras, its temporary seat, was reported to be planning eventually to transport the nucleus of its Catalan army to Valencia.

PARIS, Jan. 30.--The possibility of a French Cabinet upset is foreseen by some persons as the result of the decision of Premier Edouard Daladier to put the question of confidence tomorrow against a Socialist proposal for a general amnesty for all workers who took part in the general strike of Nov. 30.

As Governor Lehman explains in the budget message which is made public this morning, the State will probably find itself next June more than $33,000,000 in the red instead of, as was hoped, comfortably in the black. About $4,500,000 of this deficit can be ascribed to the action of the Legislature of 1938...

George Weinberg, a major State witness in the first Hines trial, who killed himself at White Plains on Sunday with a revolver owned by an investigator employed by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey, was buried yesterday in Mount Carmel Cemetery in Glendale, Queens.

BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 30.-- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's judicial authorities face a gigantic task in verifying atrocity and general terrorism accusations against known and alleged extremists, in addition to ordinary criminals, who are said to have been active here...
An executive committee and a treasurer, selected for the recently formed Institute of Life Insurance, was announced yesterday by the board of managers of the organization.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30.-- Boutet de Monvel entertained today with cocktails at La Folie Monvel. His guests included Mr. and Mrs. Jay O'Brien, Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Brooks, Mr. and Mrs. Aksel Wichfeld, Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, Mr. and Mrs...

With an off year for the Bermuda race, several coastal distance events are being talked of, and the Boston Yacht Club has come out with the announcement of a contest from Marblehead, Mass., to Halifax, a distance of 366 miles, to be started on Aug. 19.

Efrem Zimbalist deferred to program tradition in two major items of his violin recital last night at Carnegie Hall, but he made ample amends to venturesome tastes in two others. Those who haunt the town's concert halls can probably whistle every note of the Vitali Chaeonne...

LONDON, Jan. 30.--British fears of a European crisis in the near future were quieted, although not entirely removed, by the conciliatory passages in Chancellor Adolf Hitler's speech tonight. The speech seemed to foreshadow no new German "push," either in the East or in the West, and for this British opinion was duly thankful.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--Senators representing the cotton-producing States, assisted by experts from the Department of Agriculture, were searching today for a solution to an acute problem facing the nation's major exportable farm commodity and, incidentally, menacing...

MANCHESTER, Vt., Jan. 30.-- Long famous as a Summer resort, the Manchester region, which includes the neighboring towns of East Dorset and Peru, is rapidly gaining wide-spread recognition as a skiing center.

The controversy over courses in sex education in the junior and senior high schools of this city was reopened yesterday by Elisworth B. Buck, vice president of the Board of Education, who urged that "immediate steps to be taken by the board to establish such courses.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 31.--Permanent Japanese garrisons stationed at points throughout South, Central and North China and permanently strengthened naval forces to defend the ports of South and Central China that the Japanese Navy now holds are included in Japan's policy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Jan. 25: A decrease for the week of $24,000,000 in commercial, industrial...

A boy and a girl who had overcome handicaps and attained dis tinction in scholarship and conduct received the Rebecca Elsberg Memorial Prizes of $150 each yesterday in the office of Dr. Harold G. Campbell, Superintendent of Schools.

The $105,000,000 financing program of the North American Company was approved on all major fronts yesterday and, according to present plans, the utility's $70,000,000 of debentures and $34,829,000 of new preferred stock will reach the market tomorrow.

Without ruling directly on the constitutionality of the TVA law, the Supreme Court has held that the fourteen private companies which challenged the Government's power program had "no right to be free of competition" and no "standing to maintain the suit."

The special investigation bureau of the State Tax Department, which has turned over personal State income-tax returns of United States Circuit Court Judge Martin T. Manton to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey for action, is continuing an investigation of tax returns of more...

It would be difficult to find a more eloquent argument for the continuance and the expansion of the WPA federal Theatre's dance project than the production which opened a week's engagement at the Bayes Theatre last night.

The 450 WPA workers who have been reconditioning Grant's Tomb since 1937 were rewarded yesterday afternoon by the association that furnished the funds for the materials used, the Grant Monument Association. The reward consisted of certificates of honor from the association itself and free beer from the association's trustees.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--No matter how it may try, Congress cannot precisely legislate our foreign policy if a President is disposed to exercise two powers conferred on him by the Constitution. One is the power implicit in the office of Commander-in-Chief of the army and the navy. The other is to be found in the broad sentence:

Nine religious, charitable and public institutions are named among the beneficiaries in the will of Charles F. Pope, who died at his home, at 30 East Fifty-fifth Street on Jan. 18, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surrogate's Court. Friends, relatives and employes also receive bequests.

Challenging Adolf Hitler's dictum in "Mein Kampf" that "the people collectively are always stupid," Dr. George Gallup, director of the American Institute of Public Opinion, said yesterday that the polls of his organization definitely demonstrated the mass intelligence of the...

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30.--As the Legislature authorized tonight an audit of assets of the State Teachers Pension and Annuity Fund with a view to a possible reduction in the annual appropriation, the problem of financing unemployment relief was tossed into the lap of a special committee.

Reports that proposals for the release of loan cotton were gaining support in Congress had an unsettling influence on the March position on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices at the close were down 10 points to 3 points up.

Dr. Edwin Milton Beery, a specialist in ophthalmology who had practiced in Brooklyn for more than thirty-seven years, died yesterday in St. John's Hospital, Brooklyn, after a three months' illness. Dr. Beery, who lived at 118 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, where he also maintained his office, was 67 years old.

While boom buying has been conspicuous by its absence, the initial Spring trips of merchants to the wholesale markets here have produced gains in both dollar and unit volume over the corresponding period last year, according to a survey of early volume in major department...

A resolution introduced by a stockholder at the annual meeting of the Adams Express Company yesterday calling for the election of auditors by the stockholders, among other items, was voted down at the meeting.

ALBANY, Jan. 30.--Governor Lehman submitted to the State Legislature tonight a tax program calling for new levies totaling $64,000,000 to overcome a State deficit for the current fiscal year and prevent one is the 1939-40 period.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--Counsel for Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association said in District Court here this afternoon that Secretary Morgenthau and William O. Douglas, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, should be subjected to cross-examination on the legality of their action in proposing to make public ...

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--The Rev. Dr. Francis E. Tourscher, Catholic historian and teacher, died today of a heart attack in St. Mary's Hall, Villanova, where he was stricken as he celebrated mass in the chapel. He completed the mass, in spite of his illness, and...

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Jan. 30. --Bermudians gave a warm welcome to seven of the ten Cavalier survivors this morning when they arrived on the Furness liner Monarch of Bermuda. As soon as the gangplank was lowered Sir Reginald Hildyard, Governor of ...

Yeats joins AE. in the Land of Youth. His genius, the variety of his talents, his distinction in poetry and prose, essay, drama, autobiography, made him the first Irish and perhaps the first English man of letters of this time. Taking the torch, as so many others have done, from Standish...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--Seventeen inspectors of the Bureau of Marine Inspection and Navigation have been suspended by order of Secretary Hopkins pending their answers to questions challenging their integrity in the matter of gratuities, attaches of the Department of Commerce disclosed today.

DETROIT, Jan. 30.--The General Motors Corporation today declared its neutrality in the factional split of the United Automobile Workers of America and deferred negotiations with any officers of the union until their authority had been "clarified."

Trading in cuts was mostly fair in the local wholesale markets yesterday morning. Slaughterhouse business was only fair up to noon. Steer hinds and ribs were strong to slightly higher. Other classes showed little change from last Friday. The kosher markets opened about steady with Last week's close. Conditions as reported by the United State Department of Agriculture follow:

Arthur Collies, better known as Dapper Don, was playing the races --on paper--when Detectives Walter O'Connor and Joseph Hayes of the Main Office Division arrested him yesterday at the Hotel Howard, 66 West Forty-sixth Street. He said he had already run a $5 bill up...

An aftermath of Councilman Joseph Clark Baldwin's charges of inefficiency against the Police Department developed yesterday when Commissioner Valentine, is connection with his request for additional patrolmen next year, admitted that certain precincts in Harlem were undermanned.

The splitting of a uranium atom into taro parts, each consisting of a gigantic atomic "cannonball" of the tremendous energy of 100,000,000 electron-volts, the greatest amount, of atomic energy so far liberated by man on earth, was announced here yesterday by the Columbia University Department of...

Two babies were suffocated and two others rescued last night in a fire in a children's boarding home at 67-11 Garfield Avenue, Winfield, Queens. After saving two of her four charges Mrs. Grace Moller, the proprietor of the home, was overcome by smoke and collapsed as she was attempting the rescue of a third.

Horns sounding a variety of tones, tail lights that flash to indicate turns, and special bumpers to protect tender headlights were among the variety of new products displayed yesterday by 240 manufacturers participating in the trade exposition sponsored by the Automotive...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP).--The Supreme Court ruled today that the National Bituminous Coal Commission may disclose cost data submitted by nineteen coal companies.

Martin T. Manton, senior judge of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals since 1926 and a member of the court since 1918, sent his resignation to President Roosevelt yesterday to become effective at the President's pleasure, but not later than March 1.

PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 30.-- France closed her Spanish border suddenly this afternoon. If it remains closed this may mean the collapse of all resistance to Generalissimo Francisco Franco on the Catalan front.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30.--A rough outline of the third Five-year Plan calling for an increase in annual production as a whole of 38 per cent by the end of 1942 over the production of 1937, the last year of the second Five-year Plan, was given today in an advance release...

In preparation for the expected flood of anti-advertising bills in the current sessions of Congress and forty-two State Legislatures, the Advertising Federation of America has established a national legislative committee, with Frank Braucher, federation director and vice president of WOR, as chairman.

George W. Hill, head of the American Tobacco Company, which was mentioned in the charges filed by District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey against Federal Circuit Court Judge Martin T. Manton, declared yesterday that the tobacco company "is not concerned in this matter."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30.--Judge William M. Lewis, a member of the municipal court of Philadelphia and a national leader of the Zionist movement, died today at his home here in his fifty-fifth year. A brief illness which began with a cold and was complicated by a heart ailment, but which at first was not thought serious, led to his death. He was in a coma several hours.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30.--From wherever persons may live in the United States they may travel to both the New York and San Francisco World's Fairs and return home by railroad for $90 coach fare or $135 first class plus Pullman, J.J. Pelley, president of the Association of American Railroads, announced today.

Riding on the flood-tide of a demonstration that revived memories of days when towns and villages made great fusses over their ring heroes, Melio Bettina, who is to battle Tiger Jack Fox of Spokane, Wash., for the light-heavyweight title Friday night in Madison Square Garden, arrived here last night from Beacon, N.Y.

Although European political news has caused some disturbance to business men in various lines in the last few weeks, war risk insurance underwriters have seen no cause for concern, and there were several who predicted yesterday that there would be no advance in war risk rates unless the European situation...

The Class A singles championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association opened yesterday at the University Club with fortythree competing, one of the largest fields in recent years. And the first day's play was marked by an upset.

Plans for a new sewage treatment plant facing on Bowery Bay, Astoria, Queens, the cost of which is estimated at $500,000, wet a filed yesterday by the Department of Public Works. The plant will cover the area between Forty-third and Forty-fourth Streets, from Berrian Boulevard to the East River.

Georgetown fell prey to its Fordham gymnasium jinx last night and dropped its fourth basketball contest there in two years as the Rams won, 43--34, to snap a three-game losing streak. A Maroon spurt accounted for 15 points in the last ten minutes. Georgetown, although trailing all the way, stayed in the fight up to that point.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 30.--Forecasters of earthquakes, scientific and otherwise, who have been predicting a repetition of last Tuesday's shock in spite of the government's efforts by repeated reassurance to avoid spreading panic were vindicated last night and today.

Charles H. Rickert, retired real estate man who was long active in Long Island development promotion, died Sunday at his home, 36-19 Bowne Street, Flushing, Queens, after an illness of several months. His age was 83.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30.--While wheat futures on the Board of Trade had a range today of about 1 cent a bushel, price fluctuations did not accurately reflect the volume of business. Trading was at almost a standstill all through an abbreviated session.

Sentences to die in the electric chair in the week of March 6 were imposed in General Sessions yesterday on Demetrius Gula and Joseph S. Sacoda, convicted Friday night of the kidnapping of Arthur Fried, White Plains business man, on Dec. 4, 1937.

MOSCOW, Jan. 30.--Practically clear of the rest of the field of eighteen contestants, excepting only two, Salo Flohr of Prague loomed tonight as the likely winner of the international chess masters' tournament, the final round of which will be played tomorrow. The Niagara Share Corporation of Maryland reports net assets equal to $2.914 for each $1,000 of debt, to $716 a share of Class A preferred stock, and to $12.58 a share of Class B common stock at the close of 1938, compared to 32,705, to $647 and to $11.19, respectively, a year before.

Bonds showed a firmer undertone yesterday over a broad front in the slowest trading of the year on the New York Stock Exchange. The market, as a whole, seemed to be content to mark time pending the turn of events in Europe and that part of Chancellor Hitler's speech...
The fourth annual North American Wildlife Conference is to be held this year at Detroit. The dates are Feb. 13, 14 and 15.

Telegraph history was written yesterday with a demonstration of the world's first automatic telegraph, which transmits messages in facsimile and is expected to open a new era in written communication. The machine, developed by the Western Union Telegraph Company, was put to use for the first time in the Essex House.

Age hath its honor even if it comes late to the oldest man in town, the oldest college graduate, the oldest commuter, the oldest railroad conductor and so on. A double seniority is rarer.

WHEELING, W.Va., Jan. 31 (AP) --Federal Judge William E. Baker dismissed today a receivership petition filed against the Fidelity Investment Association. The proceedings were started forty-four days ago.

Five proposals for changes in the State's mortgage foreclosure system to effect economies and to simplify procedure will be studied tomorrow at the monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.
The vacant plot at the southwest corner of Yellowstone (Sixty-third) Avenue and Grand Central Parkway, near the World's Fair in Queens, has been purchased by a corporation headed by Harry Rosenthal.

Announcement of specific amendments to the Farm Bill as proposed to the Senate Agricultural Committee exerted yesterday an unsettling influence in trading on the Cotton Exchange.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 31.--The city served notice today on the owners of the Keystone Hotel of its intention to take over management of the 22-story property at Wood Street and Boulevard of The Allies until more than $500,000 in back taxes is paid.
The Queens police opened a wide search yesterday for a temporary clerk employed by the Queens Motor Vehicle Bureau after a shortage of $17,000 had been found in his accounts.

James J. Bambrick, president of Local 32-B of the Building Service Employes Union, announced last night that 10,000 elevator operators and other maintenance employes in 670 buildings in the garment area would be called out on strike some time this morning.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 31.--A bright sun, appearing at noon, allayed nervousness in Concepcion and Chillan. There had been earth tremors throughout the night and an eruption of the volcano Antuco, 125 miles southeast of Concepcion. The volcano had been dormant for two centuries.
BARCELONA, Spain, Jan. 31.-- The Nationalists [Insurgents] advanced all along the Northern Catalan front today, according to tonight's military communique.

Encouraged by the further improvement in share prices abroad, reflecting the easing of the political tension, the stock market extended its recovery yesterday, many leading issues finishing with net gains of 1 to 3 points.
Sharp protests against Governor Lehman's budget and tax program were made yesterday by many realty, taxpayers' and trade organizations in New York.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31.--Wheat traders today put a bearish construction on Chancellor Hitler's speech to the Reichstag, in that they considered it as indicative of little likelihood of an early war in Europe.
Trading in stocks on the New York Stock Exchange last month was at approximately the same pace as in December, but was in slightly larger volume than in January a year ago.

The Universalist General Convention of Boston has sold the church building at 96 Wadsworth Avenue, at the southwest corner of West 178th Street, to the Mission Church, a Norwegian Lutheran Congregational body.
BERLIN, Jan. 31.--Another landmark in German journalism sank into oblivion today with the announcement that the Berliner Tageblatt would cease publication Feb. 1 as an individual newspaper.

At a special meeting late yesterday afternoon, the Board of Education averted a threatened tie-up of the bus transportation of the city's school children by adopting a temporary one-month contract.

Don Frame of the Harvard Club, seeded first, played his first match in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association singles championship at the University Club yesterday and accounted for a straight-game victory.

Charles William McInenly, a retired Board of Transportation engineer, died on Monday night of a heart ailment and pneumonia in his home, 35-09 149th Street, Flushing, Queens. His age was 57.

BERLIN, Jan. 31.--As a result of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's Reichstag speech Germany today is proud of her leader and proud of herself, and the anxiety with which the world listened to that speech merely enhances that pride.

LONDON, Jan. 31.--While a party of Fascists was breaking up a meeting of Sir Kingsley Wood, the Air Minister, and shouting against War Secretary Leslie Hore-Belisha in Limehouse tonight, political organizations supporting the Spanish Government staged a noisy demonstration in the West End that resulted in fifty arrests.
PERPIGNAN, France, Jan. 31.-- Figueras, the temporary capital of Loyalist Spain, has a new life, and one with genuine order. Traffic is being routed through with reasonable speed.
The Mathieson Alkali Works, Inc., reported yesterday in its statement for 1938 a net income of $999,473 after depreciation, depletion, Federal income taxes and surtax on undistributed profits.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9.--Suffering from a slight head cold, President Roosevelt deferred to the advice of his physician today and stayed away from his desk in the Executive offices.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--No Pope of modern times has been mourned with such deep and widespread sorrow in this overwhelmingly Protestant country as the Pontiff who died in the Vatican today.

The youngster is Apron Strings, originally a competitor for Hal Price Headley, but claimed from him by Mrs. O.B. Wearley, who will send the filly to the post tomorrow.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10.-- A dinner in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Hill was given by Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. tonight at Casa Del Pastor.

The bill to "reform" relief introduced by Senator Byrnes of South Carolina is a discouraging document. In its most important provisions it is opposed to, rather than in accordance with, the fundamental reforms in relief that experience has shown to be imperative.

Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator, announced yesterday.

William Wallace McLaughlin, who headed the city's detective bureau at the turn of the century and who retired in 1907 when an investigation was ordered of charges that he was using the bureau as a private detective agency, left a net estate, of $734,019, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday. Inspector McLaughlin died on Oct. 12, 1933, at the age of 86.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 10.-- The United States defeated CzechoSlovakia, 1 to 0, in two overtime periods and Canada overwhelmed Switzerland, 7 to 0, today in the first two matches of the final round of the world amateur hockey championships.

At a special meeting yesterday afternoon the Board of School Superintendents selected five candidates--two women and three men --to fill the five vacancies in the assistant superintendent division. These positions, carrying tenure, pay $10,000 annually.

WATERBURY, Conn., Feb. 10.-- Soon after the administration of Mayor T. Frank Hayes of Waterbury took office in 1930, Controller Daniel J. Leary complained that there were "too many records" around City Hall, threatened to have the city bookkeeping machines "thrown out the window" and stated that "certain people have put us here and have to be taken care of," according to testimony given in Superior Court today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP).-- The Maritime Commission agreed late today to re-establish immediately American flag freighter service between Seattle and the Orient.

SAN ANTOTIO, Texas, Feb. 10. --Siege-Gun Jimmy Thomson's "home-run" tee shots wrecked the competitive course record at Brackenridge Park with a seven-under part 64 that left the field three strokes behind today in the opening round of the $5,000 Texas open tournament.

The two-story business building at 1,001-3 Springwood Avenue and 103-7 Prospect Avenue, Asbury Park, N.J., has been sold by the Howard Savings Institution of Newark to Jacob Cantor, whose clothing business has tenanted the property for many years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The Communist party of America is operating under a "Trojan horse policy," its real aim being overthrow of this government by force and violence if necessary, Solicitor General Jackson told the Supreme Court today in arguing for deportation of Joseph G. Strecker, Austrian-born alien, whose case has a bearing upon that of Harry Bridges, labor leader.

The 130th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln will be marked tomorrow. Legally observed in twenty-nine States and Alaska, the holiday will be celebrated widely here by patriotic, religious, political and other gatherings tomorrow and on Monday, when it will be official.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10.--The deep Green of Dartmouth College led the way through a gray, snowy and cold day as its skiers today began the defense of their title in the Outing Club carnival, twentyninth in the series.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--While wheat futures covered a range of about cent a bushel today on the board of trade, trading was less active than yesterday.

Boston, Mass., will offer for sale on Tuesday $5,000,000 notes. The issue will be dated Feb. 17 and will become payable on Nov. 3, 1939.

Industrial production in January, as compiled and announced this week, is stated by the Federal Reserve to have been nearly 3 per cent below December. Steel output is officially reported as 10 per cent below November.
The stock market set yesterday a five-month record for dullness. Share prices closed irregularly easier but up slightly from the day's lows, due to a mild rally in the final hour.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 10 (AP).--Hubert and Curtis Stevens of Lake Placid, famed bobsledding brothers, today led a field of seven teams at the half-way mark in the two-man American bobsled tryouts for the 1940 Olympics.
LONDON, Feb. 10.--The Earle of Winchilsea and Nottingham, a former partner in William P. Bonbright Co. of London and New York, died here today. He was 53 years old.

Thirty-five men were rescued in Coast Guard surf boats last night in a dense fog, intermittent rain squalls and a pounding surf from the Texas Company tanker Lightburne off Block Island. The captain, mates and radio operator left the breaking ship a few minutes before she sank shortly after midnight.

In the absence of any corporate bond offerings, the tax-exempt field had the new investment market exclusively to itself this week, starting what is expected to be another prolonged period in which the supply of new investment mediums will consist of little other than State and municipal bonds.
Reports from Cat Cay seem to indicate that the usual February run of blue marlin is making an appearance in the Gulf Stream in the vicinity of this small island and its neighbor, Bimini.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The Secretary of State and Mrs. Cordell Hull gave a dinner at the Carlton Hotel tonight for the foreign diplomatic corps.

This occurred as news leaked out in regard to a large new deal with Germany for machinery and equipment in exchange for expropriated oil.

President Roosevelt is Honorary President of the Boy Scouts of America. But it is in more than an honorary capacity that he spoke by radio on Wednesday evening to his "fellow Scouts." Long before he became President of the United States he was actively interested in Scouting.

A gentle, sorrowful melody, composed by A. Carroll Ely, a Brooklyn business man, to express his grief at the death of a pet fox terrier, was played yesterday by the symphony orchestra directed by Dr. Walter Damrosch in his music appreciation hour, broadcast over a National Broadcasting Company network.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb, 10. --Frank Strafaci of Brooklyn, N.Y., 22-year-old metropolitan amateur champion and former national public links champion, and Isaac Lincoln Merrill Jr. of Camden, Me., will meet in the thirty-six-hole final for the Ormond Beach golf championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The Federal Trade Commission today ordered the Fashion Originators Guild of America, Inc., with headquarters in New York, to cease and desist from boycotts and monopolistic trade policies. The order was issued after lengthy hearings.

Coincident with the return of a superseding indictment yesterday against eight former employes of the city's Independent Subway System in the looting of turnstiles in the last four years, another employe confessed he had stolen more than $25,000 in nickels from the system.

JUST a week from tonight the New York A.C. will be holding another of its notable track meets at Madison Square Garden and it is to be hoped that Mr. Orie Kelly and Mr. Paul Pilgrim and other Winged Foot officials will take a firm stand regarding unnumbered persons.
Frederick Brown, the operator, acquired yesterday a midtown business property by purchasing the fire-story building at 76 East Fiftysixth Street.
The Front Page Ball, the seventeenth annual party of the New Fork Newspaper Women's Club, was held last night in the Starlight Roof of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

A morning paper notice of last night's Boston Symphony concert at Carnegie Hall must be largely an acknowledgment of gratitude to Serge Koussevitzky for a magnificent performance of the Bruckner Eighth symphony.

The visit of the Brazilian Foreign Minister, Oswaldo Aranha, to Washington on a special mission to consult with the President and Secretary Hull on the common interests of Brazil and the United States will remind many of us that Mr. Aranha was formerly the Ambassador of his country at Washington.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 10.-- Striking back at critics who charged him with using dictatorial methods against broadcasters, Frank R. McNinch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, declared himself tonight "unalterably opposed to government censorship" but insisted upon both sides of controversial subjects having opportunity to express themselves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 10.-- Richard Arlen and Andy Devine were named today by Universal as the leads for a series of Seven outdoor pictures to be filmed between April 1, 1939, and April 1, 1940, from works by Jack London, Peter B. Kyne, Earl Derr Biggers, Courtney Riley Cooper and W.R. Burnett, which the studio owns.

The clergy and laity of all faiths throughout the nation joined yesterday in paying tribute to the life and accomplishments of Pope Pius XI. The Pope was hailed as a champion of peace and tolerance, a spiritual leader who toiled unceasingly to alleviate distress in the world.

New State and municipal financing scheduled for next week totals only $6,823,251, to be represented by one State and thirty municipalities, compared with the revised total of $24,951,379 for this week.
BERLIN, Feb. 10.--The German Government today took "protocolar" cognizance of the death of Pope Pius XI and accorded him, as one of the world's sovereigns, the honors provided by diplomatic usage.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 10.--In the dim halflight of the Sistine Chapel under the vaulted ceiling frescoed by Michelangelo's magic brush the body of Pope Pius XI lay at rest this evening after a day of hurry and confusion attendant upon the Pontiff's sudden death.

Sailors Snug Harbor at last has settled upon a plan for improvement of the row of peaceful old dwellings it owns at 7 to 13 Washington Square North, extending east from Fifth Avenue halfway over to University Place.

MARCH FIELD, Calif., Feb. 10 (AP).--Major Gen. H.H. Arnold, chief of the Army Air Corps, tonight announced completion of tests on a radically designed singleseated, twin-engined fighting plane "capable of speeds well above 350 miles an hour, probably exceeding in performance any military airplane in the world."

Bob Nicholson and Roy Leenig recorded 35 points between them in leading Trinity School's basketball team to a 61-34 triumph over Horace Mann in an Eastern Private Schools League game on the Trinity court yesterday.

Two junior high school girls shared honors with fourteen boys in the poster contest conducted by the Boy Scout Foundation of Greater New York as part of the Boy Scout Week program which will end Tuesday.

The Western Union Telegraph Company, Inc., reported yesterday in its preliminary annual statement for 1938 a net loss amounting to $1,637,879 after depredation, taxes, rentals and interest.
VALENCIA, Spain, Feb. 10.-- Premier Juan Negrin returned today to what is left of Republican Spain. He announced tonight that the new Spanish Government headquarters would be in Madrid.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--Cornelius V. Bull, general counsel of the American Veterans Association, told the House World War Veterans Committee today that if the widows of all World War veterans were pensioned, public sentiment would become aroused against all pensions and that compensation to deserving veterans might be reduced.

Coach Ed Kelleher cleaned his bench with frequent substitutions as Fordham's basketball team routed Canisius in the Maroon's gymnasium last night, 72--39. Fifteen points each by Captain Bobby Hassmiller and Al Brassel and twelve by Howard (Dutch) Weil led the scoring as the Rams, at the peak of their form, found it almost impossible to miss the hoop.

The Brooklyn Tech High School hockey team won the championship of the P.S.A.L. by subduing the Manual Training High School sextet at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night, 5 to 1. The game was the final one in the round-robin series for the title.

Activity in the listed bond market was at a low ebb yesterday, with the turnover on the New York Stock Exchange receding to less than $5,000,000. Most of the leading obligations fluctuated irregularly within a narrow range.

Robert Ashforth, night manager of the Barnum Hotel's coffee shop in Bridgeport, Conn., testified yesterday at the second trial of Tammany District Leader James J. Hines that he had seen Hines in the company of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer in that city during August and September of 1935.

A plan of reorganization for the Standard Commercial Tobacco Company, Inc., under the auspices of the stockholders' reorganization committee headed by William Hayward, provides for the cash payment in fall of all taxes, reorganization expenses and allowed claims, and satisfaction of all contingent creditors' claims.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb, 10 (AP).--The Minimum Wage Board of the New Jersey Labor Department set tonight a minimum scale of 36 cents an hour for women and minors in the light manufacturing industry.
CHICAGO, Feb. 10.--Secretary Ickes declared tonight that, "owing to economic tie-ups, our press is not as free as it should be in a democracy."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--Members' trading in round lots for their own accounts on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on Jan. 21 amounted to 22.54 per cent of the total volume, compared with 23.17 per cent in the preceding week, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The investment of Social Security funds in government securitics brought a Republican charge of "embezzlement" at a House hearing today and a Democratic demand that the word be deleted from the record.
Jules Brulatour, 71 years old, head of a film-distributing concern, paid a fine of $500 yesterday in Special Sessions to avoid serving in the workhouse an alternative thirty-day term.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--The sadness of the Roman Catholic world at the death of Pope Pius XI was reflected throughout official and diplomatic Washington today as religious and political leaders joined in expressions of condolence at the passing of the spiritual leader of 400,000,000 Christians who acknowledge the primacy of the Holy See.

Charges that several high-ranking police officials and certain political figures in Brooklyn received money and other gifts to obstruct the prosecution of criminal acts arising from labor disputes have come under the scrutiny of John Harlan Amen, Assistant Attorney General investigating charges of official corruption in Brooklyn, it was learned yesterday.

PERPIGNAN, France, Feb. 10.-- The Spanish Insurgents reached the frontier at Portbou at 1:15 this afternoon and at Bourg-Madame at 2:40, thus completing the conquest of Catalonia and the Pyrenees frontier.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP).-- Secretary Wallace warned Senators today against a bill to fix minimum prices for farm products, saying that if the government attempted this there would be widespread bootlegging of farm crops and a billion-dollar increase in consumers' food costs.
More than a month earlier than usual, the Nash Motors Division of the Nash-Kelvinator Corporation will today launch a "Spring" selling drive, W.A. Blees, general sales manager, announced yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 10.--At the close of a three-day hearing on the condition of the French army, navy and air force the Defense Committee of the Senate today voted confidence in the government's preparations for national security.
LONDON, Feb. 10.--A general contraction in the volume of business was the feature of the stock markets today.

De Witt Clinton High's winning streak, which had reached eleven, was snapped yesterday when the quintet bowed to Evander Childs High, 42--20, in an upper Manhattan-Bronx P.S.A.L. clash on the loser's court. The setback also was the first in five league games for Clinton, which remained in the lead.

OTTAWA, Ont., Feb. 10 (Canadian Press).--Sympathy of the Government of Canada in the death of Pope Pius was expressed in a message sent today by Prime Minister Mackenzie King through the British Minister to the Vatican.

"Madras Comes to New York" will be the subject of the "World Christianity Days" to be observed in the New York area beginning tomorrow and closing with a "World Christian Fellowship Dinner" Tuesday evening in the Hotel Astor.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 10.--Villanova, paced by Captain Walter Kelley, defeated Fordham's swimming team today, 45--27.

Charges that truant officers, sent by the Board of Education, are intimidating them through "questionable tactics" were made yesterday by parents as the Bronx student strike closed its second week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10.--Recommendation that the Bureau of Accounts of the Interstate Commerce Commission have the same access to the books of subsidiaries of railroad companies and of holding companies, banks and brokerage and investment banking houses that it has to the books of railroads was contained in a special report made public today by a Senate Interstate Commerce subcommittee, of which Senator Wheeler is chairman.

In a unanimous decision the Appellate Division sustained yesterday a decree of Justice Charles B. McLaughlin enjoining the Municipal Civil Service Commission from awarding extra credits for college work in relevant fields and for participation in organized athletics in rating candidates for appointment to the police force.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP).-- Joan Crawford, film star, filed suit today for a divorce from Franchot Tone, now playing in New York. The complaint asserts that they had signed a property settlement, of which it asks court approval.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 10 (AP).--The Providence Bulletin said today it had received information that German exchange students in the United States and Canada had been directed to act as agents of the German Government on American and Canadian university campuses.

County officials whose salaries have been attacked by Mayor La Guardia as excessive received a cool reception yesterday from Kenneth Dayton, Budget Director, when they included salary increases in their estimates this year.

Tonight should mark a happy occasion in the career of Lew Leslie because his sixth edition of the Negro musical show, "Blackbirds," will pass in review at the Hudson. The courageous producer has been working toward this event for a longer period than he cares to recall.

BELGRADE, Feb. 10.--The wanderer south of Germany learns at least two facts that may be of decisive importance to the future of Europe and the world. The first is that not one of the countries herded within the German orbit by force of geography, economic pressure and the Munich agreement likes to be where it is or likes Germany.

LONDON, Feb. 10.--It became known for the first time tonight that Pope Pius had gently reminded Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain of the duties of democracies and the evils of totalitarian regimes when he received the Prime Minister last month.

While the United States and Canada joined in the world-wide mourning for the death of Pope Pius XI yesterday, the hierarchy of the Roman Catholic Church quickly made arrangements for the American group of Cardinals to take part in the election of a new Supreme Pontiff.

Most spectacular of the special features on the program of the Westminster Kennel Club's sixtythird annual dog show to be held in Madison Square Garden Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week will be the obedience test team match, a form of canine competition never before attempted in this city.

Notre Dame and New York University, both riding winning streaks after shaky starts this season, will clash at Madison Square Garden tonight in the feature of a collegiate basketball doubleheader. NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 10.--Official tax maps showed that the city of Newark owned, through tax deeds, three of the five parcels of propertg in the Gommersal tract in the Newark Airport which the city bought late in 1935 for about $44,000.

Although brokers for various large mill organizations continued to distribute contracts in the three active old-crop deliveries of cotton, more aggressive trade calling developed yesterday and prices on the Cotton Exchange ended 5 points higher to 2 points lower.

DUBLIN, Ireland, Feb. 10.--In few countries in the world has the death of Pope Pius occasioned more profound and universal grief than in Catholic Ireland. The World's Fair exhibit of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and affiliated companies, will show the high standard of living achieved by the 37,000 employes of the system, it was announced yesterday by the company.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 10 (AP).--An excited demonstration of the rebellion of man's nervous system against the tyranny of noise cost Dr. Logan Clendening four hours behind jail bars today.

Everything that happens now is referred to something that happened then--for all the world as though history had not begun until that cycle started and could not possibly have changed since. What people did in 1914 for standards of comparison--and how accurately they turned out--would be worth investigating.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10.--Norwood (Barney) Ewell, Penn State Negro freshman sprinter, set a new world record of 5.1 seconds for the 50-yard dash tonight in winning the event at the second annual Penn A.C. indoor track and field carnival. Father Kellenberg expressed the belief that if the Pope were to have selected the field of endeavor closest to his heart he would have chosen the field of Catholic Action by which to be remembered.

The second annual convention of the New York State Young Communist League was brought to a close yesterday afternoon with a resolution expressing sympathy to young Catholics on the death of Pope Pius XI.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12.--A sound and stable aircraft industry is not only important to commerce but also is essential to national defense, Oswald Ryan, member of the Civil Aeronautics Authority, declared in a speech broadcast over the NBC network tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--The struggle in Congress over President Roosevelt's national defense program and international policies was carried to the country today in a nation-wide radio broadcast, with Senator Nye of Dakota, a stanch isolationist, attacking the Chief Executive's course, and Senator Lee of Oklahoma defending it.

Pell Jr. in the semi-final round of the annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet tournament at the Tuxedo Racquet and Tennis Club, 4--15, 17--14, 15--5, 15--9. CHICAGO, Feb. 14.--Wheat futures fluctuated today in an erratic manner within a range of 5/8 cent a bushel. While the general run of outside interest was light, there were several buying and selling orders of fair size, which resulted in quick changes in prices.

Insurance in force in 1938 increased $76,319,647 to a grand total of $4,175,557,199 at the end of the year, Guy W. Cox, president, reported yesterday to policy holders at the annual meeting of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston. This is the highest amount in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14.--A farreaching program, under which the United States will station more military representatives in Latin American republics and give assistance to those countries, is about to go into effect.

BERLIN, Feb. 14.--Reportedly because of the acute labor shortage, Field Marshal Hermann Goering today issued a decree making changes of jobs by individual workers impossible without the permission of local labor offices.

Five hundred alumni of Townsend Harris High School, which occupies the ninth to twelfth floors of the City College School of Business, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue, met there last night to protest the proposal for its discontinuance, now before the Board of Higher Education.

Aycock Brown, the determined outdoor editor of The Beaufort (N.C.) News, writes us that his efforts to stimulate surf casting derbies along that stretch of coast are meeting with success. As a result of his efforts, several contests will be held at various points.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., Feb. 14.-- Charles W. Beall, former owner of a private zoo here on Mott Avenue, that later became the nucleus of the Frank Buck Zoo at Massapequa, died today in his house on the grounds of the establishment. He was 67 years of age.

Leading all the way, New York University's basketball team defeated Brooklyn College, 44--28, at the University Heights gymnasium last night. Ben Auerbach, ably assisted by Captain Danny Dowd and Irving Resnick, led the home team's attack. The Violet had a 22-9 lead at the intermission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15.--Embarking today on a second investigation of recent activities of a French air mission in the United States, the Senate Military Affairs Committee encountered new difficulties in efforts to satisfy demands by some members that information developed by the committee be given to the public.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15.-- Dr. Wilton Everett Britton, State entomologist for Connecticut and a nationally known authority in his field, died here today in a hospital. He was 70 years old.

Rehabilitation plans for the Austin Silver Mining Company after twenty-one months of troubles with the Securities and Exchange Commission were announced yesterday. They include sweeping changes in the directors and officers, issuance of convertible notes to satisfy creditors' claims of about $90,000, and a new stock issue to furnish additional working capital.

The national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, holding its nineteenth annual meeting at the church headquarters at 281 Fourth Avenue, debated yesterday the stand to be taken by the church on the President's proposal to include employee of churches and other non-profit organizations in Federal social security laws.

Leo H. BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 15.-- Bela Imredy, father of the anti-Jew ish bill intended to exclude Jews and those Christians with Jewish parentage from the Hungarian civil service and liberal professions while radically curtailing their position in trade and industry, resigned as Premier today on grounds replete with irony--he was compelled to admit the correctness of Nazi assertions that he was himself of Jewish descent.

With the race narrowing down to the final weeks of play, the New York A. C. team continued on its road to victory in the Metropolitan League Class A squash tennis matches last night.

ROME, Feb. 15.--Criticism of the reported Anglo-French offer of financial help to Generalissimo Francisco Franco to begin reconstruction after the ravages of the Spanish civil war is the keynote of today's press comment. Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools.

A sixty-five-mile-an-hour squall accompanied by blinding sheets of rain struck New York at 1 P.M. yesterday, the climax of a day of exceptionally freakish weather that also included a record high temperature for the date--62 degrees--a dense fog that tied up shipping and the airlines in the morning, and snow last night.

Two pool records were shattered by Princeton's mermen last night as they downed Columbia's team, 46 to 29, in the Lion tank. The Tiger natators won seven of the nine events to register their second consecutive Eastern Intercollegiate League victory, which put them in a tie with Yale for first place in the circuit. It was Columbia's second defeat in three league meets.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15.-- Mrs. James P. Donahue entertained tonight with a large dinner at Cielito Lindo, having several additional guests later for dancing in the patio. MOSCOW, Feb. 15.--Admiral Ivan Stepanovitch Isakoff, First Vice Commissar of the Red Navy, is expected to leave in the next few days for the United States, accompanied by seven naval experts on an undisclosed mission. There was no announcement on the formation of this naval delegation, and the only authoritative information was that the members received their American, Polish, German and French visas today.

ABOARD THE S.S. REX, at sea, Feb. 15.--A high mass of requiem for Pope Pius XI will be sung on board the Rex Friday morning, with Denis Cardinal Dougherty of Philadelphia and George William Cardinal Mundelein of Chicago, two Bishops and attendant prelates and priests participating, and Beniamino Gigli, Metropolitan Opera star, as the soloist. The celebrant will be Mgr. Cassani, chaplain of the Rex.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15.--If the Presidential goal of a national income of $80,000,000,000 to $90,000,000,000 yearly is to be reached, it will come through greater efficiency, better personnel relationships and lower prices to the consumer, C. Glenn Cunningham has telegraphed his entry to Dan Ferris, meet director for a day for the nationals at Madison Square Garden a week from Saturday. Frank Hayes and twenty-two other defendants.
Dog owners attending the last two sessions of the Westminster Kennel Club's exhibition yesterday probably marveled at the obedience tests as much as anything else and had good reason to do so.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses presented his arguments for construction of the $41,000,000 Batteryto-Brooklyn bridge yesterday at a public hearing before the City Planning Commission in City Hall. Borough President Stanley M. Isaacs of Manhattan opposed the project.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--After a short and successful struggle with the germ that inflicts humanity with what is called grippe, the President left Washington tonight for outdoor recreation in a climate which should consolidate his victory.

Bradley, third ranking rider of the meeting and considered a sure rider of a Flamingo and Widener starter, is through for the balance of the Florida season as the result of an accident in the sixth race at Hialeah today. Five seeded and three unranked players will do battle today in the quarter-finals of the annual Whitehall invitation squash tennis tournament at the Whitehall Club overlooking New York harbor. Three of the favored contestants scored notable victories in the lower-half second-round play yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--The Department of Agriculture announced today that it looked for an improvement next Spring in the domestic demand for farm products, but it added that general foreign demand conditions continued relatively unfavorable. The 1938 annual report of the Southern California Edison Company, Ltd., exclusive of subsidiaries, shows a net income for the year of $11,733,479, after expenses and charges. Two goals by Neil Colville gave the New York Rangers a 2-to-1 triumph over their city hockey rivals, the Americans, in the teams' seventh clash of the season at Madison Square Garden last night. The grand jury demand for the summary dismissal of Magistrate Mark Rudich appears to be only the first fruit of Special Prosecutor Amen's inquiry into official corruption in Brooklyn. Rumors of such corruption have been current for many years. Previous investigations have tended to support them. WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--Thoroughly recovered from an attack of grippe which kept him from his desk for a week. President Roosevelt left Washington by special train late tonight on his way to Key West. Harry A. Hyman, builder of Kensington House, the fourteen-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Seventh Avenue and Twentieth Street, has sold the structure to Leo Ritter. WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.--Encouraged by their recent showing in test votes on New Deal policies, as well as by the lack of harmony in the Democratic ranks, House Republican leaders started a movement today to return to Congress some of the powers vested in the President during the emergency period of 1933-1936.

Concerns handling a variety of wearing apparel lines figured prominently in busines space leases reported yesterday by brokers and renting agents of buildings in Manhattan. Furriers, milliners and manufacturers of coats are among the tenants taking new quarters.

Hilles of New York told the Monopoly Investigating Committee today that 1 1-3 per cent of the $7,000,000 annual business of his agency for the Employers Liability Assurance Company was derived in twelve years from the New York Life Insurance Company, of which Mr. Hilles is a director.

When the division bell rang the government had 62 votes to 39 for the Opposition.

LONDON, Feb. 16.--Challenging the claim of an American company to be the first to develop a method for making "molded" airplane parts, Bruno Jablonsky, general manager of Jablo (Holdings), Ltd., said that his firm was now producing propellers and other parts by a similar process for the Air Ministry.

The grand ballroom of the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria will be the scene on Tuesday afternoon, Feb. 28, of the debut of a new bud--a member of the old Tagetes family (known in America as marigold)--which will be presented to flower society by its discoverer, David Burpee, the Philadelphia seed man.

Except for being a few days older Bela Imredy, who resigned on Wednesday as Premier of Hungary, is precisely the same man that he was last week. He is no taller or shorter than he was last week, no more or less intelligent, no more or less sincere, public-spirited and unselfish. When he has the grippe the symptoms are the same as they would have been last week.

John Henry Walbridge, retired banker and business executive, died yesterday in his apartment at the Hotel Plaza of arteriosclerosis. He was 78 years old.
