WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--John J. O'Connor, former Representative from New York who was the lone victim in the recent campaign of President Roosevelt's efforts to defeat legislators who had opposed his policies, urged in a letter to Representative Patrick H. Drewry, made public today, that the "sensible" Democrats get together now and pick a candidate for President in 1940.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP).-- Doris B., consistent 9-year-old mare owned by Mrs. S. Orr, won the featured sixth race at the Fair Grounds today to keep intact her record of not finishing worse than second in any of her seven starts this year.

BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Feb. 19.-- Competing under the most hazardous sort of weather conditions, fifty talented riders from all parts of the East kept a throng of 3,000 at a high pitch of enthusiasm as the Brattleboro Outing Club held its annual open ski jump today.

The New York State Bankers Association will hold today the first of a series of four seminars on bank-investment problems in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street. The succeeding meetings will be held on the next three Mondays.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP).--The Detroit Red Wings finally broke the spell the Boston Bruins had held over them this season, winning a National Hockey League game before 8,700 tonight, 4 to 1. Boston had downed the Wings six straight times.

ALBANY, Feb. 19.--The principle of local responsibility for relief was praised today by David C. Adie, State social Welfare Commissioner, in reporting that careful local administration had saved more than $45,000,000 for the State, Federal and local governments in 1938.
An inter-faith memorial service for Pope Pius XI was held yesterday afternoon at the synagogue of Anshe Emes, Stanhope Street and Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Attorney General Frank Murphy announced today that the Federal Government would begin suit tomorrow for $1,053,474,63 damages against eighteen leading automobile tire manufacturers, as a result of Assistant Attorney General Thurman Arnold's monopoly investigation.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19.--Captain C.T.I. (Pat) Roark, famous British polo star, was seriously injured today in a game that saw California's Midwick four beaten, 12 to 7, by a team of British International Cup players.

MIAMI, Feb. 19.--Beset with "disturbing" diplomatic reports suggesting that another European war crisis was in the offing, President Roosevelt sailed eastward through the Caribbean today to join the combined fleet in its test of the nation's naval defensive power. On board the cruiser Houston, he kept in touch with Washington through the naval radio station at Arlington, Va.

Police officials, concerned over the possibility of trouble being provoked by anti-Nazi pickets at the meeting tonight of the GermanAmerican Bund in Madison Square Garden, announced yesterday an increase of 330 in the number of men assigned to the meeting, bringing the total to 1,300, including officers.

Dr. Phillips Thygeson has been appointed executive officer of the Department of Ophthalmology in Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of the university. Dr. Thygeson and Dr. John H. Dunnington of the same department were promoted to full professorships.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Continuation of the past and present policies and activities of the InterAmerican Commission of Women and of the chairmanship of Miss Doris Stevens was urged in letters sent today by the National Woman's Party to members of the governing board of the Pan American Union.
LONDON, Feb. 19.--The City has taken a surprisingly cheerful view of the government's proposals doubling its borrowing powers over the five-year rearmament period from 400,000,000 to 800,000,000.
With the missionary spirit characteristic of musicians of her country, Harriet Cohen, noted English pianist, opened her Town Hall recital yesterday afternoon with two groups of English music.

Early advertising through the medium of television probably will take the form of talking picture shots, broadcast from motion picture films, according to an article on "Television in 1939," published in the current issue of "Successful Advertising," house organ of Yan Sant, Dugdale Co., Inc., Baltimore agency.
If the estimates of the World's Fair officials are borne out, this city, beginning next April, will be the terminus of the greatest pilgrimage in history.
Preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, the rector, urged his parishioners to begin Lent with a determination to avoid "temper, worry and grouch."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 19.-- Clear skies and a mild temperature on Long Island Sound brought out twenty-five sailing dinghies today for the regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club. The winners were Eddie Maxwell with his Class B boat Tu Yung and Dick Hill with his X craft Dunker.
PARIS, Feb. 18.--After a threeday weakness, the Bourse rose during the last two sessions of the week on a generally firm note.

An improvement in the system of classifying and distributing inmates of State penal institutions is recommended to the Legislature in the ninety-fourth annual report of the Prison Association of New York, made public yesterday.
Spot cotton and the near futures were slightly higher last week on the New York Cotton Exchange, while distant deliveries declined moderately.
A refreshing picture of the desert blossoming like the rose, or at least like the lilac and honeysuckle, is offered in a report of the United States Forest Service.

BERLIN, Feb. 19.--The loss through serious illness of Dr. Rudolf Brinkmann as vice president of the Reichsbank and State Secretary of the Ministry of Economics is considered a crushing blow in fiscal circles since no competently trained successor to the dual office seems eligible.

ZAKOPANE, Poland, Feb. 19.-- Germany's skiers showed their superiority over the Scandinavian countries' representatives in the annual meeting, held under the auspices of the International Ski Federation, which ended today. Germany won six of the nine events, including the jumping competition and the combined jump and eighteen-kilometer race.
Hanya Holm and her concert group provided an evening of distinguished dancing at the Guild Theatre last night in their first appearance of the season.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Record-breaking, it seems, is getting to be a habit with 19-yearold Torger Tokle of the Norway Ski Club.
BERLIN, Feb. 19.--Marked changes have occurred inside Germany as a result of Chancellor Hitler's "triumphal year."

CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--Reports that private negotiations were under way for an exchange of United States lard for German manufactured goods started a short-covering movement in the former here last week which carried prices up sharply.

Eight hundred employes of the Department of Sanitation, members of the Sanitation Benevolent Association, met yesterday in Beethoven Hall, 210 East Fifth Street, applauded criticism of the conduct of the department of Commissioner William F. Carey and affirmed their determination to maintain the association despite his objections.
Mrs. Herbert R. O'Conor, wife of the Governor of Maryland, who had been at the Biltmore, departed yesterday for Annapolis.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19.--Henry G. Picard of Hershey, Pa., one of golf's big money winners, picked up $2,000 today for his victory in the Crescent City open tournament with a seventy-two-hole score of 284.

PARIS, Feb. 19.--Senator Leon Berard's negotiations with the Burgos government in the person of Count Francisco Gomez Jordana, the Foreign Minister, moved forward "satisfactorily" today, according to information that has reached official quarters here, but no precise report has yet been made by the French agent.

Improved demand for lower-price apparel was noted in the wholesale markets last week and volume of mail orders increased. Numerous buyers are expected here this week on second trips to purchase most of the required goods for pre-Easter selling.

A letter requesting the Board of Education to disapprove a resolution denying the use of school auditoriums for meetings of a controversial nature was made public yesterday by former Corporation Counsel Paul Windels as chairman of the committee on civil rights of the New York County Lawyers Association.
"Miss Swan Expects," a comedy by Sam and Bella Spewack, who wrote "Boy Meets Girl" of 1935 fame and the book of the current musical "Leave It to Me!" opens tonight at the Cort.

Recognition by the United States of the Franco government in Spain was urged at a mass meeting held yesterday afternoon in the 107th Infantry Regiment Armory, at Sixtysixth Street and Park Avenue, under the auspices of the General Committee for Americanism and Neutrality.

Mischa Elman, who had played the Brahms violin concerto at last week's pair of concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, appeared again as soloist with that organization, under John Barbirolli's baton, at its concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y., Feb. 19.--Close competition was the order of the day in the Manhasset Bay Club's weekly Frostbite regatta today. The races were sailed in a light breeze and the warmest weather the fleet has enjoyed in a long time.

LONDON, Feb, 19.--The British public and British official quarters alike were disturbed today by streamer headlines announcing that because of "ominous reports" front Europe President Roosevelt might curtail his cruise with the fleet.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 19.--Demand for steel products continued to mark time last week and total bookings were on a par with recent weekly tonnages.

LONDON, Feb. 19.--Although Great Britain's import trade in January declined 10.9 per cent from the year before and exports decreased 4.1 per cent, the decline was seasonal, while the rate of decrease was only about half that of December.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP). --The Rev. Martin V. Stone, National Grand Army of the Republic adjutant and for fifty years a Methodist pastor in New York and Pennsylvania churches, died here last night at the age of 93.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--At the request of President Roosevelt, a "Conference on Children in Democracy," the first session to be held at the White House April 26 and a final session early in 1940, was called today by Secretary Perkins.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 20.--Americans can protect their interests in the Pacific by relying on Japan instead of strengthening their Pacific fortifications, says the newspaper Asahi in an editorial intended to refute American years that Japan means to seize control of the Pacific.

PRINCETON. N.J., Feb. 19.-- Fifth--seven medals and other trophies won by the late John Riegel De Witt, '04, one of Princeton's alltime greats on the track and gridiron, have been presented to the university by his widow, it was announced today.

Store adjustors are considerably heartened over the progress which has been made in seeking a solution of the problem of unfair returns of merchandise, Lewis G. Morris of James McCutcheon Co. declared in a statement issued for publication today, in summing up the extent of action taken so far by the Metropolitan Retail Stores Adjustors, of which he is president.

The annual report of the New York State Public Service Commission, submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature, records "a marked tendency on the part of public utility companies in New York State to decrease litigation and to moderate their opposition to the decisions and requirements" of the commission.

Charles E. Reid, executive vice president of the Bronx Real Estate Board and for nearly twenty-six years executive secretary of the Bronx Board of Trade, died yesterday at his home, 300 East 163d Street, the Bronx, of a cerebral hemmorhage. Mr. Reid was 75 years old.
The East River Savings Bank sold the one-story brick taxpayer containing ten stores at 1,530-48 University Avenue, near Featherben Lane, the Bronx, to an investor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Feb. 11 to 17 are given in the appended tabulation:

Just as listeners whose radios were tuned to WABC were settling down yesterday afternoon to listen to the regular Sunday afternoon Philharmonic Orchestra concert, a voice broke in on the program, superimposed on the music, denouncing Secretary of Labor Frances Perkins and advocating "Americanism."
With the approaching end of the civil war in Spain Mussolini faces the need of convincing his own people that the sacrifices he called upon them to make in that country have been worth their cost.

DETROIT, Feb. 19 (AP).--The Rev. Charles E. Coughlin said in his weekly radio address today that "internationalism both in the fields of finance and politics have all but destroyed capitalism," and added that "if this policy of internationalism continues war will eventuate, capitalism will cease and communism under some form will follow."
CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--Appointment of Professor Daniel A. Prescott of Rutgers University to be Professor of Education at the University of Chicago was announced today by President Hutchins.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 (AP).--Ivan Brown and A.M. (Bob) Washbond today retained their North American two-man bobsled title as a record-breaking field smashed speed marks galore.

The City Affairs Committee, in a bulletin to its members, made public yesterday, attacked "the Tammany majority and its reactionary Republican allies" in the City Council and blamed them for turning the first year of the new Council into a "bitter disappointment." The bulletin was made public by Bishop Francis J. McConnell, chairman of the committee.
Realty deals in the Bronx reported over the week-end included sales of sites for new apartment houses.

Urging a solid front against threats to democracy, justice and liberty, the Rev. Dr. Paul D. Moody, president of Middlebury College, asserted yesterday that this nation's first line of defense was "to provide against injustice, greed, dishonesty, oppression--all those evils which are allies of tyranny and make the path of the dictator easy."

With both teams using crippled goalies, the Canadiens of Montreal and the New York Americans engaged in a free-scoring hockey battle at Madison Square Garden last night, the flying Frenchmen from the north making off with the victory, 5 to 4.

A net profit of $7,850,506, or $3.85 a share, is reported by the National Distillers Products Corporation for 1938 by Seton Porter, president, compared with $7,861,969, or $3.86 a share, earned in 1937, and with $7,753,251, or $3.80 in share, in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--A 20 per cent increase in the consumption of lumber in this country this quarter from the first quarter of 1938 is estimated today in a summary by the Commerce Department's Lumber Survey committee.

Catholio women were urged to play a more active role in civic affairs and to develop an articulate opinion on secular as well as religious issues, in an address by Lady Armstrong, prominent member of the Catholic laity, at the fifth annual communion breakfast of the St. Vincent Ferrer Fraternity of the Third Order of St. Dominic, held in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

HARLAN, Iowa, Feb. 19.--A crewless, runaway locomotive, speeding down a fog-shrouded track with its throttle wide open and its headlight hidden behind a freight car, crashed head-on without warning into a Great Western passenger train four miles out of Tennant last night, killing the passenger train's engineer and fireman and causing injuries to twenty-three persons.

"Like a bolt of lightning," says Vittorio Mussolini, the idea came to him of curbing the mode critics. H. Duce's son is a film producer and owns his own movie magazine. Like some other film producers casting their accounts, he feels that newspaper movie critics are too severe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19.--Officially, after today, the Western World's Fair is open and operating. So tonight Californians will shuffle off their "forty-niner" masquerades adopted for the festivities of the exciting week which ushered in their International Golden Gate Exposition.

The funded debt of the Pennsylvania Railroad was reduced from the high record of $699,301,044 reached in 1937 to $692,818,134, or by $6,482,910, in 1938, the report of M.W. Clement, president, for the last year disclosed yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, Feb. 19.--General Antonio Rodriguez, taking advantage of the absence of President Oscar Benavides, tried to seize the Government Palace about 2 A.M. today in an attempt to overthrow the government and was killed.
WALDO, Fla., Feb. 19.--An army airplane pilot saw a companion crash to his death in Lake Santa Fe today, then wrecked his plane as he landed quickly is an effort to give aid.

Nothing short of a sweeping revival of reverence for God and holy things can save us and liberty today, said the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Keigwin in his sermon yesterday morning at the West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street.

Young people of the Episcopal Diocese of New York attended a special service yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Fifteen hundred of them took part in a procession through the nave, their banners held aloft, followed by the cathedral choir.
Seniors in Columbia College maintain the long tradition of upperclass sophistication, according to the annual poll of their preferences conducted by The Columbian, campus year-book.

As a result of the tightening Japanese blockade of Chinese ports, steamship operators routing vessels to the Far East from New York and other American ports are placing Rangoon on their schedules and are booking heavy cargoes of general merchandise to the Burma port for transshipment to the Chinese interior.

The Cadet Chapel Choir of the United States Military Academy at West Point, following an annual custom, assisted yesterday afternoon at the evensong services at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street. Every seat in the church was filled, while scores stood in the rear of the church.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19 (AP).--Poland and the Soviet Union, who during the September Czecho-Slovak crisis appeared on the verge of a diplomatic break, today signed a farreaching agreement designed greatly to increase their trade.
Two test cases on the Sudeten issue will come before the United States Customs Court here tomorrow.

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 19. --Twenty-three passengers and the crew of six aboard a Pan American Airways plane escaped serious injury today when the craft was upset in alighting in San Juan Harbor during a rainstorm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--Eugene Sheldon Leggett, executive director of the National Emergency Council, and president of the National Press Club in 1931-32, the youngest man ever to hold that post, died here today of bronchial pneumonia at the age of 36.
In the Census Bureau's report on last month's consumption of American cotton there are produced some curious contrasts.
BERLIN, Feb. 19.--No visible effect of a war-scare on the markets is distinguishable here because no conflict involving Germany is expected.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 (AP).--Chinese reports from Chekiang Province, south of Shanghai, said the Japanese had failed in an attempt to land troops on the coast.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 19.--The third anniversary of the formation of Chile's Popular Front, the Leftist political combination, was celebrated this morning at a mass meeting of 10,000 at which addresses were made by Socialist, Communist, Radical and Democratic party leaders.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Feb. 19.-- The United States should not only sell war planes to "our friends," France and England, but should also cut prices, Mayor La Guardia of New York City declared in an address to a State-wide audience here today.

THERE once was a young semi-pro pitcher who was allowed to go South with the Giants on their training trip. His father, a fairly wellto-do merchant, went along for the ride and the fun around the training camp.

The so-called "cellar club" stratum of New York youth voluntarily placed itself on mock trial yesterday before Magistrate Anna M. Kross and a picked blue ribbon jury to defend itself against charges that it maintains "dens of iniquity" constituting "public nuisances."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--A Congress that is increasingly sensitive to the political omens for 1940 will proceed cautiously this week along a pathway that is beset with little major legislation.

King Haakon VII of Norway hailed the New York World's Fair yesterday afternoon as "a great demonstration of peace," as he voiced his country's greetings to the people of the United States and to the exposition in the eighth of the Fair's radio "Salutes of Nations."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19.-- From many distant States persons are already arriving here to participate in the events of the annual Yale Junior Promenade week, which will be featured by the prom in the Payne Whitney gymnasium on Friday night.

The Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank sold to a client of James Felt Co. the six-story tenement on a lot 25 by 100 feet at 552 Grand Street. The property is assessed at $18,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $11,500.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--Somewhat higher prices for wheat were recorded last week in the world's wheat markets, but there was little in the news to stimulate aggressive buying.
Long Island University's triumph over St. Francis, its seventeenth in a row, was the outstanding event of an unusually busy week in metropolitan basketball circles.

New York University's School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance has awarded tuition scholarships for the Spring semester to 131 students, it was announced yesterday by Harold O. Voorhis, secretary of the university.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19.-- Featuring the Washington's Birthday celebration at the Surf Club will be an afternoon water ballet, Olympic diving exhibition and alligator wrestling exhibition at the pool, preceded by a fashion promenade during the luncheon hour. Prospective hostesses include Mrs. Martin B. Faris, Mrs. Guston T. Fitzhugh and Mrs. Charles Corby, all of New York.

A fight that has aroused more genuine interest than any of the current indoor season will be staged at the St. Nicholas Palace tonight when Mickey Farber of the East Side opposes Al Davis, undefeated lightweight from the Brownsville section of Brooklyn. The bout is scheduled for eight rounds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP).--The American Civil Liberties Union asserted today that conditions were "deplorable" in most of the insular possessions of the United States and recommended a "broad extension" of civil rights in the colonies.

The fifteenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will see the only performance this Winter of Wagner's "Die Meistersinger." During that week, beginning Monday, "Tristan and Isolde," "Siegfried," "La Boheme" and "Ill Trovatore" will receive their final presentations.
PORTLAND, Ore., Feb. 19 (AP).-- Pro tennis touring is gutting hard on 27-year-old muscles, and daughter doesn't know him any more, so Ellsworth Vines will quit the golden trek.

Although delightful Spring weather prevailed, only sixteen gunners visited the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. C.T. Jackson won the high-over-all scratch cup by breaking 97 out of 100 targets.

MOSCOW, Feb. 19.--The crew of the disabled Soviet icebreaker Syedoff, which has now drifted to within 275 miles of the North Pole-- the farthest north ever reached by any vessel--has declined the offer of the Soviet authorities to relieve them by airplane and deposit another crew aboard.
The role of WPA workers in extending the city's play facilities was outlined yesterday by Lieut. Col. Brehon B. Somervell, local Works Progress Administrator.
CHICAGO, Feb. 19.--Firmness in prices of corn last week on the Board of Trade was regarded by brokers as due largely to local short covering and a little change in local sentiment.

The City Planning Commission was urged not to give hasty approval to the Battery to Brooklyn suspension bridge by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects, in a resolution made public yesterday by Arthur Loomis Harmon, president of the chapter.
After wandering around the National Sportsmen's Show for many hours the arrived at the conclusion that, while the hunter may have been slightly ignored, the angler had not.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19.--Between 2,000 and 3,000 of the men who fought under Carranza, Villa and Zapata dined under the blazing sun in the old amusement park just off Paseo de la Reforma today and heard speakers exhort them to unite to save the revolutionary movement in Mexico from being dominated by Stalinist doctrines imported from Moscow.

ALBANY, Feb. 19.--The legislative session enters its second phase this week with the consideration, by the joint committees of the Senate and Assembly of Governor Lehman's $411,000,000 budget and his program for $64,000,000 in new taxes.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 19.-- Herbert Pascoe, Speaker of the New Jersey Assembly, disclosed here today that a Republican House caucus in Trenton tomorrow would consider an inquiry to determine "what steps the State Department of Banking Insurance had taken to prevent the closing of the New Jersey Title Guarantee and Trust Company of Jersey City."

The annual report of the Western Electric Company, Inc., for 1938, released for publication today, shows a net income of $5,734,000, after all expenses and charges, compared with $19,514,000 in 1937, a drop of $13,780,000.

Miss Mildred Stewart, former intercollegiate titleholder, representing the Salle Santelli, captured the honors in the first of a series of annual silver foils invitation fencing tournaments at the Salle D'Armes Vince yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 19.--The Economist's index of British commodity prices, based on the average of 1927 as 100, was 68.5 on Feb. 15, compared with 68.7 a fortnight before; 68.7 a month before and 60.4 on Sept. 18, 1931, just before suspension of gold payments by Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19.--While total net income reported on individual income taxes for 1937, which were filed from January through August of last year, increased by $2,145,189,386 over the previous year to $21,088,537,025, the tax liability on taxable returns, on which there was taxable income of $15,193,949,142, dropped by $61,691,888 or 5.1 per cent, Secretary Morgenthau announced today.

The Temple of Religion at the New York World's Fair will show that, along with the advances in science and culture, religion is in the picture of the future world, the Rev. Dr. Charles B. Ackley declared yesterday morning in a sermon at St. Mary's Episcopal Church, 521 West 126th Street.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 19.-- Army athletic insignia for participation in Fall sports have been won by 119 cadets. Benedict, superintendent of the Military Academy.

Mr. Rudolph Binder states in The Eugenical News that in the fifteen years that followed the World War Germany lost between ten and twelve million--several times the number who succumbed to bullets, gas and lack of food.

A NEW Federal Communications Commission of eleven mem bers, with a division of five commissioners in complete charge of the regulation of broadcasting, has been proposed by Senator Wallace White of Maine as a substitute for the Wheeler-McNinch bill to establish a three-man commission with authority centralized in the chairman.

Mussorgsky's "Boris Godunoff," in a revival after ten years' absence from the repertory, and the season's first performance of "Parsifal" will be features of the last week, beginning next Monday, of the Metropolitan Opera season.
The New York Telephone Company will show today in its annual report for 1938 a net income of $29,377,181 available for dividends, or $6.97 a share.
ROME, Feb. 28 (AP)--Three thousand Italians returned to their homeland from France today in the greatest mass movement yet undertaken in Italy's program of repatriation of her citizens abroad.

Undermanned and underrated, but not at all uninspired, the Canadiens of Montreal contributed one of the biggest upsets of the waning National Hockey League season by shutting out the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden last night.

Barring totally unforeseen developments, the Hines conviction will insure District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey the support of the entire New York State group of about ninety-two delegates at the Republican National Convention next year, according to opinions expressed yesterday by political leaders in New York City.
Prominent among charitable activities conducted during the Lenten period are benefit card parties. Several have been arranged for the coming week in New York and in near-by communities.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26.--The party of Yankees that left New York yesterday arrived at the world champions' training camp tonight and discovered that, even by the definition given by the front office, there was a holdout problem.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP).--The Boston Bruins, National Hockey League leaders, recorded another victory tonight over Chicago Black Hawks, 5--1, before 11,000 fans.

BERLIN, N.H., Feb. 26.--The biggest crowd in the long history of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association, 25,000 persons, braved a swirling snowstorm today to witness the national skijumping tryouts to select the American color-bearers for the world championships is Norway next year.

Justice McLaughlin's years on the bench, first of the County Court and then of the Supreme Court in Kings County, will not soon fall into oblivion. His early interest in juvenile delinquency led him to support the Baumes lawn and to advocate the raising of the age covered from 16 to 18.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26.--A moderate revival in the export demand for corn last week drew in a sufficient volume of speculative buying and a lifting of hedges to advance the price of futures 1/8 to 3/8 cent a bushel.

Hailing the New York World's Fair as an instrument for peace, President Ismet Inonu of the Turkish Republic broadcast his nation's greetings to the people of the United States and to the exposition from Angora yesterday afternoon.

MOSCOW, Feb. 26.--The case of Mikhail Voznesensky, Rudolf Island radio operator accused of sabotage contributing to the loss of Sigismund Levanevsky and his five companions in their attempt to fly over the North Pole to America in August, 1937, was given, to the judges tonight for a verdict. This will be handed down tomorrow evening.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 26.--In exactly three days, sixty-two Cardinals will enter the conclave to select one of their number to succeed Pius XI to the throne of St. Peter. Never before, probably, has the supreme function invested in the Sacred College been followed by Catholics and non-Catholics alike with such breathless interest as today for seldom, if ever, have the political implications of the Cardinals' decision been as obvious and immediate.

PARIS, Feb. 26.--The Bourse registered even less animation last week than in the previous one, the business volume being insignificant. Prices were heavy, although they hardened somewhat in the last two sessions, but closed without any noticeable improvement. Rentes, alone, ended the week higher than a week ago.

In 1938, the General Foods Corporation sold the largest tonnage of food in its history, according to the preliminary annual earnings statement made public today by C.M. Chester, chairman of the board.

It is natural that attention should be paid, with more or less of perplexity, to the smallness of present transactions in securities. On the New York Stock Exchange, trading in stocks during the year to date has been about the same as in 1938, and, except for 1935, that was the smallest for the period since 1926.

New Yorkers were urged yesterday to free themselves of bigotry and overcome the "tendencies toward race, class, religious and individual hatred" in a statement signed by ninety prominent laymen of the Protestant, Catholic and Jewish faiths.

BERLIN, Feb. 26.--Frank AshtonGwatkin of the British Foreign Office has been here for a week, ostensibly to prepare for forthcoming trade talks between British and German export industries. Actually, however, his purpose has been to investigate the possibilities of a general political settlement as a necessary condition for the cessation of the armament race and a return to economic normalcy.

Anna Sokolow and her Dance Unit gave their first Broadway recital of the season at the Alvin Theatre last night under the auspieces of the New Masses for the benefit of the Medical Bureau and North American Committee to Aid Spanish Democracy.
Housing properties in Brooklyn proved attractive to investors is the week-end activity, Among the sellers was the Brooklyn Trust Company, which disposed of two parcels.

An individual cannot earn God's favor but he can work toward the "eternal life" and do what he aan to be worthy of it, Professor Frederick C. Grant of the faculty of Union Theological Seminary declared in a sermon yesterday morning at the James Memorial Chapel, Broadway and 120th Street.

Midwinter inactivity continued for the most part to surround both the stock market and trade. On the Stock Exchange prices began last week with a decline which, on a small volume of Business, brought averages to the lowest since Oct. 1.
WINTER PARK, Fla., Feb. 26 (AP).--Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declared today a "responsible press is the life-blood of our democratic system."

Columbia University's School of Law will bring a required course in jurisprudence into its curriculum next year as a step in giving more recognition to legal philosophy, the subject for instructibn in-which the late Justice Benjamin N. Cardozo bequeathed his residuary estate to Columbia, it was announced yesterday.

Bad Catholics are at the root of every evil and persecution the church has suffered from the time of Judas Iscariot to the present day, Mgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Professor of Fundamental Theology at Catholic University, Washington, declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

PARIS, Feb. 26.--President Manuel Azana of the Spanish Republic left the Spanish Embassy on Avenue George V this evening at 10 o'clock for his brother-in-law's home near Geneva. By this act he abandoned all pretension to act as Chief Executive of the Spanish Republic.

LONDON, Feb. 26.--The British Government has informed the Jewish and the Arab delegates to the Palestine Conference that it intends to end its mandate over Palestine and establish an independent State with treaty relations with Britain.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP).-- Hirosi Saito, former Japanese Ambassador to the United States, died here today at the age of 52.

THOMASVILLE, Ga., Feb. 26.-- It's not often they repeat in the army of touring golf professionals, but Henry G. Picard of Hershey, Pa., winner of the recent tourney at New Orleans, took the big prize today in the Thomasville open.

Distinguished American opera personalities replied with some bitterness yesterday to remarks of the Italian tenor, Beniamino Gigli, who was quoted in cable dispatches as saying that the Metropolitan Opera in New York was in a state of decadence.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Feb. 26.-- Paramount has purchased "Triumph Over Pain," Rene FueloeMiller's biography of William Morton, the Boston dentist who discovered anesthesia in 1846. Arthur Hornblow Jr., will produce the screen version this Summer, and Henry Hathaway will direct. Preston Sturges has been assigned to prepare the scenario.
A thick fog, accompanied by steady rain, covered New York and vicinity yesterday, paralyzing airplane traffic and slowing up, though not halting, shipping and ferry service.

WARSAW, Poland, Feb. 26.-- Anti-German rioting continued here today. Agitated crowds marched through the main streets trying to reach the German Embassy and frequent clashes with police occurred. Several hundred, youths, after meeting in the Engineering College, proceeded toward the German Embassy and police had to intervene.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 26.--Somewhere in the South Atlantic tonight the battle lines between the White and Black fleets were believed to be forming, marking the approach of the major engagement, as the second week began in the United States Navy's manoeuvres and its working out of Fleet Problem XX.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The Republican National Committee asserted in a statement today that twenty-one of forty-eight States are now "unquestionably Republican" and that, if the party carries New York State in 1940, "the Republicans would be able to put their nominee in the White House."

Thirty-two men, the crew of the American freighter Lillian, were rescued from open boats thirteen miles off Barnegat Lightship last night after drifting for more than an hour through a dense fog in which their ship had collided with the German freighter Wiegand.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 21.-- Nazi German influence in Central America, though widespread and active, is nowhere as yet a menace to the dominating influence of the United States throughout the Central American republics. That summarizes impressions gathered in the course of a trip that I have just made through all five of them, beginning with Costa Rica and ending here.

ALBANY, Feb. 26.--Governor Lehman anounced today the appointment of Robert M. Benjamin of New York City as a Moreland Act Commissioner to investigate the field of administrative law in New York State and report back his findings on the subject to the Governor before the 1940 session of the Legislature.

PARIS, Feb. 26.--Finance Minister Paul Reynaud has not given the exact figure but has declared rather enigmatically that gold furnished to the Equalization Fund by the repatriation of capital would suffice to buy 6,000 airplanes in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The Treasury's net excess of cash expenditures over cash income in January amounted to $357,000,000, making a total net cash outgo for the seven months of the fiscal year of $1,518,000,000, according to the February bulletin of the United States Treasury Department, made public today.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 26.--The educational spotlight turned upon the problems of rural schools and the intention of administrative leaders to seek a revision of the general curriculum of all the nation's public schools in the interests of developing more intelligent and capable citizens, with the opening today of the sixty-ninth annual convention of the American Association of School Administrators.

A banking group headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., will offer today, subject to award by the City Council, a new issue of $2,150,000 city of Kansas City, Mo., serial bonds, due March 1, 1940 to 1975.

The fifty-first annual indoor championships of the Amateur Athletic Union passed into history on Saturday amid a shower of records and stirring achievements that set them apart as the best games of the season.
The Home Owners Loan Corporation and saving banks figured prominently as the sellers of houses in the Bronx which they had foreclosed.

AMSTERDAM, Feb. 25.--Continued weakness of the guilder is greatly puzzling Dutch quarters. Whereas some time ago the pressure on Dutch currency could be explained by the fears of a threatening European conflict, the situation in Europe now is certainly no ...
PAGELAND, S.C., Feb. 26.--Unless roaring Red MacPhail proffers sullen Van Lingle Mungo a contract calling for "a lot more" than $5,000, the Dodgers will have no Mungo on their pitching staff in 1939.

LONDON, Feb, 26.--The stage was set tonight for simultaneous recognition of the Franco regime in Spain by Great Britain and France, following the hurried departure from Paris of President Manuel Azana of the Spanish Republic.
PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26.--Interest in the steel trade continues to be focused on second-quarter price possibilities, with a formal announcement expected some time this week.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26.--The Japanese launched their long-deferred campaign today against Lushan, on whose peak fifty-five foreigners, including twelve Americans, remained despite repeated warnings by the invaders to leave.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26.-- Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Stackhouse of Greenwich, Conn., will entertain a company of seventy with a kaffe klatsch tomorrow morning at the Surf Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26.--Judge William H. Holly of the Federal District Court here and five other members of the Illinois State bar, in a statement issued in connection with the rift in the National Lawyers Guild on the issues of communism, fascism and nazism declared their opposition to any and all "ideologies, political philosophies or isms which challenge our American institutions."

LONDON, Feb. 26.--Amid all the current conflicting factors in the economic picture, those of a more favorable character came out on top last week in the financial markets here, which slowly felt their way to slightly higher price levels.

Arrangements for the sale of the motion picture rights to "Abe Lincoln in Illinois," the season's outstanding dramatic success, have been virtually completed, with the price reliably reported at approximately $275,000, a record figure.

Defeating Columbia at Hanover on Saturday, Dartmouth assured itself of at least a tie for the championship in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League. It was the ninth--straight victory for the Indians in the circuit and their thirteenth in a row in and out of the league.
The crux of the problem of the sluggishness of the business recovery lies in the outlook for profits, according to the Guaranty Trust Company's monthly survey of business and financial conditions.

ROME, Feb. 26.--The Italian Government has ordered the expulsion of three Swiss correspondents, including Paul Gentizon, for twelve years Rome representative of the Paris Temps, it was learned today. The two others are Robert Hodel, for twenty-nine years correspondent of the Neue Zuercher Zeitung, and Luigi Pedrazzini, for five years correspondent of the Gazetta Ticinese.

The trade-mark of modern life is the tin cup, and the watch cry seems to be "Give me my rights!" the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Fortyeighth Street, said yesterday in his sermon on "Liberty and License."

Competing in an exceptionally strong field of twelve teams, the Fencers Club trio of Hugh Alessandroni, Tracy Jaeckel and Norman Armitage won the John Allaire Trophy in the three-weapon tourney at the New York Athletic Club yesterday. It was the second victory in two years for the Fencers Club in this event.

Otis A. Glazebrook Jr., chairman of the Kreuger Toll Company 5 per cent debenture protective committee, has announced that $1,944,632 will be made available today to holders of certificates of deposit for the debentures on the basis of $43.80 for each $1,000 of deposited debentures.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The votes by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls in Congress during the period Feb. 18 to 24 are given in the appended tabulation:

BERLIN, Feb. 26.--Prentiss B. Gilbert will be buried in Geneva, where he was United States Consul General and an unofficial American observer of the League of Nations from 1930 to 1937. His body will be taken to Geneva immediately after the funeral service her a Tuesday in the American Church. The service will be attended by representatives of the German Government, the diplomatic corps and Mr. Gilbert's many personal friends.
CERTAINLY the biggest novel of the season thus far is Elizabeth Page's "The Tree of Liberty,"* for it is something like 500,000 words long--about as long as five ordinary-sized books put together.

The Schulte Real Estate Company, which recently bought 518 Madison Avenue, has added to its plottage by purchasing from the Bank for Savings the five-story apartment house adjoining at 520. It paid cash for the property and now controls two business parcels on a combined plot of 40 by 95 feet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--Facts which he termed "amazing" and "startling" had been brought out by the Temporary National Economic Committee's hearings on the insurance business, Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney of Wyoming, committee chairman, said today in the latest of his statements giving "highlights" of the monopoly investigation.

A fair volume of mail orders was placed in the New York wholesale market last week. Buyers' visits to obtain apparel and accessories for pre-Easter selling are expected to swell sales volume this week and next.

ALBANY, Feb. 26.--Wide-spread discrimination against New York's 500,000 Negroes in the fields of employment, housing, education, recreation and hospitalization is charged in the summary of a report to be made to the Legislature tomorrow night by the temporary Commission on the Condition of the Urban Negro Population, an official legislative body, after a twoyear study of the problem.
BURGOS, Spain, Feb. 26 (AP).-- The Foreign Office of Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime announced today that Venezuela and Bolivia had accorded full legal recognition to the government.
High winds and a driving rain kept the field down to twelve gunners for the final shoot of the month over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

BERLIN, Feb. 28.--Financial circles here deny that Chancellor Hitler's adoption of the rejected fiscal reform measures recommended by Dr. Hjalmar Schacht and Count Lutz Schwerin von Krosigk will make any appreciable contribution toward solution of the current economic and financial difficulties.
CHICAGO, Feb. 26.--Shoe sales, particularly in the better grades, are the brightest spot in an exceedingly irregular Loop specialty store trade.

The proposal of Rumania to force the emigration of 50,000 Jews annually during the next five years should be opposed everywhere, Leo Wolfson, honorary president of the United Rumanian Jews of America, declared in an address yesterday at the twenty-ninth anual convention of the organization at the Hotel Astor.

Dreary, rainy weather may be preferable for fishing, but yesterday's miserable conditions kept the public away from New York's 1939 edition of the National Sportsmen's Show at the Grand Central Palace and prevented the creation of a new attendance record.

LONDON, Feb. 26.--A summary of the Britash Government's suggestions for solution of the constitutional phase of the Palestine problem was presented to the Jewish and the Arab delegates to the Palestine conference over the weekend.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Feb. 26.--Madcap of Herds, a snow white sealyham from the Croglin Kennels, West Orange, N.J., was selected tonight by John G. Bates for the best-in-show award at the fifteenth annual all-breed event sponsored by the Kennel Club of Buffalo at the Rroadway Auditorium.

The, possibility of new peace negotiations with the Congress of Industrial Organizations will bring no relaxation in the American Federation of Labor's campaign for revision of the National Labor Relations Act, it was learned last night.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26 (AP).--Japanese authorities were understood today to have decided to renew their demand for increased policing power in Shanghai's International Settlement for suppression of terrorism.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., Feb. 26.-- If Carl Owen Hubbell were possessed of the same flamboyant disposition so commonly associated with one Dizzy Dean, there would not be the slightest doubt that the famed screwball maestro would be predicting arrousing comeback for himself with a modest quota of at least twenty-five pitching victories.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 26.-- Young Dick Shaughnessy of Dedham, Mass., set a new world record as he completed a sweep of the individual events and paced his club to the team title in the seventh annual Middle Atlantic States skeet championships at the Loantaka Club today.
Paul Vancso and Miss Mary Whittemore became the new Eastern badminton champions yesterday on the courts of the Old Sixtyninth Badminton Club at the 165th Infantry Armory.
Is the President's effort to reconcile the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations likely to prove successful where previous peace negotiations have failed?

LONDON, Feb. 26.--The Board of Trade estimates a final deficit of 55,000,000 in Great Britain's overseas trade in 1938, compared with deficits of 56,000,000 in 1937; 18,000,000 in 1936; a surplus of 3,200,000 in 1935; a deficit of 7,000,000 in 1934, and an even balance in 1933.

PARIS, Feb. 26.--Speaking at Marseille today former Premier Pierre-Etienne Flandin made an appeal for real liberalism in international relations and, above all, in international exchange as the only effective antidote to the conflict-of ideologies and the only way to prevent war. He put the blame on both totalitarian and democratic leaders for the present situation.

One of the most impressive musical events this city has seen in many years, one that stirred the pulses and tightened the throats of those who were present both as spectators and listeners, was the appearance of Ignace Jan Paderewski yesterday afternoon in Studio ...

Cotton prices last week again moved within a narrow range. At the close of trading, on Saturday, active future deliveries on the New York Cotton Exchange had registered net advances of 6 to 12 points for the week. The old-crop deliveries were up 9 to 10 points, while the new-crop months gained 6 to 12 points.

The morale of the Police Department was never better than it is today, Commissioner Valentine told 3,000 members of the Protestant St. Geoige's Association of New York policemen in pointing out to them at their second annual communion breakfast in the Hotel Astor yesterday the responsibilities that would come with the World's Fair.

Thomas M. Lynch, a former resident of Poughkeepsie, who had been Appraiser of the Port of New York since July, 1933, died Saturday night at his residence, 1,035 Park Avenue, of a heart attack after a week's illness. He was 64 years old.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Feb. 26.-- After taking poison tonight Mrs. Lydia Van Dusen, 37 years old, of 1,055 Brown Street here, persuaded her 5-year-old son, Richard, and a neighbor's boy, William Hoffman Jr., 12, to drink some of the liquid, which they thought was water. Richard died soon afterward, Mrs. Van Dusen died a few hours later and the Hoffman child is in a critical condition at the Peekskill Hospital.

A net profit of $7,412,072 is reported by the Radio Corporation of America for 1938, equivalent after preferred dividend requirements to 30 cents a share, compared with $9,024,858, or 42 cents a share, earned in 1937.

April, due to the fact that it ushers in the open trout season, is also important to the striped bass anglers, especially those who like surf casting. Ed Buckley of Freeport, who is usually on his toes when he hears the word "striper," says they began taking them from the surf in the Jones Beach area on April 15 last year.

At the services attending the unveiling of the bas-relief of Mr. Edmund L. PEARL BUCK'S newest book may not be of Nobel Prize stature, but it is an excellent and pointed story told for the most part with warmth and much charm. The studied quasi-elegance of her "This Proud Heart" period at least temporarily abandoned, Mrs. Buck has gone back to the scene of "The Good Earth" and "Sons" for this ninth of her novels. The title is "The Patriot."

LOS ANGELES, March 1 (AP).-- Captain Clyde Earl Tousley, former member of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, died last night at his home here after a two-year illness. He was 50 years old. In the World War Captain Tousley served as first lieutenant of infantry.

Ninety-five students in Columbia College have won King's Crown awards for outstanding extra-curricular service, it was announced yesterday by Benjamin A. Hubbard, director of King's Crown activities. Formation of the Association of Customers Men was heartily endorsed yesterday by William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, at a meeting of the new body yesterday afternoon at the Hotel New Yorker.
As Sixth Avenue emerges into the light with the razing of the elevated, interest in realty along that thoroughfare is rapidly returning.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP).-- Gerard Swope, president of the General Electric Company, told the House Ways and Means Committee today he thought that $15 a person a month was as much as the Federal Government should pay now toward old-age pensions. He testified at hearings on proposals to expand the social security system.

A search warrant permitting the examination of four safe deposit boxes held by the late F. Donald Coster, president of McKesson Robbins, Inc., was issued here yesterday by United States Commissioner Isaac Platt. Three of the boxes are in Bridgeport, Conn., and one in Jamaica Queens.
CANNES, France, March 6.-- Patriarch Miron Cristea, Premier of Rumania, died here this evening of bronchial pneumonia that was complicated by heart disease. He was 71.

A composer of popular songs, with the manners and appearance of an old-fashioned music teacher, went to Federal Court yesterday, acting as his own attorney in a suit for an injunction and an accounting against the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers and twenty-one co-defendants.

Reports of the sharp upsurge in wholesale purchases of major electrical appliances since the introduction of new lines started early in January were confirmed here yesterday by the monthly figures of the National Electrical Manufacturers Association.

Mrs. Julia Isham Taylor, who gave Isham Park in upper Manhattan to the city in memory of her father, the late William B. Isham, died yesterday at her residence, 135 East Sixty-sixth Street, after an illness of several months, in her seventyfourth year. Her husband is Henry Osborn Taylor, historian of the Middle Ages.
LONDON, March 6.-- Zionist and British delegates to the Palestine Conference met again in an informal session tonight and again adjourned to meet at some unspecified time in the near future.

Mack, chairman of the board of the college, and Robert P. Goldman, president of the union.

Faust, who tossed a bomb among the audience at a war benefit performance by the Chicago Grand Opera Company on Nov. 17, 1917, stood in the Detective Bureau today and explained the appearance of four other bombs which had been hidden in a safe-deposit box more than twenty-one years.

Lockwood in Brooklyn.

The stock market started out yesterday as though it would continue the buoyant tendency displayed last week, but soon found the going heavy.

PARIS, March 6.--For the first time since the war and under a new law making espionage in peacetime an offense punishable by death, a former French naval officer, Ensign Marc Aubert, condemned for treason two months ago, was executed at Toulon this morning. It is said his revelations to a potential enemy power might have led to a major naval disaster in wartime.
WASHINGTON, March 6.--President Roosevelt received today a special medal awarded by the American Hebrew Magazine for his work on behalf of religious tolerance.
PARIS, March 6.--How is the French Government to get rid of the 400,000 refugees from Republican Spain (including some 50,000odd soldiers), who are proving such a costly and troublesome burden?

MIAMI, Fla., March 6.--Many colonists entertained with luncheon and box parties at the opening of the Spring horse racing meet at Tropical Park this afternoon.
Each year in the excitement of the approaching trout season we seem inclined to forget that thousands of surf casters are equally interested in the possibilities of April as a fishing month.

Johnny Layton, representing New York, managed to get an even break yesterday in the national three-cushion tournament in two of his hardest matches. He won from Tiff Denton of Kansas City by 50 to 46 after losing the afternoon match by 50 to 49 at the Strand Billiard Academy.

EDGEWATER, N.J., March 6.-- A fight between nearly 100 members of the C.I.O., who are striking against the Archer-Daniels-Midland Linseed Oil Company, and scores of alleged strikebreakers, which took place near the company's River Road plant here this morning, resulted in the arrest of nine men on charges of disorderly conduct.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., March 6 (AP). --An intensified milk diversion program to enforce dealer compliance with the voluntary contract replacing the Federal-State marketing agreement invalidated by the courts was mapped by dairy leaders tonight as the metropolitan producers' bargaining agency met here to take stock of the situation.

WASHINGTON, March 6.--Colonel Edwin M. Watson, for six years military aide to President Roosevelt, will doff his uniform early next month and take office as a secretary to the President, filling the vacancy left by the resignation of James Roosevelt, the White House announced today.
TOKYO, March 6.--A six-year naval replenishment and expansion plan, costing 1,693,000,000 yen and designed to give Japan a navy equal to the strongest fleet afloat, was announced today.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP).-- Southern Representatives moved quickly today to avert a split with Western members over proposals to equalize railroad freight rates throughout the country.

WARSAW, Poland, March 6.-- Grigore Gafencu, Rumanian Foreign Minister, left Warsaw this afternoon for Bucharest after a most successful three-day visit. He carried the feeling that the PolishRumanian alliance, much shaken by the Czecho-Slovak crisis last Fall, was again a working arrangement, renewed and reinforced.

A proposal for the rezoning of lower Sixth Avenue as a residential district from Spring Street to the south side of Thirteenth Street was submitted to the City Planning Commission yesterday by the Sixth Avenue Association.

The average cost of living in the United States is now about 85.3 per cent of the 1929 level, according to figures made public yesterday by the statistical division of the National Industrial Conference Board. Items included in the estimates of the average cost of living were food, which accounted for about 33 cents of the wage-earner's dollar; sundries, 30 cents; housing, 20 cents; clothing, 12 cents, and fuel and light, 5 cents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 10. --Five members of the title-defending eight-man Lehigh University squad reached the finals tonight to climax the opening day of the thirty-fifth Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium at Yale.

After what was believed to be the most scathing denunciation of a defendant ever voiced by a General Sessions judge, James Strachen, 31 years old, a mechanic's helper of 309 East Fifty-eighth Street, was sentenced to a Sing Sing term of two to five years yesterday.

The Governor of California has challenged New York State and other sovereign communities boasting well-equipped inland waterways to a national race of river steamers on April 22, it was announced yesterday in a communication from the California State Chamber of Commerce.

CHICAGO, March 10.--Sales of men's clothing in February showed a good gain over 1938, the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers reported today. Sales were better by over 17 per cent, according to 56 per cent of the reports to the national business committee. With 20 per cent business was about the same, while 24 per cent noted decreases averaging 14.5 per cent.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., March 10.--Elwood Burdsall, president of the First National Bank and Trust Company of Port Chester since 1915 and secretary-treasurer of the Russell, Burdsall Ward Bolt and Nut Company since 1901, died here today in his home after an illness of six months. He was 82 years old.

The agreement reached between the United States and Brazil, the largest of our South American neighbors, promises great advantages for both countries. It will stimulate the flow of trade in both directions.

More than 250 students and guests attended the junior-sophomore promenade of the New York University College of Arts and Pure Science and College of Engineering last night in the Bowman Room of the Hotel Biltmore. The event marked the first time that the two classes have held their annual dances under joint sponsorship.

The 1939 Maintenance Fund Campaign of the Brooklyn Council of Boy Scouts of America has already realized $20,000, it was announced yesterday by George P. Kennedy, chairman of the general campaign council.

Threatened reprisals against the United States Weather Bureau were averted yesterday when the Blizzard Men of '88, on the eve of celebrating the fifty-first anniversary of the Great Blow, decided to ignore what they consider a gratuitous insult to the rondest calamity of their lives.

The three-day respite from classrooms of delegates to the fifteenth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association on Morningside Heights took on a scholastic air yesterday as speakers advised them to "learn all you can" in preparing for a journalistic career.

ALBANY, March 10.--Factory employment and payrolls reported to the State Labor Department as of Feb. 15 were at the highest points since November, 1937, Frieda S. Miller, State Industrial Commissioner announced today. The factory employment index rose to 81.7, while the payroll index was 76.1. The period from 1925 to 1927 is used as 100 in compilation of the index.

LONDON, Saturday, March 10.-- The British destroyer Intrepid early this morning rescued the British freighter Stangate which had reported that she had been seized by a Spanish Nationalist warship twenty-three miles north of Cape San Antonio and was being taken tn Palma, Majorca.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--Presidential possibilities became a lively theme among Republican leaders here today when a delegation of twenty-six New York Republicans arrived for a "harmony conference" with party members of Congress from New York State.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--Department store sales for the week ended March 4 were 7 per cent higher than for the corresponding week last year and for the fourweek period ended March 4 were 1 per cent higher than for the similar period a year ago.

Business employers are seeking the "American type" of employe, described as a girl who is slender, attractive, courteous, well-mannered and not overpainted, Dr. Alexander S. Massel, principal of Central Commercial High School, declared yesterday.
ONE mile to go. The Columbian Mile in the Knights of Columbus Games at Madison Square Garden tonight. It's the last big mile of the indoor season. Glenn Cunningham will be there.
Mr. Charles M. Schwab's decision to close his residence on Riverside Drive is determined by personal reasons which we must all respect; but lovers of New York would hate to see this landmark removed.

VATICAN CITY, March 10.--Today this correspondent attended with Denis Cardinal Dougherty, Archbishop of Philadelphia, and two members of his suite, a private audience of farewell to the new Pope in his office in the Vatican.

An appraisal of the collateral behind Alleghany Corporation 5 per cent bonds of 1944 made by the Guaranty Trust Company yesterday held that the value of he collateral behind the bonds was more than 150 per cent of their face value. Formal announcement of the Guaranty's findings is to be made today.

HAVANA, March 10.--Five American yachts sailed over the starting line off Morro Castle at 6:15 P. M. today for the race to Key West, Fla. All had participated in the tenth annual contest from St. Petersburg, Fla., to Havana, which ended yesterday.

Walter Spence defeated his clubmate, Peter Fick, by the margin of four feet in a special 220-yard free style race in an exhibition swimming meet held in the pool of the New York Athletic Club last night. Spence was clocked in 2:17.5.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.--The American republics are not seeking "an impossible isolation from the other nations of the world," Secretary Hull stated today in a message to a University of Pennsylvania forum on the Lima conference.

In his address at the Bond Club on Thursday Assistant Secretary of Commerce Patterson brought attention to bear again on the proposal to place more "working directors" on the boards of American business corporations.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., March 10.--Robert E. Orr of Crestwood, Yonkers, a civil engineer and president of the Robert E. Orr Company, Inc., general contractor and builder, with offices in Grand Central Terminal, New York, died here today in Lawrence Hospital after a week's illness. He was 51 years old.

PARIS, March 10.--There was a striking lack of public curiosity as Eugene Weidmann, German killer, and his accomplices went on trial today at the Versailles Palais de Justice. Passers-by showed little interest and only a small group waited outside to see the prisoners come and go.

WASHINGTON, March 10.--Negotiations to end the strike in thirteen Washington hotels were started today by conciliators from the Department of Labor. L. R. Steelman, director of conciliation, said that "definite progress" had been made in a meeting with the strikers and hotel owners.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10.--On the eve of the first exhibition game of the 1939 campaign against the Cardinals, Marse Joe McCarthy today received good news at the Huggins Field proving grounds of the Yankees.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)-- Five women testified today before a House Interstate Commerce subcommittee considering the Schwartz-Martin wool labeling bill, and all but one urged that it be approved. The bill would require that all garments bear labels showing their exact fiber content, including percentages of virgin and reclaimed wool.

NEWARK, N. J., March 10.--The list of defendants in the Newark meadowland conspiracy case was reduced to nine today when Common Pleas Judge Dallas Flannagan granted motions for the dismissal of charges against four defendants.

HENDAYE, France (at the Spanish Frontier), March 10.--Fighting continues in Republican Spain as forces supporting the National Defense Council still struggle to suppress a revolt of the Communists.

BUFFALO, March 10 (AP).--Three police officers were ordered tonight to testify before a grand jury investigating city affairs, without immunity from prosecution under a new provision of the State Constitution.

Clifford Curzon, English pianist, who made his American debut in this city a fortnight ago, appeared last night at Carnegie Hall in a concerto program in which he was assisted by sixty-five members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, under Alexander Smallens.

UTICA, N. Y., March 10.--More than 500 Central New York dairymen voted unanimously this afternoon to withhold all milk from handlers in the New York milk shed Tuesday morning if 90 per cent of the metropolitan distributors have not signed uniform contracts.

Dr. Benjamin M. Anderson Jr., economist of the Chase National Bank since 1920, will leave the bank to accept an appointment as Professor of Economics at the Los Angeles division of the University of California, it was announced yesterday. He will assume his new post in September.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 10. --Four hundred couples tonight danced at the fourth annual Yale freshman promenade, which was held in Woolsey Hall. The grand march was led by George W. Kirchwey of New Canaan, Conn., and Miss Ellen-Douglas Allen of Greenwich.

Richberg.
Magistrate George H. Folwell in Bay Ridge Court, Brooklyn, dismissed yesterday afternoon a complaint of criminal libel naming Fritz Kuhn, but denounced the Nazi leader and his work.

GLENS FALLS, N. Y., March 10. --George Frederick Bayle, president of the Glens Falls Portland Cement Company from 1905 to 1933, died at his home here today at the age of 78. He retired six years ago because of ill health.

Eighty per cent of the current denials of bank credit fall on small and very small business, according to figures presented yesterday at the closing session of the Eastern Regional Conference of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria.

LOS ANGELES, March 10.--Hafis Salich, former navy intelligence operative, and Mikhail Gorin, Russian tourist agent, were convicted of violating the Espionage Act by a Federal court jury here today. Natasha Gorin, wife of Gorin, was acquitted.

"New York's Friendly Day" will be observed in churches tomorrow by proclamation of Mayor La Guardia. This is in connection with the campaign now being waged by the Citizen's Committee of the Salvation Army for the work of that organization.

PHILADELPHIA, March 10.-- Peter A. Rubano, one of the best known operatives in the United States Secret Service, died last night in the Presbyterian Hospital after an illness of two months. His age was 57.

MANCHESTER, England, March 10.--Shouting, "God save Ireland!" and "Up the Republic!" and other slogans, six men and one woman were sentenced in a closely guarded courtroom here today to imprisonment ranging from seven to twenty years for their parts in recent bomb explosions.

CHICAGO, March 10.--Michigan's powerful Wolverines bid strongly tonight for a sixth straight Big Ten indoor track championship by advancing nine men for tomorrow night's championships at the University of Chicago field house.

WE sometimes say that humorists try hard to be funny. What we usually mean is that they have not tried quite hard enough. For no one minds what labors lie behind the conceits that bring on laughter. But we do mind having the labor made apparent: we seldom enjoy seeing scaffolding.

Mussorgsky's masterpiece, "Boris Godunoff," which was revived at the Metropolitan Opera House last Tuesday night in the final week of the regular season, was repeated last night.

The Goodall Company, manufacturer of Palm Beach clothing, will increase its cooperative advertising with retailers 20 to 30 per cent in the coming season over that of last year, it was announced yesterday. Newspapers will be the media for the cooperative copy.

THERE is an air of Brontesque tumult about Stefan Zweig's "Beware of Pity," the story of a girl's desperate infatuation. This is the first novel that the author of "Marie Antoinette," "Mary, Queen of Scotland and the Isles," and various other essays in biography has written. It displays admirably his skill in italicizing dominant traits that may rule a character. And it is unfolded with all his glossy; rolling assurance.

PRAGUE, March 16.--Prague entered its second day of German occupation in a mood of stolid resignation. The Czech people have apparently lost the national self-confidence they had acquired in the twenty years after the World War and their spirit appears to be broken.

The fright given io the financial markets on Wednesday by Chancelor Hitler's fresh triumphs in Central Europe seemed yesterday to have passed by. Rules under which rooming-house proprietors may obtain licenses to operate during the World's Fair period were issued yesterday by Paul Moss, Commissioner of Licenses.

The rose was the featured flower yesterday at the twenty-sixth annual flower show at Grand Central Palace. There were roses massed in formal gardens, cut varieties remarkable for length of stem and size of bloom and new specimens shown for the first time.

WITH THE HUNGARIAN ARMY, in Huszt, Carpatho-Ukraine, March 16 (AP).--Hungarian troops stormed this little Carpatho-Ukraine capital at 4 P.M. today and after an hour and a half of energetic mopping up smashed all Czech and Ukrainian resistance.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 16.--Stroking calmly with precision, in contrast to the fury of his oppovent, Elwood Cooke of Portland, Ore., upset the defending champion, Wayne Sabin, his fellow-townsman, today to enter the final round of the annual Bermuda tennis championships. He will meet top-ranking Bobby Riggs of Chicago.

Dramatic evidence that science may have at last discovered a diagnostic test for early cancer in human beings, a step that would go a long way toward solving the problem of cancer, second on the list of man's natural killers, is reported in the current issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, out today.

New Yorkers have watched with sympathetic interest many and many a St. Patrick's Day parade. The kindly folk in it and on the sidewalks will seem kindlier in a world so much of which is hostile to what most of us believe and hope. Yet in such a world today's march has a profound significance.

The Empire State Association of Mail Order Men has decided to admit individual members and organized groups from the Eastern seaboard and New England States.

LOUISVILLE, March 17 (AP).-- With a beard dyed green, D.G. Carr, 59, a Pennsylvanian Railroad engineer of Irish-Scotch-German descent, observed St. Patrick's Day today. He said he used green ink and was going to have a little more fun before he cut his beard off.

Bad weather during the week was responsible for postponement of Spring promotions and a slowing of reorder activity in wholesale markets, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday in its weekly summary.

When President Roosevelt sailed from Key West for a holiday in mid-February he said that he hoped to stay away until March 4, but that he might be forced to return sooner because of continued reports of a disturbing nature from abroad.
WATERBURY, Conn., March 17. --"When the history of this case is written it will be no more than a foreword of the history of the fraud that was perpetrated in this city."

ITHACA, N.Y., March 17.--The second prize of $50 in the Forbes Heermans award for play writing at Cornell University was won by Edward L. Kamarck of New York City, a junior in the Arts College. His play is entitled "Apartment 3 D." Competition is open to any undergraduate of the university, for plays written on an American theme. No first prize was awarded.

TAMPA, Fla., March 17.--He used to be Mild Will from Wilkinsburg, Pa., and a choir singer when he was at home, but now they are calling him Commissar McKechnie, the leader of the Red menace in baseball. Though the Cincinnati Reds finished fourth in the National League last season, friends and strangers are now coming up to Commissar McKechnie and accusing him of having this year's pennant in his grasp.

Robert A. Burns of Reiss Advertising, Inc., won the gold medal presented each year by the Advertising Club's advertising and selling course for the best essay written on what benefit was derived from the instruction.

Excelling with all three weapons, the City College fencing team defeated Wayne University of Detroit, 18 to 8 , on the Lavender strips yesterday. Max Goldstein and Herbert Specter of City won three bouts apiece, the former with the foil and the latter with the saber.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Denison Noyes of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harrison Crane Noyes of Norwich, Conn., to Carl Victor Schieren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harrie V. Schieren of Montclair, N.J., took place here yesterday afternoon in the Church of the Transfiguration.

CHICAGO, March 17 (AP).--Johnny Brown, 124, Chicago, outpointed Eddie Dempsey, 126 , Moline, Ill., tonight in an eight-round fight. Frankie Kainrath, 123, Chicago, gained an eight-round decision over Jackie Cellura, 124, Hamilton, Ont.

When Eric S. Pinker entered a not-guilty plea in General Sessions yesterday in the alleged $18,500 theft from E. Phillips Oppenheim, the writer, Assistant District Attorney Dewell T. Tyng, in demanding high bail in the case, told Judge Owen W. Bohan complaints had been made to District Attorney Thomas E. Dewey that the defendant's thefts amounted to more than $100,000.

Resolutions warning against hasty action by the city in approving the plan for a bridge to connect Brooklyn and the Battery, and urging more deliberate study of the needs and most feasible type of connection between these two points, were adopted yesterday by the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 17.-- Bids will be called shortly to supply the government-owned railways with locomotives, rails and freight cars to the amount of $6,000,000, the managing director of the Central Railway declared today.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--President Roosevelt issued a proclamation today designating April 6 as... Army Day. He invited the Governors of the States to issue similar proclamations and ordered military units to assist civic bodies in observance of the day.

At the annual meeting yesterday of the Dictaphone Corporation M.B. Sands, president, told stockholders that business during the first two months of this year ran about 10 per cent ahead of the corresponding months of 1937.

For an hour yesterday Maurice Evans, the actor, sat at the edge of the stage in the St. James Theatre and essayed an extemporaneous and difficult role; that of a patient, wity man inviting all questions thrown at him by more than 200 girls and boys from secondary and preparatory schools.

The plan under which the Broad Street Hospital would be reorganized under the bankruptcy laws of this State was approved yesterday by Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, who must submit his findings to a Federal judge.

CHICAGO, March 17.--Prices of wheat in leading markets turned upward today on buying induced by the war scare in Europe.

With Preston Goodfellow notching two goals and aiding on another, the Poly Prep hockey team shut out an alumni sextet, 5 to 0, at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.
BRADENTON, Fla., March 17.The Yankee observance of St. Patrick's Day was a bitter pill for the Hibernian skipper of the squad, Joseph Vincent McCarthy, when the champions clashed with the Bees today.
