PRINCETON, N.J., March 17.-- Richard B. Handing, Brooklyn, has been elected captain of the Princeton wrestling team, succeeding Addison V. Foshay, also of Brooklyn, it was announced today by Coach Jimmy Reed.
DES MOINES, Iowa, March 17 (AP).--H.W. Shaver, an auditor, won a divorce from his bride of three months yesterday on grounds that she is a "jitterbug."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 17. --Paced by the Golden Gophers of Minnesota and the skilled St. Nick sextet of New York, four top-flight hockey teams emerged as semifinalists in the national A.A.U. championship tonight after eight hours of blistering hockey in the first round.
CLEVELAND, March 17 (AP).-- Cleveland teams held four of the five leading places in the five-man event of the American Bowling Congress tournament tonight.
CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., March 17.--Ormande William McClave, president of the McClave Lumber Company of New York, died today at his home here of heart disease after a long illness. He was 55 years old.
MONTREAL, March 17 (AP).--One rink from the United States survived the first round of the final stage of competition for the Royal Caledonian Curling Trophy today while two others were beaten.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--Elmer F. Andrews, Administrator of the Wages and Hours Law, today appointed an industry committee to study conditions in the shoe manufacturing industry and to recommend minimum wage rates for the approximately 215,000 shoe workers.
E. Lewis Johnson, formerly of New York, died at his home at Glendale, Calif., Thursday, according to word received here yesterday. He was 87 years old.

An additional specification accusing Magistrate Mark Rudich of Brooklyn of accepting money for approving a bail bond posted in a prostitution case was filed under stipulation yesterday with the Appellate Division in Brooklyn in preparation for the jurist's removal hearing before that tribunal next Monday.
GENEVA, March 17.--A warning that Switzerland is prepared to fight, if necessary, to maintain its independence was given today by Federal Councilor Hermann Obrecht, addressing the New Swiss Society.
A consolidated net profit of $3,598,739 for 1938 is reported in the annual statement of the Curtiss-- Weight Corporation, to be issued today by Guy W. Vaughan, president.

ELIZABETH, N.J., March 17.-- Bloomfield High School qualified for the final round of the State Group IV high school basketball championship by scoring a 36-to-34 victory over Trenton High School in a thrilling game tonight before more than 3,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--The Federal Government was charged with "fraud" today by a company cited for violation of the WalshHealey act providing that minimum wages be paid workers on government contracts.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, returned yesterday on the Cunard White Star motor ship Britannic with Mrs. Butler from a brief holiday in Nassau. He declined to discuss foreign affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--The House Ways and Means Committee decided unanimously today to exclude farm laborers, domestic help and employes of charitable, religious and non-profit institutions in any revisions of the social security system.

LIMA, March 17.--The local Hibernian Society held its annual dinner this evening, celebrating St. Patrick's Day in one of the capital's leading restaurants. The guests of honor were United States Ambassador Laurence Steinhardt and the British Minister, Courtenay Forbes.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--Summaries of the naval strength of the great powers disclosed today that the British and French had better than a two-to-one naval advantage over Germany and Italy so far as ships ready for action were concerned, and an even greater advantage if ships under construction were included in the picture.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--President Roosevelt will be away from the capital on two occasions during April, according to plans announced by the White House today. The schedule is subject to change if foreign or domestic events require his presence here.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 17 (AP).--Two of the favored teams filled the final bracket today in the Bermuda tennis championships before rain stopped play.

George S. Hinkins, vice president of the American President Lines, in charge of all East Coast operations of the company, has resigned to form his own steamship agency in Baltimore, it was announced yesterday.
Cotton-mill activity increased more than seasonally last week, and the adjusted index rose to 120.9 from 119.6. The figure was 91.6 for the week ended March 12, 1938.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--Supply contracts valued at $155,161,242 were awarded during the week ended March 11 by fourteen Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.
AMHERST, Mass., March 17 (AP). --Burgess Meredith, the actor, returned to his former school and received an honorary degree of Master of Arts.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--New York City today asked the Supreme Court to uphold the constitutionality of the Prior Lien Law of 1937, under which the city may repair tenements thirty-eight or more years old and charge the cost against the property above all other liens except for taxes and public improvements.

LONDON, March 17 (AP).--Prices on all wools were firm at today's auction. Offered were 8,678 bales, including 697 bales of Falklands ranging 6 d to 11 d a pound. Sales totaled 7,056 bales. Buyers for the domestic trade took heavyweight and crossbred wools, while Continental business again was limited.
WASHINGTON, March 17.-- Newspaper correspondents found President Roosevelt in a St. Patrick's Day bantering mood at the opening of his press conference this morning.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., March 17. --Many parties will precede the dance for parents of pupils of the Buxton Country Day School here to be given tomorrow at the school.

Avian aviation made history, a little convalescent girl in a hospital was made happy and a press agent realized a dream yesterday when a homing pigeon named Braddock made a twenty-mile non-stop flight here from Elizabeth, N.J., with a cargo of one canary, riding piggyback.

NEWARK, N.J., March 17.--Up to the end of 1935 the city of Newark had invested $19,394,000 in its airport and Port Newark developments, according to testimony today at the city meadowland conspiracy trial.

The Central Railroad of New Jersey will default in the payment of interest due on April 1 on its registered general-mortgage bonds, Edward W. Scheer, president, announced yesterday. There are ninety days of grace in which the default may be "cured."
SAN FRANCISCO, March 17 (AP). --The most reckless selling in the stock market this year sent stocks tumbling today. The cause was the foreign situation and its implications.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--An assertion that increased individual consumption of whisky was undesirable in view of the social implications involved in too great use was made by Dr. Wesley A. Sturges, executive director of Distilled Spirits Institute, in testimony before the Temporary National Economic Committee today.
Dave Freeman of Pasadena, national junior tennis champion and California badminton and table-tennis titleholder, has entered the national badminton championships...
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 17.--Letters have been awarded to members of Wesleyan's Little Three champion basketball squad and the varsity swimming squad, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 17.--President Roosevelt indicated today that a supplemental farm program dealing specifically with the problem of huge commodity surpluses, particularly of cotton, might soon be submitted to Congress.

Because the religion of an attorney was mentioned in the summing up address a $45,177 negligence verdict returned by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo was set aside yesterday and a new trial ordered by the Appellate Division in a unaiimous decision.

Industrial expansion has been marked in many New Jersey communities in recent months. Some towns which have been making a concerted drive to attract more plants have made their greatest progress during the last two or three months.

Stockholders of the Federal Mining and Smelting Company will be asked to approve at their annual meeting on April 10 the retirement of the company's preferred stock, of which 8,000 shares of $100 par value are outstanding.
ALBANY, March 17.--Republican legislative leaders have received an eight-page handwritten letter from former Governor Nathan L. Miller suggesting drastic cutting of the proposed $415,000,000 budget.

Plans for altering the four-story dwelling at 125 East Sixty-second Street, between Lexington and Park Avenues, were announced in the sale of the house by Joseph L. Ennis Co., operators, to Dora Frank.

Creation of an "opportunity school" to train, guide and reeducate New York City's thousands of unemployed boys and girls between 17 and 24 years of age, at an estimated initial cost of $50,000, was recommended yesterday by the Vocational High School Division.

PARIS, March 17.--At a ceremony attended by the Duke and Duchess of Windsor and many prominent American and French personalities a tablet commemorating the inauguration of the American Legion was unveiled here today on the occasion of the Legion's twentieth anniversary.

Paintings and drawings by Balthus were placed on view yesterday at the Pierre Matisse Gallery. A feature of the exhibition is a large oil, the first of four panels of the season that the artist is planning. Fourteen drawings, illustrations for "Wuthering Heights," are included.

The vacant plot forming the northwest corner of Linden Boulevard and 222d Street, St. Albans, Queens, 100 by 94 feet, has been sold by the Albans Holding Corporation to Charles Benenson, operator and builder.
The Friendly Society of the Sons of St. Patrick in Brooklyn held their annual celebration last night in the Columbus Club, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn.

Jessie King, Australian mezzosoprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Miss King received her early musical training in her native country and later studied in Paris and Vienna.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 17.--President Leon Cortes Castro recommended a reduction in the export tax on coffee from 8 to 6 per cent as a relief measure for coffee planters. President Cortes announced that he hoped to make further reductions until the tax was eliminated.

IT is no surprise to find that among the twenty tales in William March's new book, "Some Like Them Short," there are few that fail and a good many that are excellent. For Mr. March is one of the most accomplished of contemporary short-story writers. He is master in many forms.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 17.--The Belleview amateur golf championship on the Belleview Biltmore links was won by George F. McLaughlin of Chicago, who defeated Edwin H. Vare Jr. of Philadelphia, 5 and 4...

VATICAN CITY, March 17.--Pope Pius XII will take possession of the Cathedral of St. John Lateran, his see as Bishop of Rome, on May 18. This ceremony will complete those connected with his assumption of St. Peter's throne.

AIKEN, S.C., March 17 (AP).--Miss Kathryn Hemphill of Columbia, S.C., won the third Aiken women's golf tournament today with a fiftyfour-hole 219. Mr. Opal S. Hill, Kansas City professional, was second with 221 and Miss Isabel Ogilvie of Augusta, Ga., was third with 229.

As fearlessly as St. Patrick himself battled with the pagan Oisin, 60,000 loyal sons and daughters of Ireland braved a biting wind to parade for nearly five hours yesterday on Fifth Avenue, which was transformed into a lively sea of green in honor of the patron saint of Ireland.

Unless the political tension eases in Europe in the near future, and Wall Street has no "inside" advices that it will, it appears likely that the flow of frightened capital to the United States will increase, with the usual precautionary building up of foreign balances here.

PARIS, March 17.--With the avowed object of turning France into a vast workshop for national defense, Premier Edouard Daladier, in agreement with his Cabinet, today asked Parliament to approve within the next two days a five-line bill giving the government full power to rule by decree in all matters affecting national defense.

Jack Hoffman, sales manager of Lake Hiawatha, near Caldwell, N.J., announces that five additional cabins and six plots have been sold in that development. Among the purchasers were Robert Fulton, Mary Lynch, Herbert Clayton, Robert Guillan and H. Shoemaker.
CHICAGO, March 17.--Samuel Hiram Schneider, executive secretary of the Association of Western Railways, died today in his home here after a long illness. He was 52 years old.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Brazil, March 17 Alfred Realini, Brazilian explorer, reported today that he had seen the skeletons of Colonel P.H. Fawcett, British explorer, and his son, Jack, who vanished in the Brazilian Matto Grosso jungle in 1925. He said they had been killed by Indians.

RENO, March 17.--Mrs. Elizabeth Greve Carolin, the former Lillian Elizabeth Greve of New York, who divorced T. Grant Caldwell of Brooklyn last June, obtained a divorce today from Edward Marley Carolin, to whom she was married here in October. She charged cruelty.
PHILADELPHIA, March 17 (AP). --Young stars from Trenton, N.J., High School won three events tonight to take the team championship in the thirty-fifth annual national interscholastic swimming meet.

The Federal Communications Commission may consider soon extending the six-month period for which licenses are granted to radio broadcasting stations, Frank R. McNinch, the chairman, said yesterday in an interview at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

SHAMROCK, Pa., March 17 (AP). --There was no "wearin' of the green" today in this tiny village with the Irish name. Shamrock is in the heart of Pennsylvania's Dutch country and there's not an Irishman in town.

PATERSON, N.J., March 17 (AP).--State Boxing Commissioner Abe J. Greene today lifted a ninemonth old suspension of Bob Pastor and cleared the way for the heavyweight to go through with a scheduled fight in Chicago on March 31. Pastor and his manager, James J. Johnston Jr., were suspended last July when Greene charged they had failed to fulfill an agreement to fight Clarence (Red) Burman in Newark.

BERLIN, March 17.--The Krupp Works exports during the fiscal year 1937-38 ending Sept.30 were 21 per cent higher than those of the previous year and represented 25 per cent of the concern's total business, according to a statement issued today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 17.--George Ward Fuller of this city, former vice president of the Ingersoll-Rand Company, died here today in a convalescent home following a brief illness. He was 87 years old.

Stars of stage, screen and radio will appear tonight in the annual show and fashion revue of the Israel Orphan Asylum to be held in Madison Square Garden. Proceeds will be used for the support of the orphanages maintained by the organization.

After snatching a satchel containing a $2,734 payroll from a clerk who was carrying it to the office of the National Maritime Union of America, two armed robbers escaped yesterday noon from the lobby of the five-story building where the union has its quarters at 126 Eleventh Avenue, near Twentieth Street.

LONDON, March 17.--After six weeks, the Palestine Conference ended today in failure as far as producing any agreement between the Arabs and Jews is concerned.

A two and one-quarter cent reduction in the price of Grade A and Grade B milk delivered to homes, and corresponding reductions in the price of store-bought milk--the biggest single reduction in more than twenty years--were announced last night by the Borden Farm Products Division of the Borden Company, the cut to become effective tomorrow morning.

Surrogate James A. Foley sighed with relief yesterday as he announced that he had decided that ten persons in the fifth degree of kinship would share equally in the $877,500 estate of Ida E. Two thousand persons will attend the sixth annual communion breakfast of the Board of Education's Bureau of Attendance Catholic League tomorrow at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

H. L. Bolton and John F. Lucas were elected directors of the Breeze Corporations, Inc., at a meeting of the board yesterday, following the annual stockholders' meeting. They succeed Melville C. Healy and Joseph L. Lucas.
The American Laundry Machinery Company will ask stockholders at their annual meeting to authorize the company to buy 25,000 additional shares of its stock.

WASHINGTON, March 17 (AP).-- The Social Security Board announced today grants to New York State as follows: aged, $1,228,513 (April only); blind, $94,856 (April 1 to June 30); children, $287,292 (April only).

Minneapolis, Minn., will be in the market on April 20 with S2,969,000 of permanent improvement, water works, relief and refunding bonds. Details will be announced later.

Trade here this week continued to maintain gains over the comparative week a year ago. Department store volume was estimated as averaging about 4 per cent ahead of last year, although several establishments had increases ranging up to 10 per cent or more.

The Maryland Hunt Cup Association has sent out announcements for the forty-sixth annual race for the Maryland Hunt Cup April 29 over the estate of J.W.Y. Martin in Worthington Valley, Md.
TORONTO, March 17 (Canadian Press).--Profits of $9,893,587 for the year ended March 31, 1938, were shown in the report of the Liquor Control Board of Ontario tabled in the Ontario Legislature today.

WARSAW, March 17 (AP).--The newspaper Kurjer Warsawski reported today that more than thirty soldiers were killed when Czech troops resisted the German occupation of Czech Silesia on Tuesday.
The Duchess of Leinster gave a luncheon yesterday at La Salle du Bois for Miss Natalie Bayard Merrill. Others in the party were Mrs. Wales Latham, Mrs. Auguste Winter and Miss Madeline Mason-Manheim.

CAPE MAY, N.J., March 17.-- Another page in the drama of the sea was written today when Lieutenant Richard L. Burke, commander of the Coast Guard air base here and favorite pilot of Henry Morgenthau Jr., Secretary of the Treasury, flew ninety miles to sea and rescued from boats fifteen miles apart two men who were badly in need of hospital care.
CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Saturday, March 18.--Prime Minister B.M. Hertzog confirmed today the report that Germany had made representations about immigration restrictions in Southwest Africa.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that the two-day conference that was to have been held here late this month in commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the Bill of Rights had been postponed until October.
BERLIN, March 17 (AP).--Adolf Heuser of Germany won the European heavy weight championship tonight by knocking out Heinz Lazek in the fifth round of a fifteen-round fight before a crowd of 14,000.
Drexel Tech will make a fivegame Southern baseball trip, according to an announcement by Walter H. Halas, director of athletics.

Irving Fain, 47 years old, of 36 East Twenty-seventh Street, reputed to have amassed millions before the stock market collapse ten years ago, flew in an airplane yesterday from Chicago to stand trial in General Sessions on thirtytwo counts in a sixty-one-page grand larceny indictment.

PHILADELPHIA, March 17.-- After remarking that his action probably would "shock the community," Judge Harry S. McDevitt today sentenced William (Blackie) Zupkosky, gunman and bandit, to a prison term of 100 days to 100 years and then suspended the sentence.
At a meeting of the directors yesterday Johnston de Forest was elected a director of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company.

DUBLIN, March 17.--Ireland celebrated its national festival today with customary patriotic fervor. The shamrock was worn proudly by all sections, while flags were flown in every town in Eire. Even across the border in Belfast and Derry national emblems were freely displayed.

TRENTON, N.J., March 20.--The Legislature reconvened tonight after a ten-day recess, but after a brief session adjourned until next Monday night without sign of an early agreement on a relief financing program.

MEXICO CITY, March 20.--Donald R. Richberg, in a statement today, pointed out that, despite recent intimations by President Lazaro Cardenas and other Mexican officials that the expropriation controversy was near a settlement, the chief result of his visit was "a better understanding of the different views of the Mexican Government and the companies."

In Wall Street discussions of the appointment to the Supreme Court Bench of William O. Douglas, chairman of the SEC, the greatest interest attached to conjectures about Mr. Douglas's probable successor. The opinion in best informed circles seemed to be that Jerome N. Frank would be the outstanding candidate for the post of chairman of the commission.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 20. --Until the last three races, long shots ran rampant and favorites performed as if homesick for the North at Tropical Park today. Ordinary horses provided the sport, the card being left without a feature when the original fifth event was canceled because of withdrawals and a claiming contest substituted.

Applauded by the more than 400 shareholders present, Floyd L. Carlisle, chairman of the board of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., at the annual meeting yesterday at the utility's headquarters, 4 Irving Place, declared that the greatest deterrent to recovery today was the "log jam" in the capital markets, which, he said, had been caused, in no small measure, by the "restrictive legislation" of recent years.

The ominous course of events in Europe continued yesterday to weigh heavily upon the securities markets here. After starting out with some substantial but scattered gains, stocks turned soft and followed a ragged downward trend most of the day. Trading was less active than it had been last week, the day's turnover being 946,500 shares, against 1,007,240 on last Saturday and 1,470,190 on last Friday.
An analysis of recent constructionpermit figures shows that smaller cities have been making comparatively larger expenditures for various types of buildings than the metropolitan centers.

BERLIN, March 20.--A communique issued by the Foreign Office tonight says that the recall of the German Ambassadors from London and Paris and the rejection of the British and French protest notes did not constitute a mere formality but were intended to express the Reich Government's displeasure with the attitude, especially of Britain, toward the solution of the Czecho-Slovak problem.
SHANGHAI, Tuesday, March 21 (AP).--Japanese drove into the rich and unconquered area south of Hangchow today in what appeared to be the start of a wide-scale offensive in Central Chekiang Province.

Sinclair Lewis's "It Cant Happen Here" will head a program of fiftytwo feature pictures which MetroGoldwyn-Mayer will produce and release during the 1939-40 season, it was announced yesterday by William F. Rodgers, general sales manager, at the second session of the company's annual three-day sales convention at the Palmer House in Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in 101 leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended March 15: decreases of $48,000,000 in loans to brokers and dealers in securities and $375,000,000 in holdings of Treasury notes, and increases of $448,000,000 in holdings of United ...

Fire that appeared to have started in their bedroom fatally burned two children on the fourth floor of a five-story old-law tenement at 68 East 112th Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, shortly after 8 o'clock last night.

The first scientific evaluation oil the parcle system is now being conducted in New York, David Dressler, chief parole officer of the State Division of Parole, disclosed yesterday. He said the first section of the study would be completed at the end of this year and would show the effectiveness or ineffectiveness of the system in this State.

CAIRO, Egypt, March 20.--Further examination today by Professor Pierre Montet of Strasbourg University of a silver sarcophagus containing a royal mummy, discovered near the ancient Egyptian city of Tanis, in the Nile Delta, revealed that the mummy was not that of King Psou-Sen-Nes, a father-in-law of King Solomon, but of one King Sheshonq.
Milady had best start shopping for earrings if the prediction of beauty experts, assembled for their annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania, is borne out during 1939.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 20.-- Many colonists entertained guests tonight at the southern plantation dinner which was given at the Everglades Club.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 20.-- The United States may send military missions to Latin America to displace similar missions from Europe, but Latin America does not have to accept them, according to the Dominican writer B. Gimbernard, frequently described as spokesman for President Leonidas Trujillo, writing in the Journal Cosmopolita.

SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., March 20 (AP).--National Champion Miss Patty Berg cracked low drives through chilly winds, putted consistently and scored an eight-underpar 75 today in topping two-score competitors in the first round of the fifty-foul-hole Mid-South women's medal play tournament.
Dr. James C. Ayer, retired New York surgeon, died yesterday in the Ritz-Carlton Hotel after a short illness. Since 1930 he had lived most of the time at his home in Nassau, British West Indies.

Jack Pearl, who has been away from the Broadway stage for six years, having appeared last in "Pardon My English," has been signed for "Yokel Boy Makes Good," which Lew Brown expects to put in rehearsal in early May. That would probably mean a premiere in June.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--William Orville Douglas, 40-year-old chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was nominated by President Roosevelt today to the Supreme Court vacancy recently created by the retirement of Associate Justice Louis D. Brandeis. His confirmation, of which there appeared little question, would make him the youngest man to sit on the tribunal in more than a hundred years.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The Department of Agriculture today announced agreement in principle of a plan for the purchase of 81,000,000 bushels of wheat by the Federal Surplus Commodities Corporation held under the 1938 wheat loan program to which the Commodity Credit Corporation takes title at the maturity of the loans.

Five hundred office workers, members of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, Local 16, a C. I. O. affiliate, met last night at the Manhattan Center, Thirty-fourth Street near Eighth Avenue, and voted to bolt the organization and affiliate with the American Federation of Labor through its Bookkeepers, Stenographers and Accountants Union.
WASHINGTON, March 20.--The House rejected a restrictive amendment on United States Housing Authority unit costs today and passed the Interior Department Supply Bill for 1940, carrying $159,543,905.

Plans for the reconstruction of Battery Park is conjunction with the proposed Battery-Brooklyn bridge were announced yesterday by Park Commissioner Robert Moses. The plans provide for a connection between the East and West Side highways and the bridge approaches that would require the removal of the South Ferry elevated station, which serves persons using the Staten Island ferry and the East and West Side elevated trains.
OGDENSBURG, N.Y., March 20 (AP).--The Most Rev. Joseph H. Conroy, Bishop of Ogdensburg, died today from a condition resulting from a heart ailment suffered two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--Congressional leaders moved today toward expediting the Administration program for training civilian pilots as a part of the essential reserves in this country's defense program.

PARIS, March 20.--Using the special powers accorded to him by Parliament, Premier Edouard Daladier today obtained the assent of the Cabinet and the signature of President Albert Lebrun to sixteen decrees.

Spring football practice got under way at New York University yesterday, with ninety-five candidates reporting to Coach Marvin A. (Mal) Stevens and his staff of assistants in the University Heights gymnasium.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 20. --Although a good many weeks remain before final judgment can be passed on the matter, it already seems to have become quite clear that when Bill Terry swung his famous three-for-three deal with the Cubs last December he accomplished suite a bit of all right both for himself and his Giants.

By a vote of less than three to two in the Chamber of Deputies but by more than twenty to one in the Senate, Premier Edouard Daladier has gained the power to rule France by decree. Parliament steps aside. In constitutional theory President Lebrun might nullify a decree by refusing to promulgate it.

Reflecting substantially improved retail trade toward the close of last week, mail orders in the wholesale markets here yesterday were heavier than a week ago. Some stores had their best volume of the season on Saturday. The reorders yesterday were largely concentrated on ready-to-wear and accessories, but reports agreed that the home wares-lines figured to a greater extent ...

ST.PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20.--Yankee regulars were doing a pretty good job of presenting Casey Stengel's Bees with a ball game at Waterfront Park today until the rookie catcher Buddy Rosar stepped into the picture is the tenth inning.

For almost five years William Orville Douglas has been associated with the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission, authorized under the New Deal to police investments and investment markets. Since September, 1937, he has been chairman.

NEWARK, N.J., March 20.--After a day spent almost entirely in the qualification of the first of a series of defense real estate experts and the putting to him of a thirty--seven--minute hypothetical question, court was adjourned this afternoon in the Newark meadowland conspiracy trial before the expert had an opportunity to set a valuation on one of the three tracts of land figuring in the case.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 20. --Although Dolf Camilli walloped three balls over the right field fence today, the Cardinals furnished too much home-run competition and the Dodgers lost a ball game by 7--5.

CHICAGO, March 20.--Trading in wheat futures here and abroad was much less active today. Speculators were largely on the side lines awaiting further developments in the political situation in Europe. The undertone, however, was relatively firm as exporting countries generally asked higher prices for their grain. Futures on the Board of Trade here held within a range of 3/8 to cent a bushel and closed unchanged to is cent higher.

The fate of "inland accounts," nark credits built up in Germany by American exporters of cotton, copper and other materials and available only for the purchase of German manufactured goods, was one of the major points on which foreign traders speculated here yesterday while they awaited word regarding German trade policy toward the United States, now that penalty duties of 25 per cent have been ordered imposed ...

OTTAWA, March 20 (Canadian Press).--If there was prospect of an attack on Great Britain, Prime Minister Mackenzie King told the House of Commons today, "I have no doubt what the decision of the Canadian people and Parliament would be.

Growing agitation to break down the barriers to free flow of agricultural products between States may ultimately have an adverse effect on the numerous State advertising campaigns to promote farm products. A recent report made by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics to the Secretary of Agriculture expressed the fear that State-financed campaigns, such as that engaged in by Maine, Idaho and Florida, may strengthen these barriers.

After a week-end out for a quick visit to Cincinnati, the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo reopened its Spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with a bill which consisted of "Carnaval," "St. Francis," "The Blue Bird" and "Gaite Parisienne."

The Costa Rican Government, through Dr. Castro Beeche, Minister of Costa Rica at Washington, will announce today a three-year plan for the resumption of interest payments on the dollar bonds of the republic, now in default. The offer provides for the purchase by the ...

The break in the Swiss franc and the news of heavy engagements of additional gold in London, featured the foreign exchange market yesterday. Nervousness over the political position of Switzerland in the light of the German advance into Central Europe was reflected by the ...

Plans are being prepared to erect seventy-five medium-priced dwellings during the present year in the Benson Place section of Westfield in Union County, reports Carl Kolodin of the Fidelity Construction Company, developers of the tract. The new community is known as Park Acres. The property contains fifty-two acres, the greater part of which is well wooded. Three new model homes were recently opened for inspection.

At this critical stage of affairs in Europe, when the British and French Governments are attempting to create a barrier to new German conquests, Senator Pittman has proposed an amendment to our own Neutrality Act which would have a direct bearing on the situation which is now developing abroad. Under the Neutrality Act in its present form, Britain and France ...
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 20.--When Bill Dickey came into the Yankee dugout and began to buckle on his shinguards, Lou Gehrig looked over at him and said, jestingly:
PARIS, March 20.--The possibility that a formal alliance between France and Great Britain may be signed during President Albert Lebrun's visit in London this week is being hinted tonight in Paris.

For six hours yesterday Magistrate Mark Rudich sat in a crowded Appellate Division courtroom in Brooklyn as the hearing of charges seeking his removal got under way. He heard a fellow magistrate, Anthony F. Burke of Manhattan, accuse him of attempting to influence the disposition of a criminal case concerning which Louis Kassman, professional bondsman and self-confessed perjurer, had testified previously that he paid Magistrate Rudich $100 to handle the unsuccessful "fix."

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The ginger-haired, pale young Far Westerner with the cowboy gait whom the President today nominated to be an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States is one of the most interesting, able and genuine people in public life. His keen mind and salty--even sulphurous--speech ...

RIGA, Latvia, March 20.--In an exciting finish among four closely bunched leaders, Salo Flohr of Prague, hero of the recent Leningrad-Moscow chess congress, emerged today as winner of first prize in the international masters tournament, which began at Kemeri on March 4.

If confirmed by the Senate, William O. Douglas, named by the President to fill the vacancy in the United States Supreme Court left by the retirement of Justice Brandeis, will sit on the highest bench in the land without any previous experience as a judge. In this, as in several other respects, however, his career parallels that of Felix Frankfurter.

Although the Museum of the City of New York moved to its new building in Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets only seven years ago, already the structure has been outgrown. The institution's "greatest needs today are more space and more fund," Beverley R. Robinson, president, said in the annual report issues yesterday.

HONG KONG, Feb. 28.--Although Hong Kong has not been so poorly equipped to repel an armed attack as has Gibraltar, which had only four anti-aircraft guns at the time of the Munich conference last September, this island outpost of imperial Britain has also lagged behind in defense works, and feverish attempts are now being made to make up for lost time.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 20.--The six-room residence and one-acre gardens of Guy Colby, senior partner in the New York accounting firm of Colby Co., were sliding slowly down a mountainous hill beside the Hudson River here today.

Although activity in the New York printing industry is currently running considerably below normal, definite indications of an upturn have developed in the last few weeks, according to oplnlons expressed yesterday at the opening of the three-day Fourth Annual Exhibition of Modern Trends in Print

According to a preliminary report of the Committee for the Study of Federal and State Stock Transfer Taxes issued yesterday, security transactions are being driven out of New York State by the present State stock transfer tax.

Fickle Charlie McCarthy transferred his affections from Edgar Bergen, his boss, to Mayor La Guardia at City Hall yesterday during a ten-minute visit to advertise the Press Photographers' Ball at the Hotel Astor on April 14.

Two English skating stars, Miss Daphne Walker and Freddie Tomlins, arrived yesterday aboard the North German Lloyd liner Europa to take prominent parts in the charity figure skating carnival which will be presented for four nights at Madison Square Garden. The opening performance will be on Friday night.

The submission to Congress of a bill to establish a Railway Reorganization Court, which should deal with the exceedingly vexed question of reorganization for embarrassed companies, is at least a useful first step in legislation for relief of the carriers. The sponsors of the bill point out that its provisions are in line with the suggestions ...

Pressure was lifted yesterday from most groups of domestic bonds while foreign-dollar obligations eontinued to decline from nervous liquidation caused by the week-end developments in Europe. Trading was at a subdued pace from last week with the most conspicuous recovery shown among the United States Government direct loans.

George J. Langley, lawyer and former World War aviation lieutenant, will contest the leadership of the Eleventh Assembly District with Bernard F. Plunkett, who has been picked to succeed James J. Hines following Hines's conviction for participation in the numbers racket, it was announced yesterday.

Still fulfilling the functions of a representative of an independent country, Karel Hudec, acting consul general of Czecho-Slovakia, yesterday paid a courtesy call on Mayor La Guardia at City Hall and later, in an interview, announced that under international law the agencies of the former government here may well remain in operation until the United States recognizes the protectorate set up by Germany.

MONTREAL, March 20.--The National Hockey League made the official announcement tonight that Hector (Toe) Blake was the league's leading scorer for the 1938-39 season that wound up last night. The hard-working left-winger of the Montreal Canadiens had a total of 47 points, made up of twenty-four ...

WASHINGTON, March 20.--Internal revenue collections in February were $333,517,597.03, an increase of $52,916,142.38 over February a year ago, the Treasury announced today. The increase was largely accounted for by a rise in Social Security tax collections.

Edward Antonio Paulton, dramatic and motion-picture writer, from whose pen came many gay, witty librettos and lyrics to delight musical comedy and light opera followers of the Eighties, Nineties and early Nineteen Hundreds, died yesterday in the Hollywood (Calif.) General Hospital after a brief illness. For the last eight years he had been a dialogue writer and scenarist. His age was 73.

The reports made to Ducka Unlimited by the volunteer checkers scattered at various Winter seeding grounds throughout the country indicate that the largest migration of wild ducks and geese in five years will head for the Canadian breeding grounds this Spring.
Two Washington Heights apartment houses and a long-held loft building in the vicinity of City Hall were among the properties traded in the Manhattan realty deals announced yesterday.

Three former officers of the State Title and Mortgage Company, who were convicted and sentenced more than a year ago but have not yet served a day in prison, received a second period of grace yesterday in Federal Court over the bitter opposition of government counsel.
WASHINGTON, March 20.--Secretary Morgenthau has no fear of inflation despite the rush of warscare gold to this country, he told his press conference this afternoon.

A sit-down strike in the six elevators of the Hotel Governor Clinton at Thirty-first Street and Seventh Avenue, staged in conjunction with a walkout of 169 bellboys, bartenders, maids, chefs and kitchen workers, waiters and waitresses, which closed the restaurants and caused the suspension of service in the thirty-one story structure at 7 o'clock last night, was ended within a half hour by the police.

Led to the spot by a 17-year-old suspect in the theft of $3.22 from the candle offering box in a Brooklyn church, the police recovered from a sewer yesterday a red leather bag containing a small gem-studded crucifix and a chalice, believed to have been the loot in a similar robbery.
The Columbian National Life Insurance Company reports in its annual statement as of Dec. 31, 1938, total admitted assets of $46,216,669, compared with $44,046,905 at the end of 1937.

LONDON, March 20.--Major Lester D. Gardner, American aviation executive, has been elected an honorary fellow of the Royal Aeronautical Society for his distinguished services to American aviation, it was announced today.
SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., March 20 (AP).--Scoring seven runs in the fourth inning before a man could be retired, the White Sox easily defeated the Pirates today, 11 to 4.

PITTSBURGH, March 20.-- The University of Pittsburgh's trustees tonight named Charles W. Bowser, an honor student and gridiron star at the institution from 1920 to 1933, to succeed Dr. John Bain (Jock) Sutherland as football coach.

BERLIN, March 20.--With National Socialist organizations in Memel holding mass demonstrations under the slogan, "Home to the Reich," and Saturday set as the deadline for "fundamental decisions," Juozas Urbsys, the Lithuanian Foreign Minister, today called on Foreign Minister Joachim von Ribbentrop to discuss the situation resulting from this open defection of territory still under Lithuania's sovereignty.

A concession that the brokerage clause of the Robinson-Patman act is constitutional but a contention that its interpretation by the Federal Trade Commission is unconstitutional are contained is a brief made public here yesterday and filed by the Great Atlantic and Par cific Tea Comnanv in the Circuit ...

Preliminary skirmishes in the Na. tional Hockey League's post-season warfare for the Stanley Cup and the championship of the world will be fought tonight on three fronts. At Madison Square Garden the New York Rangers will clash with the Boston Bruins, in Toronto the New York Americans will oppose the Maple Leafs, and in Montreal the Detroit Red Wings will skate against the Canadiens.

The report of the Director of the New York Public Library begins with the rather startling confession that there comes from every department, every division, every branch a sincere and emphatic expression of regret at failure in 1938 to give the public "the quality of service which the staff holds dear."

BERLIN, Tuesday, March 21.--A challenge to democracies to talk as man to man and call a spade a spade is issued in today's Voelkischer Beobachter by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels, who advises the democracies to "forget such terms as humanitarianism, civilization, international rights and international confidence."

ALBANY, March 20.--The Senate by a vote of 27 to 18 passed and sent to the Assembly tonight the Hastings bill, which would permit localities to establish systems of work relief and employ home relief recipients on the projects.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20.--Joseph E. Widenor's notable collection of acacias was adjudged the "most meritorious exhibit" as the 1939 Philadelphia Flower Show opened its doors at the Commercial Museum today.

The State of California will consider bids today for $3,134,644 of registered warrants. The issue will be dated March 24 and is to be due on or about Aug. 30. On Friday officials of the State will offer for sale an additional issue of $3,085,980 of registered warrants.

WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP).-- The Northern States Power Company of Wisconsin signed an agreement today with Smith, Barney Co. of New York for sale of a proposed $17,500,000 issue of twentyfive-year bonds.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--A compromise by which President Roosevelt's request for $150,000,000 for additional relief funds would be cut $50,000,000 was reported today to have been agreed upon by several Democratic members of the House Appropriations subcommittee. They were said to have received assurances that the whole committee would accept the figure of $100,000,000 when it voted on Wednesday.

ALBANY, March 20.--Strong opposition to both the McNaboe and the Devany anti-radical bills was expressed tonight by Speaker Oswald D. Heck at the first general conference of Republican members of the Assembly, held just before the start of tonight's session.

It will be unbeaten Long Island University against unbeaten Loyola of Chicago in the final of the national invitation tournament at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, a game between the last two undefeated basketball titans in the country.

The annual report of the El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries for 1938, released yesterday, shows a net income for the year of $2,083,689, after all expenses and charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.29 a share on the company's outstanding, common stock, and compares ...

WASHINGTON, March 20.--Condemnation by the United States of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's conquest of Czecho-Slovakia, and a flat refusal by this government to recognize the legitimacy of the occupation were made formal and official in a note sent by Acting Secretary of State Summer Welles to the German Embassy this afternoon.

Two leases involving four floors in the seven-story building at 109111 Wall Streets featured the contracts for commercial space reported by brokers yesterday. The Alexander Publishing Company, tax information publishers, who for six years have been at 60 Wall Street, took the fourth, fifth and sixth floors. The American Molasses Company, Inc., took the seventh floor. Leonard. J. Carpenter, broker, negotiated both leases.

Steps were under way in London yesterday toward forming an anti-Hitler coalition. The British proposed a joint declaration and warning by several powers, while the Russians, who hold the key to such a coalition, suggested a nine-power conference. [Page 1.]

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The compromise offer of the Central High School auditorium for the proposed concert here on April 9 by Marian Anderson, Negro contralto, has failed of acceptance, and the concert committee of Howard University again is exploring the limited facilities of the capital with a view to making other arrangements for Miss Anderson's recital.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 20.--The International Congress of American Democracies opened here today with eighty-three delegates present from nine other American counties and several hundred from Uruguay.

A plea for racial and religious freedom and tolerance in this country as an example to a world "rocked by bigotry and prejudice" was made yesterday by speakers at a luncheon in the Town Hall Club sponsored by the New York Round Table of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

WARSAW,Poland, March 20.--A Cabinet of national defense and national concentration was urged here today, opposition leaders arguing that the present government does not command full public support therefore it cannot successfully enlist the nation's moral and material forces to meet the emergency.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 20.--Despite semi-official statements that negotiations on the German-Rumanian trade agreement have not been completed, it is learned from a most reliable source that the final documents will be signed tomorrow. The same source says no new agreement has been made, but merely an annex to the old one.

The recovery under way on the Cotton Exchange at the close of last week made further progress yesterday. The near months regained all of their recent loss. The October rose to its best price for this month and the list ended with ...

The annual report for 1938 of the Cuneo Press, Inc., and subsidiaries, issued yesterday, showed a net consolidated income of $1,025,201 after depreciation, interest, amortization, Federal and State income takes and other charges.
MOSCOW, March 20.--It is said that truth is stranger than fiction, but Andrey A. Zhdanoff is stranger than both. This Zhdanoff, you understand, is a greatly important citizen of the U.S.S.R.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--The Senate went on record today on retrenchment in government expenditures when it inserted in the reorganization bill an amendment by Senator Byrd pronouncing economy to be "desirable."

The "Little Old New York Village" in the amusement zone of the World's Fair was dedicated yesterday by former Governor Smith, Grower A. Whalen, president of the Fair corporation, and George Jessel, who heads the group promoting the concession.

Bars do not have to close at 4 A.M. weekdays and 3 A.M. Sundays and beer may be sold twentyfour hours a day in New York State, it was admitted last night by a member of the State Liquor Authority after the Queens Court of Special Sessions dismissed a complaint against a Jamaica lunchwagon operator.
UNGVAR, Hungary, March 20 (AP) --The flag of Czarist Russia was hoisted today over this capital of Carpatho-Ukraine, annexed by Hungary and made autonomous after the break-up of Czecho-Slovakia.

CHICAGO, March 20.--Following a very satisfactory February record, retail furniture sales have taken a sharp turn for the better during the second ten days of March, the National Retail Furniture Association reported here today.

"MADAME being ill goes into the Bath," the future Minister Plenipotentiary noted in his diary, "and when placed there sends" for me. It is a strange Place to receive a Visit, but there is Milk mixed with the Water, consequently the Parts immerzed are invisible.
A frail Irish widow, 61 years old, protected her $1 "grocery money" early yesterday morning by seizing a makeshift broom-handle walking stick and routing a Negro marauder from her Brooklyn flat.

Leon Barzin, conductor of the National Orchestra Association, knows how to balance familiar music with the less frequently heard, and for last night's concert at Carnegie Hall he turned the trick for both Mozart and Strauss. Mayor La. Guardia announced at City Hall yesterday that 25,000 WPA workers would have to be dropped here by April 3 and that 40,000 to 45,000 more would go by June 30 unless Congress voted the $150,000,000 supplemental relief appropriation asked by President Roosevelt.

ALBANY, March 20.--Several indications today pointed toward the conclusion that the proposed Statewide sales tax was still playing a large part in the Republican financial program for the State which has been under discussion in conferences here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 20.-- James Stewart will be seen in the title part of "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," and Edward Arnold has been cast in the chief supporting role by Columbia. As a youthful Senator bearing a striking resemblance to the Gary Cooper part in "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," ...

PRAGUE, March 20.--The police department, in a statement for the now Nazified Czech Official News Agency, designed to rebut foreign newspaper reports of many arrests and suicides since the German occupation, said Prague's suicide rate was no higher than normal and gave comparatively moderate figures for arrests. It denied that any concentration camp had been set up in Bohemia or Moravia.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--Germany's policy of subordinating economic and financial stability to political aggrandizement has in all essentials defeated itself, since the Reich faces the democracies in such impoverished condition that there is slight possibility it could survive a protracted war.

PHILADELPHIA, March 20.-- Branch 1 of the American Federation of Hosiery Workers sought unexpectedly today to stay the $3,515,872 damage suit now on trial against it in Federal District Court hare by contending that Judge William H. Kirkpatrick was without jurisdiction.

BALBOA, C.Z., March 20.--When Daniel MacFarland Hunsacker Jr. of Los Angeles and Hector Morrison of Vancouver, B.C., were rescued yesterday 300 miles from this port by Captain A. Engstrom of the Swedish freighter Buenos Aires, they were without food and water, their auxiliary motor was disabled and the jib of their yawl, Sunray, had been burned.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--President Roosevelt told Congress today that there was no immediate need for raising the $45,000,000,000 limitation on the public debt. He asked, however, that the $30,000,000,000 "ceiling" on Treasury bond issues be removed.

WASHINGTON, March 20.--Dilatory tactics of German architects, as well as recent "astounding" events which have shocked Americans, have caused the resignation of Harry Francis Cunningham of Washington as associate architect of the proposed new German Embassy, he said today.

FORT WORTH, Texas, March 20. --Vice President Garner was described as "in the driver's seat right now, well in the lead as a likely Democratic candidate for the Presidency in 1940" by Elliott Roosevelt in his semi-weekly broadcast tonight.

William McC. Martin Jr., president of the New York Stock Exchange, telephoned yesterday to theSecurities and Exchange Commission at Washington the text of a letter in which he asserted the commission apparently had misunderstood the aims of the recent conference of national security exchanges, which recommended certain amendments in the Federal Securities Acts.

LONDON, March 20.--The sudden change in sentiment in the stock markets this afternoon brought about a partial-rally from the sharp falls of the morning. The lead for the later trend was received from Wall Street and from hopes for the formation of an international front against Germany.
A move to prevent an "un justified" boycott of merchandise made in Czecho-Slovakia prior to German occupation and now being marketed here got under way yesterday.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 21. --One minor development of today's Dodger doings, aside from the tired feeling that assailed all the athletes after a prolonged session of batting practice, was Leo Durocher's declaration that no more of his men would visit the Tiger trainer, Denny Carroll, for treatments.

NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP).-- Catcher Frankie Pytlak, who walked out of the Indians' training camp today, signed a contract tonight and promised to return to work tomorrow.

Pedro Montanez, 141 , Puerto Rico, knocked out Howard Scott, 140, Washington, in 2:26 of the second of a listed eight-round feature bout at the New York Coliseum last night before a crowd of 8,000 persons.

Richard Andrew Johnston, retired advertising executive, died on Monday night in his home, 98 Morningside Avenue, after a short illness. Had he lived he would have celebrated his seventy-fifth birthday next Saturday and his fiftieth wedding anniversary on April 1.

Differences of opinion as to some of the labor provisions of the legislative program submitted by the Association of American Railroads are expected to be smoothed out at a meeting of the membership to be held in Chicago on Friday.

Ingenuity and a fund of understanding of living conditions in other countries are reflected in a group of miniature houses built by Girl Scout troops of New York, which were judged yesterday at Lord Taylor's by a jury of three. Dr. Leopold Arnaud, dean of architecture,...

Brilliant azaleas, snapdragons, pink and white tulips, forsythia, primroses, yellow jonquils, peonies, bright trumpet daffodils--and Spring--arrived promptly yesterday to make the third annual Children's Flower Show of New York in Germania Hall, Sixteenth Street and Third Avenue, a miniature fairyland.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., March 22.--Suddenly regaining his top form, Joseph Pepp's No Sir beat seven other veterans in the St. Augustine Purse at Tropical Park today. Paying $18.60 for $2 and ...

Conservation Commissioner Lithgow Osborne, speaking before members of the Federated Sportsmen's Clubs of Ulster County, announced that New York was no longer one of the leading States in conservation activity and pointed out that unless matters changed for the better this State would "find itself in the rear guard."

TOKYO, Thursday, March 23.-- Recent mysterious meetings cause the press today to express the belief that the Japanese cabinet is exploring methods by which the European situation may be utilized for the advantage of Japan's imperial policy.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, March 22.--Premier Theodor Stauning, speaking during the election campaign, made the following statement tonight about the foreign situation and its effect on Denmark:

SHANGHAI, March 6.--While Japanese leaders continue to repeat the old phrases about "immutable policies" and while the Chinese leaders reiterate their determination to "fight to the last man," the wellknown Oriental tendency toward political flexibility is apparently coming to the fore.

A plea for a "unified program" for price stabilization in the milk industry, which reflected a lack of harmony between the two big groups of dairy farmers supplying milk to the two largest distributors in the metropalitan area, was made yesterday by the Sheffield Producers Cooperative Association, representing 12,000 dairymen in New York, Vermont and Pennsylvania.

LONDON, March 22.--Germany's seizure of Memel and Premier Mussolini's pro-axis statement caused a sharp break in the stock markets today. Selling developed and the effects of yesterday's rally were eliminated.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 22.-- Touring the championship No. 2 course in 32, 36--68, four under par, Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., forged to the front at the completion of the second round of the annual 72-hole North and South open golf championship at the Pinehurst Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The likelihood of a Congressional investigation of the WPA increased today when the Rules Committee of the House approved, by a vote of 7 to 4, a resolution ordering such an inquiry.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., March 22.--Funeral services for Rear Admiral Ralph Mervine Warfield, U.S.N., who died last night on a New York subway station of a heart attack, will be held at 3 P.M. Friday at the Fort Myer Chapel, Arlington, Va. Burial will follow at Arlington National Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The conduct of the management of the Interstate Hosiery Mills, Inc., in not checking properly the company's financial position for 1934, 1935 and 1936 "indicated a complete abdication of responsibility," the Securities and Exchange Commission said today in an opinion regarded as significant with respect to accounting procedures.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 22.--This country had an agitated day when "everybody's secret" of the partial Rumanian mobilization was revealed through the newspapers, which published the government communique issued last night. Many persons in this capital and the provinces misinterpreted the communique as indicating a general mobilization order, and a large number of reservists went to recruiting centers of their own accord.

In one important respect Hitler's latest triumph differs from his conquest of Czecho-Slovakia. The Memel district into which German troops are marching was once a part of Germany. It was detached from that country and set up as a protectorate of the League ...

Total estimated volume of advertising in 1938 was about $1,530,000,000, compared with $1,768,000,000 in the preceding year, a decline of 13.4 per cent, according to L.D.H. Weld, director of research, McCann-Erickson, Inc., writing in Printer's Ink, out today. This was the first decrease in advertising volume that has taken place since 1933.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 22.--Injuries suffered in an automobile accident by Mrs. Therese H. Semon of Mamaroneck, former president of the Women's Town Club and the Federation Settlement House, both in New York, resulted this afternoon in a Supreme Court jury here returning a $50,000 verdict in her favor. The verdict was for the full amount sought in the complaint, which was said to be unusual.

With the signing of contracts for a system of electric and handpushed chairs, the World's Fair completed yesterday its program for enabling visitors to see as much as possible without walking miles on end, and with a minimum of footweariness.

Martin T. Manton, former senior judge of the Second United States Circuit Court of Appeals, appeared on the defendants' side of the bar in Federal Court yesterday morning and murmured that he was not guilty of corrupting the high office he held less than two months ago.
Tenement houses in scattered sections of Manhattan were sold yesterday by savings banks.

John L. Lewis, chairman of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and president of the United Mine Workers, declared yesterday that the C.I.O. and its affiliates would never agree to dissolve as the price of peace with the American Federation of Labor. Conferences between representatives of the two rival federations are to be resumed in Washington tomorrow in continuation of the effort initiated by President Roosevelt to bring about labor unity.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP).-- Congress has been told that Germany is building better military planes than the United States, primarily because it leads the world in aircraft research and development.

Until Wednesday, March 15, Czechoslovakia was still an independent republic. All goods manufactured in that country prior to that date were entitled to be marked "Made in Czecho-Slovakia," and all such goods had a special interest for Americans who wished to aid the industries of a people whom ...

Nationally known figure skaters, ranging in age from eight years to eighty-four will participate in the sixth annual carnival of the Skating Club of New York, which is to open tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden. The complete cast, ...

MOSCOW, March 22.--From this capital it appeared today that Britain had thought over her refusal of Soviet Russia's proposal for a conference of six powers interested in the present European crisis [Britain, France, Poland, Rumania, Turkey and the Soviet Union].

MEXICO CITY, March 22.--Before bidding good-bye today to Donald R. Richberg, who is leaving for Washington tomorrow, President Lazaro Cardenas acted to increase the efficiency and lower the costs of government operation of the oil fields of expropriated companies.

The Travelers Aid Society spent $101,000 in 1938 to aid 47,910 persons, it was announced yesterday by Virginia Murray, the executive secretary of the society, in its annual report. An additional $10,000 will be needed this year to cope with problems created by the World's Fair, she said.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--Secretary Wallace of the Department of Agriculture is confident that, in so far as the executive branch of the government is concerned, details of the program under which it is hoped to recapture a fair share of the world's cotton markets will be in hand within a week.

For the first time in nine years a Brooklyn school gained sole ownership of the city senior high P.S. A.L. basketball championship, when James Madison High crushed Jamaica High of Queens, 44 to 32, in the final-round play-off at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

ROME, March 22.--In its comment on the Fascist Grand Council's resolution the press today stresses in extremely firm tones that Italy is ready to march with Germany against the so-called democratic bloc. It warns that the democracies should harbor no illusions on this point.

Telegraphic protests against the Treasury Department's order imposing countervailing duties of 25 per cent on dutiable German merchandise were sent last night to President Roosevelt and to the Secretaries of the Treasury, State, Commerce and Agricultural Departments by the Board of Trade for German-American Commerce.

Film programs to be shown tomorrow, Saturday and Sunday, unless otherwise specified, have been endorsed as suitable for children 14 years and under by the Schools Motion Picture Committee, voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in

KAUNAS, Lithuania, March 22.-- Having bowed to the German demand for the immediate surrender of Memel territory, the Lithuanian Government proclaimed a state of emergency throughout the country today and also called up two annual classes of army reserves in order to be prepared for any eventualities.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--In a note written partly in Czech and partly in Slovak, Vladimir Hurban, the Minister of Czecho-Slovakia who last week refused to yield his legation to the German Embassy, confirmed that refusal formally to Dr. Hans Thomsen, the Charge d'Affaires of Germany.

Plans to reduce the number of memberships in the New York Stock Exchange have been shelved, as interest in the proposal does not appear to the board of governors to warrant continued study of the project. Only 521 of the 1,375 members replied to an informal questionnaire by Edward E. Bartlett ...

CLEVELAND, March 22 (AP).-- William McGeorge, a 53-year-old cost accountant, tucked a rabbit's foot charm into his watch pocket today and forthwith rolled a perfect 300 game at the American Bowling Congress.

A campaign against price-cutting in the printing industry was urged yesterday by Hunter Snead, sales promotion manager of the Electrical World, at a "Successful Selling" luncheon held in conjunction with the printing exposition of the New York Employing Printers Association at the Hotel Astor. Associated Printing Salesmen, Inc., was a co-sponsor of the luncheon.

TRENTON, March 22.--Acting on a report from his investigators that many fraudulent practices in the administration of relief had been found in West New York, Director Arthur Mudd of the New Jersey Financial Assistance Commission suspended State financial aid to the municipality today and mailed the report to Mayor Joseph Stilz.
CHICAGO, March 22.--The wheat market showed considerable strength in the early trading today because of the unsettled European political news. Prices advanced ...

Until some better means of acquainting the public with sales messages is devised, advertising of today's general type seems destined to remain a major industry and an accepted merchandising method, according to The Index, published by the New York Trust Company.

It is to be recorded that the Mozart Requiem, with short new choral works by Burle Marx, the Brazilian composer, and the Bach Fifth Brandenburg Concerto, were performed at the concert given by the Schola Cantorum, Hugh Ross, conductor, last night in Carnegie

ALBANY, March 22.--Governor Lehman rejected today the request of the New York City Affairs Committee for a "searching legislative inquiry" into the judiciary in Brooklyn, holding that if the committee has any evidence of misconduct it should present "such information to Special Assistant Attorney General John Harlan Amen."
Bond values broke sharply yesterday in more active trading on the New York Stock Exchange, the decline more than wiping out the gains recorded in the half-hearted recovery movement of the two pre

WASHINGTON, March 22.--A fleet of thirty-one combatant vessels will be employed this Summer in the training of officers and enlisted men of the United States Nacal Reserve and the American Merchant Marine. Every reserve unit of the service is included in the training program, which will apply to four areas, the Atlantic, the Gulf of Mexico, the Pacific, including Hawaii, and the Great Lakes.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 22.-- Under the patronage of many prominent residents, St. Agnes Guild of Holy Trinity Church presented Oliver Stewart, tenor, in a concert tonight at the home of Mrs. Woods Plankinton for the benefit of the guild's charities.

POWELL, Wyo., March 22 (AP).-- Entrenched in a fort of mountain rocks, Earl Durand, fugitive slayer, shot down two besiegers in a battle late today with a posse of sixtyfive Wyoming and Montana officers. Those slain had fallen on a slope directly in the line of fire from Durand's citadel, 400 feet up the side of a steep ridge.
MOSCOW, March 22.--The AllUnion Communist party congress, which ended here yesterday, elected a new central committee of seventy-one members, with sixty-eight "candidates," or alternates.
Several leases of space by business firms for expansion purposes were reported by brokers yesterday. Many of the commercial rentals of the day involved quarters in the Fifth Avenue district.

LONDON, March 23.--The House of Commons gave enthusiastic endorsement today to the government bill providing legal authority for the British Treasury's swift action in impounding all Czecho-Slovak gold, bank balances and securities in this country.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The State, War and Navy Departments united today in approval of the Pittman resolution to "assist the governments of American republics to increase their military and naval establishments" as the first step in what may be a long-range program to coordinate the national defenses of the various nations of the Western Hemisphere.

The crisis that confronts the Jewish people as a result of Nazi expansion in Europe is a "danger signal" for all minorities and carries with it the seeds for destruction of the rights of all small peoples, Rabbi Jonah B. Wise, national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal for Refugees and Overseas Needs, warned last night.

ALBANY, March 22.--The Commission of Correction renewed today a recommendation that inmates of the Fifth District, or Harlem, Prison, 170 East 121st Street, be searched before being returned to their cells after court appearances.

The decision of 500 members of Local 16 of the United Office and Professional Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate, to transfer their allegiance to the American Federation of Labor was termed a "deliberate spite action" yesterday by Peter K. Hawley, president of the local.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--The White House collection of famous paintings was enriched today by the addition of a Lincoln portrait which was thought by his son, Robert Todd Lincoln, to be the best likeness of his father in existence. The work of G.P.A. Healy, the portrait was the gift of Mrs. Mary Todd Lincoln, who died in March, 1937.
