ROME, March 22.--It was learned today that a whole family of Hungarian Jews drowned themselves at Taormina, Sicily, on March 11-- Mrs. Kuerschner, two sons, Dr. Arthur and Eugene Kuerschner, and one daughter, Renee.
Evidence of continued interest in taxpayer sites close to new residential developments in Queens was provided yesterday when the sale of a corner plot in St. Albans was announced.

The group of East Side boys who four years ago went through the routine of an apprehended criminal as a lesson in crime prevention held a reunion last night and helped project a "preventarium" in which boys from all over the city might benefit by the type of experience they found helpful.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--A New York State resident with a $500,000 taxable income would have to pay taxes under Federal and existing State income tax laws of $26,130 more than his entire year's taxable receipts under the bill to "take the profit out of war," introduced yesterday by fifty Senatorsprobably an unprecedented number to sponsor any single measure and more than a majority of the chamber.

CHICAGO, March 22 (AP).--Championship caliber basketball--of the college, professional and prep school varieties--will set up a practical "court laboratory" for the country's college coaches this week-end.

LONDON, March 22.--While Germany celebrated still another territorial acquisition today the British Government ran into momentary difficulties with its proposal for a four-power declaration pledging resistance to further acts of German aggression.
HIALEAH, Fla., March 22 (AP).-- John F. Dwyer, retired New York Police Inspector, is dead here from injuries suffered in a fall, and will be buried tomorrow in the Miami Cemetery.

CHICAGO, March 23.--The highly publicized Hochstetter process for de-inking newsprint struck a snag here today at the convention of the National Association of Waste Materials convention when Dr. F.W. Hochstetter was charged with using better-than-newsprint waste materials for his recent Pittsburgh newspaper tests.

A trade practices bill, suggestive of the Robinson-Patman act and more sweeping than the Parsons "loss leader" measure which has passed the Assembly, has been introduced in Albany and was being studied carefully in retail circles here yesterday. The bill, which affects ...

LONDON, March 22.--The scheme to guarantee non-intervention with an international cordon around all frontiers of Spain finally collapsed today as a result of the refusal of Germany and Italy to pay their overdue contributions.

North American Edison Company 5 per cent debentures due in 1969 and the 5 per cent debentures due in 1963 were stricken from listing and registration by the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. They were suspended from dealings on Feb. 4 upon being called for redemption.

Large fields will compete in the leading stakes of the second Jay F. Carlisle Memorial Trial for all retriever breeds on Saturday and Sunday under the auspices of the Labrador Retriever Club at Sands Point, L.I. Drawings for the three events were held yesterday at the residence of Mrs. Morgan Belmont in this city.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 22. --"Vigil in the Night," Dr. A.J. Cronin's new novel destined for Fall publication, was purchased today by RKO as a vehicle for Carole Lombard. George Stevens will direct. It is reported that Producer Pandro S. Berman paid $75,000 for the rights to the book by the author of "The Citadel." The story is ...

Frank A. Horne of 409 Grand Avenue, Brooklyn, president of the Merchants Refrigerating Company, 17 Varick Street, and one of the leading Methodist Episcopal laymen in the United States, died yesterday afternoon in the Methodist Episcopal Hospital, Brooklyn, of which he was president. He was born in Brooklyn seventy years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP). --A verdict carrying death in the electric chair brought from a murder trial judge tonight the declaration that "scores and scores of victims" perished at the hands of a group which poisoned for insurance money.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--After reversing the vote it cast yesterday for the sharply restrictive amendment proposed by Senator Wheeler, the Senate adopted today the bill giving limited powers to President Roosevelt to reorganize government bureaus and agencies.

ALBANY, March 22.--Brandishing on the floor of the Assembly a "switch-blade" knife, an ominouslooking weapon with a blade four inches long and a handle slightly longer, Assemblyman Burrows, Negro Democrat, virtually "intimidated" the House into passing a bill classifying the knife as a dangerous weapon along with guns, blackjacks, sawed-off shotguns and other arms of the underworld.

Michel Fokine's "Les Elfes" had its first performance here at the hands of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo in the Metropolitan Opera House last night, with Mia Slavenska and Igor Youskevitch in its chief roles.

Chancellor Hitler was aboard a battleship last night bound for his new outpost in the east, Memel, formal surrender of which had been made by Lithuania in a treaty signed in Berlin, which included a non-aggression clause. [Page 1; text of treaty, Page 4.] German troops started their occupation of Memel early today. [Page 5.]

A marked improvement in the inventory situation of American industry is shown by three new monthly indices developed during the past year by the economic research division of the National Industrial Conference Board, Virgil Jordan, president, announced yesterday.

A Syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co. marketed yesterday the issue of $15,500,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds due on March 1, 1964, of the Northern States Power Company, a Wisconsin corporation. The bonds were priced at 106 and accrued interest.
The tenth annual report of the Niagara Hudson Power Corporation and subsidiaries, which will be forwarded today to stockholders, shows for 1936 a consolidated net income of $7,195,520.

The Democratic Presidential nomination issue was injected last night into the prospective primary contests for Tammany district leaderships when Thomas Palmieri announced that he would oppose Dr. Paul A. Santangelo for the leadership of the First Assembly District and would support Paul V. McNutt, former Governor of Indiana and Commissioner to the Philippines, for the Presidential nomination next year.

CLEVELAND, March 22 (AP).--A simple pendulum--an iron ball and a wire-swung back and forth today in a Cleveland office. Its oscillations threatened to break into an explosion among the world's track and swimming stars.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--Over the objections of the New York Stock Exchange, which asserted that the issuer had not complied with its "rule" for withdrawal of securities from listing, the Securities and Exchange Commission today granted an application of Dominion Stores, Ltd., to withdraw from listing and registration on that Exchange 280,014 shares of nopar common stock, effective at the close of trading on April 17.

COPENHAGEN, March 22.--Official sources here disclaim any knowledge of a debate in the Altinget, the Iceland Parliament, over the question of allowing Germany to erect military air bases in Iceland. The story appeared in the Danish Communist paper, the Arbeiterbladet, and has been repeated ...

Stranahan, Harris Co., Inc., and Watling, Lerchen Hayes won yesterday the award of $736,000 of highway improvement refunding bonds of Oakland County, Mich., on an interest cost basis to the county of 2.927 per cent. The successful bid ...

Stanley Cup hockey warfare will be resumed tonight on three widely separated fronts. Here at Madison Square Garden the New York Americans, beaten by the Toronto Maple Leafs in the opener, will seek to even the score with the Queen City skaters in their series. At the same time the Rangers will oppose the Boston Bruins on the latter team's home ice, while the Canadiens and Red Wings see action at Detroit.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 22. --Mrs. William Lyon Phelps, wife of the author, lecturer and retired Yale Professor of English Literature, died this morning of a stroke of apoplexy. She was stricken upon arising and lapsed into unconsciousness after calling Professor Phelps.
TAMPA, Fla., March 22 (AP)--One wabbly inning for Bucky Walters gave the Red Sox all they needed today to down the Reds, 3 to 0.

LONDON, March 22.--Captain Sir Sidney Herbert, Conservative M.P. for the Abbey division of Westminster, one of London's "silk stocking" constituencies, and son of the late Sir Michael Herbert, formerly British Ambassador in Washington, died today at the age of 48.

Miss Hope Sands has arrived from Philadelphia and is visiting Mrs. Francis D. Gallatin at the Park Lane. Mrs. Gallatin will be matron of honor for Miss Sands at her marriage to Richard G. Leonard on April 22 in the Church of the Heavenly Rest here.

The American Council to Combat Nazi Invasion will be the sponsor of a "Stop Hitler" parade Saturday, it was announced yesterday. Members of the United Czecho-Slovak Societies, Rumanians, Lithuanians, Hungarians and other national groups, many in native costume, will participate.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--Indications that Congress might take into its own hands the question of tax revision as a business stimulant increased on Capitol Hill today as many members came to the conclusion from recent developments that President Roosevelt would not lead the movement.
HAINES CITY, Fla., March 22.-- The great American League experiment took place today and, judging from surface indications with satisfactory results.

A reception at the Jacques Seligmann Galleries, 3 East Fifty-first Street, on the afternoon of April 3 will serve to open the annual Public Education Association benefit, which this year will be an exhibition of paintings by famous artists on theatrical subjects. Much interest already has been aroused in the show, which will be entitled "The Stage."

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP).-- Counsel for the Missouri Pacific Railroad and the Stedman committee, which represents about S225,000,000 of Missouri Pacific first and refunding bonds, argued today before the Interstate Commerce Commission in behalf of their respective reorganization plans for the bankrupt carrier.

A team that never made a mistake, Long Island University snapped Loyola's twenty-one-game winning streak and extended its own to twenty-four by scoring a smashing victory over the Chicagoans in the final of the national invitation basketball tournament at Madison Square Garden last night, 44 to 32.

ALBANY, March 22.--Following conferences of Republican party leaders here, it was reported tonight that a substantial agreement had been reached for the imposition of a State-wide sales tax in place of Governor Lehman's tax program, with the tax to be accompanied by a substantial cut in the budget.

NEW ORLEANS, March 22 (AP). --Miss F.M. Hill's 5-year-old Royal Flight, in the money only once in eight previous outings, smashed the Fair Grounds record for a mile and a half today with a five-length victory in the feature.

AINTREE, England, March 22 (AP).--Lord Bicester's chestnut gelding, Rockquilla, jumped up among the first five favorites as a large crowd arrived in Liverpool today for Friday's running of the Grand National Steeplechase. The throng came from Lincoln, where it had watched the Lincolnshire.
Long Island Sound yachtsmen are slated to compete in their first 1939 championship regatta on May 20, according to the tentative schedule announced yesterday. The new season ...

PROVIDENCE, March 22 (AP).-- A "test case" truck strike in Rhode Island spread with paralyzing force to Massachusetts and Connecticut tonight in a sudden development in a wage dispute between 1,200 truck operators and 10,000 drivers in the three States.

Henry J. Ficke, for a number of years employed by the Holmes Protective Agency, received a suspended sentence yesterday in the attempted "fix" of the jury that convicted James J. Hines, and Salvatore Di Sapio, a barber also involved, received an indeterminate sentence up to three years.

Under the burden of further ominous developments in the European crisis and of discouraging events at home, the stock market cracked badly yesterday.

PARIS, March 22.--Even though one more large section of the Austro-Hungarian Empire of his ancestors has passed under German control, Archduke Otto of Habsburg does not abandon hope that some day, somehow that empire can be reunited and that in its reunion its people will find that liberty and welfare they used to enjoy.

Over the vigorous objections of Mrs. Johanna M. Lindlof, the Board of Education at its regular meeting yesterday afternoon assigned an acting supervisor of lunchrooms to centralize the New York City high school cafeteria system.

Net profit of the Glenn L. Martin Aircraft Company amounted to $2,349,355 in 1938, or more than twice the amount earned in 1937, according to a report issued yesterday. The profit, which was after ...

With Walter R. Kramer of Detroit and Mrs. Del Barkhuff of Seattle, defending titleholders, heading the lists, the most representative field to gather for the national amateur badminton championships will start play this morning in the third annual tournament.

MEET the Baseball Bookworm. No, not Professor Moe Berg. That learned gent doesn't have to look into books any more. He has read all there are two or three times. The Baseball Bookworm is a big, round-faced, genial young fellow in a Yankee uniform, 6 feet 2 inches, 210 pounds, just turned 25 years old. The name is Joseph Emmet Gallagher.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22.--The Dodgers beat the Cardinals today, 6--4, before 1,144 fans and the victory brought a satisfied feeling to Larry MacPhail and Leo Durocher.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP).-- The Interstate Commerce Commission sent today to Congress a comprehensive report on transportation proposing creation of a temporary agency to study emergencies facing the railroads and reorganization of its own functions to expedite decisions.

NEWARK, N.J., March 22.-- Professor Albert Einstein visited the Newark airport here today and in a rapid-fire explanation full of algebraic symbols completely baffled an airport publicity man who had started out to give the scientist a technical explanation of a new radio altimeter.
WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP).-- Congress gave final approval today to a $358,000,000 rearmament bill, authorizing the army Air Corps to build its fighting strength up to 6,000 airplanes.

The extent to which our New York City school system is becoming more practical in the sense of fitting certain students with a specific means to earn a living is shown clearly by the report of the vocational department made public by Dr. Campbell.

BERLIN, Thursday, March 23 (AP). --German troops marched into Memel territory promptly at 5 o'clock this morning formally to take possession of Chancellor Adolf Hitler's latest territorial acquisition.

After hearing advocates and opponents of a zoning change in the Riverdale section of the Bronx that would make it a "G" zone, restricting it to one-family dwellings, the City Planning Commission continued its public hearing for one week yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--In passing today the Second Deficiency Appropriation Bill, carrying $186,672,028 in funds and contract authorizations, members of both parties administered a rebuke to the Federal Bureau of Investigation and its director, J. Edgar Hoover, for over-obligating its appropriation by $266,000 in the appointment of 113 additional persons without authorization of law or the funds with which to pay them.

A slight reversal of the moderately upward trend in steel bookings and production is in evidence, and unless there is a sharp increase in business over the remainder of the month, March totals for all products will be little, if any, above those of February, although it is a longer month, Iron Age says this week.

SHANGHAI, March 22 (AP).--The Chinese-Japanese conflict, once more characterized by far-flung positional warfare in addition to guerrilla operations, surged toward new decisions in five disputed provinces today.

ALBANY, March 22.--Special New York City legislation is being held up in the Legislature by the failure of the city's authorities to send the emergency messages which are required under the new Constitution. Formerly the messages came from the Governor, but it is now necessary that the request for the passage of special acts must come from the Mayor and Council, or twothirds of the members of the Council.
LONDON, March 22.--"Mr. and Mrs. Brown," as London calls President Albert Lebrun of France and Mme. Lebrun, again moved through London today to a continual roll of cheers and crash of bands.

ALBANY, March 22.--A bill carrying a jail sentence of two years or a fine of $10,000 for any member of the Legislature if he should charge a fee for services rendered to a person holding a claim or entering into a controversy to which the State was a party was introduced today by Senator Desmond of Newburgh.
Two apartment houses, one in Newark, N.J., and the other in Manhattan, figured in one of the New Jersey deals reported yesterday.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 22.-- Carl Hubbell and Hal Schumacher unveiled their reconditioned pitching arms in their first test of the exhibition season today and the result proved an unqualified success.
HAVANA, March 22.--Holders of Havana city waterworks bonds have brought suit against the city for $759,385 in defaulted interest and amortization payments for eighteen months.

Three Brooklyn detectives and a professional bondsman were arrested yesterday on charges of extorting $500 last June 4 from Louis Rothenbeig, owner of a grocery store at 427 Kingston Avenue, Brooklyn. They were held in $2,500 bail each in Brooklyn Felony Court for hearing next Monday.

Peter Fick of the New York Athletic Club captured the metropolitan senior A.A.U. 100-yard free style championship, one of the feature events of the Dolphin Society water carnival, at the Columbia University pool last night.

The expansion of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association's program for cleaning and beautifying the city in preparation for World's Fair visitors was aided last night by a percentage of the proceeds from dinners and suppers given in the Trianon Room of the Ambassador.

WASHINGTON, March 22.--Resenting John L. Lewis's attack upon "hidebound aristocrats of the American Federation of Labor," the members of the Federation's Executive Council met this afternoon to frame a reply to questions directed at their peace committee by the peace committee of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Saturday is the final registration date for architects who wish to participate in the architectural competition for the Smithsonian Gallery of Art in Washington. The competition, authorized by the Seventy-fifth Congress, is for the purpose of selecting a design for the proposed new art museum.

Picturing himself as an innocent victim of the combined treachery of an unscrupulous bail bondsman and an attorney whose friendship and word he had relied upon, Magistrate Mark Rudich of Brooklyn took the witness stand at his own removal hearing yesterday. He denied emphatically that he ever had received bribes for approving bail bonds or had knowingly accepted surety from a person who did not own the property offered.

Many court decisions recently have emphasized the fact that public housing is a necessary and logical governmental function. The highest tribunals in thirteen States now have upheld the validity of various measures adopted in those States in behalf of low-rent housing and slum clearance, supplementing the provisions of the United States Housing Act.

Edward P. Trainer, business manager of Local 33, Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, announced yesterday that he had asked Secretary of Commerce Harry Hopkins to investigate application of the seamen's eight-hour law as affecting licensed officers and engineers. In a letter addressed to the Secretary, Mr. Trainer charged that the ...

DANZIG, March 22.--Nazis here rejoice over Memel's return to Germany. The city is beflagged, schools received a holiday, uniformed Storm Troopers paraded the streets and there were thanksgiving services in all Protestant churches.

Uncertainty over developments in Europe as well as possible changes in farm legislation brought a further setback in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and the list closed with losses of 2 to 8 points.

The payoff in the Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer policy racket case was begun yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora gave J. Richard (Dixie) Davis one year in a penitentiary and Harry Schoenhaus a suspended sentence. It will be completed This morning when James J. Hines, Tammany district leader, goes before General Sessions Judge Charles C. Nott Jr. to learn his punishment after conviction in the same case.

Mayor La Guardia has addressed a circular letter to all judges, court officials and others whose salaries are protected by constitutional or statutory provisions asking them to take voluntary pay cuts ranging from 5 to 10 per cent to help the city meet a "difficult situation" in its budget for the fiscal year starting July 1, it was learned last night.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP).-- Senator Bailey suggested today that the National Rivers and Harbors Congress set an example of "selfimposed restraint" in preparing plans for Federal waterway projects.

LONDON, March 23.--In the belief that yesterday's break had been overdone, the stock markets today looked to hopes of a joint declaration by the democracies and felt that the temperate tone in the King of Italy's speech justified a more cheerful tendency.

The King and Queen of England are to be invited to attend the New York races on the occasion of their visit to the World's Fair this Summer, it became known at the Jockey Club yesterday where the stewards held one of their periodical meetings.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--Farm and railroad problems and developments in the international situation occupied the attention of President Roosevelt today, as he spent most of the day in the White House with a slight head cold.

ATLANTIC CITY, March 23.-- Demands for high prices by the brush manufacturers forced the government to establish its own brush factory at Leavenworth Penitentiary, Representative Joseph B. Shannon, Democrat, of Missouri, told the twenty-second annual meeting of the American Brush Manufacturers at the Hotel Traymore here today.
Mrs. Harriet Readshaw Browne, dramatic interpreter, poet, musician, lecturer and special feature writer, died on Wednesday at her home, 200 West Fifty-seventh Street, after a year's illness.

Possible completion of the $1,000,000 Czecho-Slovak exhibit at the World's Fair was the subject of a conversation yesterday between Mayor La Guardia and Vladimir Hurban, Czech Minister to the United States.

The Agfa Anseo Corporation, Binghamton, N.Y., manufacturer of cameras and photographic supplies, in its report for 1938, issued today, shows a net income of $991,925 after provision for depreciation, reserves, interest and $182,528 estimated United States and Canadian income taxes.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23.-- Denis Cardinal Dougherty arrived home today from Rome voicing confidence that outbreaks in Nazi Germany would end and that the Catholic Church would emerge triumphant over any perils that might threaten it.

Eleven members of the old and prosperous Italian Fornari family that traces its history in Rome back for 300 years arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex as refugees from the recent antiSemitic edicts of the Fascist party.

Urho Toivola, chairman of the press committee for the 1940 Olympic Games at Helsingfors, who is visiting the United States to explain Finland's Olympic set-up, tendered a press reception yesterday at the Hotel Barclay.

The opening of "The Happiest Days," previously slated for March 29, has been postponed until April 3. Marc Connelly has taken over the directorial assignment, succeeding Robert Steiner. The Charlotte Armstrong play is due at the Vanderbilt.

Grassmere, one of the historio farm estates in the Hudson Valley near Rhinebeck, in Dutchess County, has just changed hands.
A Congressional investigation of the Works Progress Administration may have some useful results. But it does not promise to go very far toward solving the real problem before Congress.

Encouraged by a more confident tone in the European markets stocks here swung upward yesterday from the depths to which they had plunged in the previous day's fit of depression.

The Trianon Room of the Ambassador was the setting last night for a dinner dance, given for members of the junior entertainment committee of the Society of Mayflower Descendants.
As head man in "The Hot Mikado," which was put on at the Broadhurst last evening, Bill (Bojangles) Robinson does not come on until the second act.

Rush-hour service on the Interborough subway lines from 8 to 9 A.M. showed "remarkable Improvement" during the past week, according to testimony given before the Transit Commission yesterday by Colonel William C. Lancaster, chief engineer for the commission.

Shipbuilders of the country, through the National Council of American Shipbuilders, agreed yesterday to join with shipowners in putting on at the World's Fair an elaborate nautical exhibit designed to "spot-light the American merchant marine," Grower A. Whalen, Fair president, announced yesterday.

Plane for the first store in this city of Flagg Brothers, retailers of men's shoes, were announced yesterday when the concern leased the four-story building at 123 West Forty-second Street from the estate of George Henry Warren.

LONDON, March 23.--In historic Westminster Hall, where the leaders of England assembled during centuries of struggle with France, President Albert Lebrun and Mme. Lebrun were welcomed today by the Members of Parliament and the peers of the realm.
The first of four performances of the Skating Club of New York's sixth annual charity carnival will be presented tonight at Madison Square Garden.

RYE, N.Y., March 23.--George Palmer Putnam, the publisher, has sold his estate here, where he resided with his wife, Amelia Earhart, without once returning to it since Miss Earhart disappeared over the Pacific during her roundthe-world flight in the Summer of 1937, it was learned today.

BOSTON, March 23.--Dr. John Kittredge Browne, oldest Harvard College graduate and for thirtyseven years a missionary in Turkey, died today in Auburndale, Mass., at the age of 95. He was graduated from Harvard in 1869.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., March 23. --Ronald Colman was signed today to play the lead in Paramount's forthcoming production of Rudyard Kipling's "The Light That Failed." Robert Carson is preparing the scenario and William Wellman will direct with production scheduled for early Summer.

Barr Brothers Co., Inc., yesterday bought $1,000,000 of Utica, N.Y., tax anticipation certificates of indebtedness at 0.123 per cent, plus a premium of $4. The certificates, dated March 24, will be payable on July 24, 1939.
Unsleeping to protect the purity of an ancient institution, Mr. Sleeper of the Maine House of Representatives introduced a bill forbidding the use of tomatoes in clam chowder.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--Sale of $24,880,000 of railroad equipment trust certificates and $2,140,000 of bridge bonds to Salomon Brothers Hutzler of New York at a premium of $1,005,315 was announced this afternoon by Jesse H. Jones, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

George D. Brooke received $62,118 in 1938 from the Chesapeake Ohio Railway and as president of the Chesapeake Ohio, the New York, Chicago St. Louis (Nickel Plate) and Pere Marquette Railways, the C. O. announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP).-- The government appealed to the Supreme Court today from a decision by a New York Federal District Court holding unconstitutional a Federal-State milk marketing agreement for the metropolitan New York area.

PINEHURST, N.C., March 23.-- Coming within one stroke of the record for the tournament, Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., won the annual seventy-two-hole North and South open golf championship over the No. 2 course of the Pinehurst Country Club today with a score of 280. He was the only contestant to crack par on every round.
PRAGUE, March 23.--The German Penal Code today was officially imposed on the BohemianMoravian protectorate by order of Colonel General Walther von Brauchitsch, Commander in Chief of the German Army.

LONDON, March 23.--Despite a rally in the stock market today, British capitalists are joining with European financiers in the rush to send their money in the form of gold to safety in the United States.

Net profit of the Aviation Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on Nov. 30, 1938, amounted to $187,909 after all deductions, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--Every Latin-American Government is a "republic" in the official view of the Administration, regardless of the status of its internal affairs, Sumner Welles, Acting Secretary of State, emphasized in testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee made public today.

Some of the hitherto unrevealed wonders of the new "frequency modulation" radio broadcast system developed by Major Edwin H. Armstrong, Columbia University electrical engineering professor, were demonstrated last night at the university at a meeting of the Radio Club of America.

The program given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, john Barbirolli, conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall was simple, but too long, and heavy as unbaked dough in its principal contents.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--Increasing espionage by foreign agents in the United States has led the detective forces of this government to meet regularly and pool their information, Attorney General Murphy revealed today.

Increased attention by adult education to the development of leaders capable of dealing with current problems was advocated yesterday at the sixth annual meeting of the New York Adult Education Council at the Hotei Astor.

With the best Spring skiing prospects in five years reported in the Berkshires, Adirondacks, Green and White Mountains and the Canadian Laurentians, snow enthusiasts are expected to descend in large numbers upon popular sports centers this week-end in anticipation of good trail and slope running.

Joseph Miller, 50 years old, a coat manufacturer, was shot three times about 8 o'clock last night by one of two thugs who pounced on him as he was about to stop his automobile in front of his home at 219 West Tremont Avenue, the Bronx. His assailants escaped.

Generally improved earnings for the first quarter of 1939 were reported at company meetings held yesterday. Shareholders of American Steel Foundries, Dayton Rubber, Consolidated Film, Robert Gair and Van Raalte were told that last yeax's results had been bettered.

PITTSBURGH, March 23.-- Owing to somewhat better than seasonal gains in production and originating shipments, business in the Pittsburgh district moved slightly higher last week, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 23.-- Thatchcote was the setting tonight for a large dinner given by Mrs. Benjamin Rogers for Miss Betty Lou Dillingham who, with her mother, Mrs. Walter F. Dillingham of Honolulu, is the guest of Mr. and Mrs. I. Sheldon Tilney.

About 330 savings, buildings and loan associations in all sections of the country having resources of about $500,000,000 will complete their fiftieth anniversary this year, the United States Building and Loan League announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--The House World War Veterans Committee is expected to report out tomorrow the Rankin bill providing $40 a month pensions to World War veterans reaching the age of 65 and granting liberalized pensions to widows and children of veterans.

Rumania is spending $1,000,000 on its exhibit at the World's Fair, ac-- cording to Dr. Demeter Gusti, Rumanian Minister for Social Services and commissioner general to the Fair, who arrived yesterday on the Italian liner Rex.

WASHINGTON, March 23.--A registration statement covering a $40,000,000 issue of "new money" debentures bearing 3 per cent interest and maturing on April 1, 1959, was received today by the Securities and Exchange Commission from the Texas Corporation.

Harold Haugh, tenor, and David Blair McClosky, baritone, gave a joint recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Their program featured German and English duets. Each of the singers also contributed a group of German Lieder.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 23 (AP).-- The men who write about New York politics tonight depicted Thomas E. Dewey, New York's racket-smashing prosecutor, as a Boy Scout hitch-hiker en route from Owosso, Mich., to Washington, but it all was in fun.
Proposals presented by the scale committee for a new contract with the operators were adopted yesterday at the closing session of the tri-State convention of anthracite miners at the Hotel Commodore,

Shanty Shops, a restaurant chain, will establish its twenty-eighth store in the metropolitan area at 19 East Forty-eighth Street, where it has leased the store and basement from the Guaranty Trust Company.

Effective April 1 the Associated Dry Goods Corporation will discontinue its merchandise buying office here. Three of the member stores will become members of the Cavendish Trading Corporation group and two will be represented by the Mutual Buying Syndicate, according to a joint announcement yesterday.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, March 23,--Morris de Castro, Acting Governor of the Virgin Islands, was host today to Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark and his wife, Crown Princess Ingrid, and also Vice Admiral Adolphus Andrews, President Roosevelt's representative, who arrived yesterday aboard the cruiser Indianapolis.

Oil taken from allegedly "undersized" whales, meaning less than seventy feet long, figured in a libel filed in Federal court yesterday by Earle N. Bishopp, assistant United States attorney, against 1,483 barrels ...

WASHINGTON, March 23.--Reports of a proposed trade whereby $265,000,000 in parity and conservation payments to farmers would be retained in the billion dollar Agriculture Department Supply Bill for 1940 in return for the full $150,000,000 requested as a deficiency item for relief came today as the House began consideration of the bill.

Representative J. Parnell Thomas of New Jersey, who is a Republican member of the Dies Committee, said yesterday that it was time for the business men of Wall Street to hire their own paid lobbyists to ...
DETROIT, March 23.--The Red Wings drew even with the Canadiens in the Series C National Hockey League play-off by staging a four-goal last-period rally to triumph, 7 to 3, tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)-- The Senate approved today sharp revisions of the Sugar Quota Act in a move to increase shares for mainland cane and beet areas.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 24. --Undismayed by the rather unexpected reverse heaped upon him by the Athletics in the two exhibition jousts over the week-end, Colonel Bill Terry led his Giants eighty miles down the Mississippi today to open fire upon Ossie Vitt's Indians tomorrow in New Orleans.

What was believed to be an attempt to kidnap the granddaughter of Bishop William T. Manning, Betsy Coale, 3 years and 4 months old, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith Baily Coale of 125 West Eleventh Street, was foiled last night by the Coales' Negro butler while the infant's parents were out dining with Newbold Morris, President of the City Council.
Chairman Eccles's statement before a Senate committee serves to clarify the controversy between the supporters of Government spending and the advocates of Government economy.

MEXICO CITY, March 24.--A 17-year-old smuggling charge was used today as the ground for the arrest and imprisonment of Edgar K. Smoot, 77-year-old Virginian, who has been long a resident of Mexico. Mr. Smoot's recent Supreme Court victory in a land seizure case will be the subject of a Congressional investigation at the special session called for April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Administration moved unexpectedly today to implement its business recovery efforts with a proposal to modify social security payroll taxes for old age insurance so as to save employers and employes more than $200,000,000 in the next two years and to eliminate "avoidable burdens on American productive enterprise."
Mayor La Guardia's travels in the last five years have involved a cost of $1,012.77 to the city aside from his trips to Albany and Washington, Controller Joseph D. McGoldrick reported yesterday.

John Harlan Amen, special prosecutor investigating alleged "fixing" involving Brooklyn officials, ordered yesterday the arrest of a 40-yearold accountant for posing as one of Mr. Amen's "chief investigators" and demanding $5,000 from a director of a Brooklyn hospital to "fix" a non-existent inquiry into alleged "irregularities" involving the hospital.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Several minor amendments to the new rules under Section 17(c) of the Holding Company Act and an amendment to the recently announced amendment of Rule U-3A3-1, requiring banks to take steps to get rid of any holdings of any voting securities of publicutility holding companies or subsidiaries in excess of 10 per cent of any such issue, were announced today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
A legislative bill to permit religious instruction in the public schools of this State is opposed by the Board of Education, James Marshall, president of the board, announced yesterday.

Trading in the local wholesale markets was only fair yesterday for a Friday. A very light lamb kill and higher replacement costs forced lamb prices sharply higher. Steer hinds and ribs were steady to weak and other classes mostly steady. The kosher markets opened slow with beef steady to higher; lamb sharply higher; veal about steady. Conditions as reported by the United State Department of Agriculture, follow:

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 24. --Mr. and Mrs. Grower Loening gave a dinner tonight at Manana Point for his brother, Albert Palmer Loening, Mayor of Southampton, L.I., and Mrs. Loening and their son, Albert P. Loening ...

Plans for a new apartment house in Brooklyn were announced yesterday in connection with the sale of a plot of land on the west side of East Thirteenth Street, 90 feet north of Avenue R, with a frontage of 73 feet and a depth of 127 feet.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Supply contracts valued at $4,016,518 wets awarded during the week ended March 18 by twelve Federal agencies under the provisions of the Public Contracts Act, the Labor Department announced today.
LONDON, March 24.--The British Government looked ahead tonight to an uneasy respite of uncertain duration before the next of Germany's hammer strokes descends upon Europe.
Rules governing statistical or investment advisory services by members of the New York Stock Exchange have been adopted by the committee on member firms and circulated to the membership.
Building projects submitted yesterday included plans for a threestory office building at Church and Leonard Streets. Architects also filed for an apartment house at Seaman Avenue and 218th Street.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.--Belief that the death toll of an alleged poison murder-insurance ring said to have been operating here for ten years might exceed 100 was voiced today by Judge Harry S. McDevitt, who presided at the poison murder ...

SLIM VALLEY, Idaho, March 24 (AP).--Walter Prager today won the 18-kilometer race, first event in the national four-way ski championships. The Dartmouth College coach was timed in 54:30 for the difficult 11.2-mile cross-country course over the rolling foothills of the Sawtooth Mountains.
PRINCETON, N.J., March 24.-- Princeton's varsity Rugby team opened its Spring campaign with a 21-0 victory over Cornell on Bedford Field today.

The recovery in bond values continued yesterday over a broad front, with foreign dollar loans and United States Government issues leading the way. The trading pace slackened, however, and the turnover of $5,214,700 on the Stock Exchange was the smallest for a full day in more than a month. Domestic corporation bonds also were generally higher, under the leadership of public utility and secondary railroad issues.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 (AP).-- In jail today awaiting sentence were Joe Shaw, brother and secretary to former Mayor Frank L. Shaw, and another figure high in the Shaw administration, farmer Civil Service Commissioner William H. Cormack.
Mrs. Del Barkhuff of Seattle, winner of the title the past two years, was eliminated from the women's national amateur badminton championship last night at the 165th Regiment Armory.
Four new ballets for next season's repertoire of the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo were announced yesterday by S. Hurok, general manager of the company.
Mr. and Mrs. Gurdon W. Wattles gave a dinner last night in the Iridium Room of the St. Regis.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, March 24 (AP).--Autonomy for Hungarian and Germanic minorities in Rumania was reported tonight to be under informal preliminary discussion among the Berlin, Budapest and Bucharest governments.

WASHINGTON, March 24.-- Following are the replies of Senators when asked if they had read the bill for taxing war profits, offered by Senator Bone in the Senate Tuesday, and listing them and others as the sponsors:
An active anti-returns campaign to begin immediately was authorized yesterday at a meeting of the fair trade committee of the National Coat and Suit Industry Recovery Board.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Federal Trade Commission announced today that it has accepted from three dealers selling their products in interstate commerce stipulations to cease misleading sales representations.

The fifty-seventh annual report of the United Gas Improvement Company and subsidiaries, which is being forwarded to shareholders today, shows a consolidated net income for 1938 of $26,832,668, as compared with $29,105,379 in 1937, a decrease of $2,272,711.
RENO, Nev., March 24.--A divorce was granted today to Mrs. Beatrice Flagg Iselin, wife of Oliver Iselin, merchant and banker of New York. Mrs. Iselin charged cruelty.

Seldom has the portrait of a public character been traced with more fullness of detail than in the probation report on James J. Hines. It is an instructive and a curious biography, this story of the blacksmith's apprentice who was to come to such a dismal end.
GREENSBORO, N.C., March 24 --W. Lawson Little of Bretton Woods, N.H., the former amateur king, blazed the way today with a record-shattering score in the $5,000 Greensboro open golf tournament.

Following the announcement by the New York Yacht Club of the dates of its August cruise, the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., yesterday made known plans for a cruise in June, supplanting its annual one in August.

PARIS, March 24.--President Albert Lebrun and Foreign Minister Georges Bonnet returned to Paris this evening from their socially successful visit to London and were greeted by another display of interwined British and French flags and by much cheering, which was ...
At last the criticism that has been directed against the contemplated $47,000,000,000 reserve fund ever since the Social Security Act was passed has become effective.
MOSCOW, March 24.--Robert S. Hudson, secretary of the British Department of Overseas Trade, began talks this afternoon with Anasthasius I. Mikoyan, Commissar of Foreign Trade.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Upon returning from a two-week vacation in Florida today, Secretary of State Cordell Hull condemned the military occupation of Czecho-Slovakia and other aggressive acts of the German Government.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.-- Howard Eldridge Cornell, a naval architect and consulting engineer, who formerly was an Assistant Director of Public Safety here, died in Germantown Hospital on Wednesday after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

NEWARK, N.J., March 24.--Official Federal records entrusted to Mayor Meyer C. Ellenstein in March, 1937, have never been returned to the Federal Government and are now missing, Special Prosecutor Warren Dixon Jr., showed today at the Newark meadowland conspiracy trial.

Miss Dorothy Fitch Nutt of 511 East Eighty-sixth Street, daughter of Mrs. Edward Bulkeley van Zile of Chesham, N.H., and of the late Robert H. Nutt, was married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church to William ...

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Continued increases in employment and payroll totals were reported today by Secretary Perkins, who announced that approximately 45,000 workers had been added to industrial payrolls between Jan. 15 and Feb. 15 and that wage disbursements in the period rose almost $3,900,000 weekly.

Representatives of the Appalachian bituminous coal operators and the United Mine Workers of America paused in their negotiations for a new contract here yesterday to urge Congress to enact an excise tax of 3 cents a gallon on fuel-oil imports as a means of protecting American oil and coal from "exceedingly destructive competition."

CLEVELAND, March 24 (AP).-- Two division leads changed hands tonight in the American Bowling Congress tournament. The Old Frankenmuth Beers of Detroit replaced the F. Ziehm Company of Cleveland as five-man leaders with 995, 963, 999, for a total of 2,957. The Clevelanders had rolled 2,924.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange has voted to close the market on Good Friday, April 7.

An explosion accompanied by streaks of flame and a cloud of black smoke shook the 7,000-ton oil tanker Reaper in a Brooklyn drydock early yesterday afternoon. Four men were injured by the blast, which startled the waterfront and brought fifteen piece of fire-fighting apparatus as well as police reinforcements.

For the third time within a month Martin T. Manton, former senior judge of the Second United States Circuit Court of Appeals, was indicted yesterday for selling his judicial power to a litigant, John L. Lotsch, who was named a co-defendant.

In the John Hall Memorial Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 342 East Sixty-third Street, "The Upper Room" was opened this week. It was named after the room in which Christ ate His last supper with His disciples.

The development of highly sensitive biochemical and physiological tests to determine the existence of dietary deficiencies was reported yesterday before the annual conference of the Milbank Memorial Fund at the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service.

As fighting between Hungarian and Slovak forces continued, the Bratislava Cabinet announced that it would appeal to Germany to protect the Slovak borders as provided in the treaty recently signed. Hungarian planes raided an airport in the interior of Slovakia, and twelve persons were reported killed. [Page 1.]
CHICAGO, March 24 (AP).--Allen Hall of Chicago reduced Joe Chamaco's first place lead in the national three-cushion billiard tournament today by defeating the Mexican star twice.

A new beach club costing about $100,000 is contemplated for Atlantic Beach, L.I., as a result of the leasing of a 700-foot strip of beachfront property in Scheer Beach, at the westerly end of the resort, close to Long Beach.

Clement J. Driscoll, Commissioner of Weights and Measures and First Deputy Police Commissioner under Mayor Gaynor in 1910, died yesterday at his home, 272 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, after an illness of several months. He was 56 years old.

The big fish are still giving the anglens plenty of excitement in the Gulf Stream off Miami Beach. According to Tommy Aitken at the Metro politan Miami Fishing Tournament, "You can't tell what will happen next."

The preliminary annual report of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, released yesterday, shows a consolidated net income for 1938 of $7,038,590 after all expenses, taxes and charges, including foreign exchange losses.

MADRID, March 24.--A Republican peace mission returned to Madrid from Burgos tonight with Generalissimo Francisco Franco's conditions for the surrender of Republican Spain. The National Defense Council under General Jose Miaja met immediately to consider them.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--Of the fifty Senators listed as sponsors of the war profits tax measure when it was introduced in the Senate Tuesday by Senator Bone of Washington, only six besides the four real authors of the bill would say today that they had actually read it through.

PHILADELPHIA, March 24.-- Basing his plea on an alleged admission of perjury, counsel for Ellis H. Parker, former Burlington County (N.J.) detective, and his son, Ellis Jr., convicted of kidnapping Paul H. Wendel as an aftermath of the Lindbergh case, asked the Federal Circuit Court of Appeals here today to open the way for a new trial.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 24.--Feasting on the Class A.A. minor league pitching of their Kansas City farm club, the Yankees touched a new high for the season in circuit clouting at Waterfront Park today as they buried the Blues, 8 to 3, and stretched their winning streak to six straight.

WHEN we talk about the American way of life we usually overlook the fact that-- beyond the fundamental liberties--there are a good many different ways of life within the Republic's borders. But in the world of the novel-- as Grace Lumpkin's "The Wedding," a story of a Southern town, reminds us--these distinctions are often more or less scrupulously observed.

POWELL, Wyo., March 24.-- Wounded in a desperate attempt to hold up a bank in his home town, Earl Durand, untamed mountain man who had killed four peace officers in nine days in the greatest man hunt in the history of this State, put a bullet through his head today.
Contrasting results for February were reported yesterday by the New York Central and Pennsylvania Railroads in respect to passenger revenues.

CHICAGO, March 24.--A.J. Hayes, general manager of the Central Cooperative Wholesale, Superior, Wis., was elected chairman of the board of National Cooperatives, Inc., joint buying federation of consumer cooperatives, at a meeting of the directors here today. The chairmanship is a new position.
Thousands of trade unionists as well as other groups are expected to take part this afternoon in the "Stop Hitler" parade, terminating ...
Migratory birds from the South have been arriving in the Bronx Park. They include, according to Dr. W. Reid Blair of the Zoo, a few robins, purple finches, fox sparrows and flickers.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 24.-- Returning to the stage after fifteen years, John Barrymore opened here tonight in the McCarter Theatre in "My Dear Children," a new play by Catherine Turney and Jerry Horwin. At curtain time no standingroom was available.
The United States Maritime Commission held a hearing at 45 Broadway yesterday on the refusal of the United States-Baltic Conference to admit the Thorden Line to membership.

Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York contributed a total of $509,504 last year to the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, which in turn distributed the entire sum to various home and foreign missions, it was reported yesterday to Bishop Stephen J. Donahue, administrator of the archdiocese.
Plots of vacant land in Forest Hills and St. Albans again figured in the Queens realty trading reported yesterday by brokers, when apartment house and taxpayer sites changed hands.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP).-- Representatives of the ports of Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Norfolk, Va., asked the Maritime Commission today for more favorable rates on traflic from South America.

WASHINGTON, March 24.--The Gatineau Power Company of Montreal, Canada, filed today under the Securities Act of 1933 a registration statement covering $62,500,000 of first mortgage 3 per cent bonds, Series A and B, due on April 1, 1969, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced.
Juliana Force, director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, announced yesterday plans that have been arranged for the museum's extra-mural participation in the New York World's Fair.
